6 - Al-Muḥaqqiq mentioned in "Al-Mu'tabar," page 22, explaining two interpretations regarding the sprinkling of water:
   The first interpretation: That it refers to sprinkling the ground to consolidate its particles, thereby preventing rapid drainage of water separated from the body into the water.
   The second interpretation: That it refers to wetting the body, then performing ghusl with it to hasten the ghusl before separated water drains into the water.
7 - Referenced in "Al-Mustadrak," volume 1, page 217, Hadith 1. Similar content in "Fiqh al-Ridha," page 85, referenced in "Bihar al-Anwar," volume 81, page 52, continuation of Hadith 23. In "Bihar al-Anwar," volume 80, page 139, from "Al-Tahdhib."
Sheikh considered three scenarios:
Firstly: That this ghusl is among the recommended ghusls and not the ghusl of janabah, as it is not permissible to use water that has been used for the ghusl of janabah.
Secondly: That the ghusl is relevant only in circumstances of necessity.
Thirdly: That the ghusl applies to someone whose body does not carry any impurity.

6 باب الحائض، والمستحاضة، والنفساء ورؤيتهن الدم، وغسلهن وما يجب عليهن من الصلاة وتركها إعلم أن أقل أيام (1) الحيض ثلاثة أيام، وأكثرها (2) عشرة أيام (3) (4).

البياض لا صفرة ولا دما، فإنها تغتسل وتصلي وتصوم، فإذا رأت الدم أمسكت عن الصلاة فإذا رأت الطهر صلت، وإذا رأت الدم فهي مستحاضة قد انتظمت لها (1) أمرها كله (2).
فإن رأت الدم أكثر من عشرة أيام، فلتقعد عن الصلاة عشرة أيام، وتغتسل يوم حادي عشر وتحتشي، فإن لم يثقب الدم الكرسف صلت صلاتها كل صلاة بوضوء، فإن غلب الدم الكرسف ولم يسل صلت صلاة الليل وصلاة الغداة بغسل، وسائر الصلوات بوضوء، وإن غلب الدم الكرسف وسال صلت صلاة الليل وصلاة الغداة بغسل (3)، والظهر والعصر بغسل، تؤخر الظهر قليلا وتعجل العصر، وتصلي المغرب والعشاء الآخرة بغسل واحد، تؤخر المغرب قليلا، وتعجل العشار الآخرة إلى أيام حيضها، فإذا دخلت في أيام حيضها تركت الصلاة (4).
فان (5) رأت المرأة الصفرة في أيام الحيض (6) فهو حيض، وإن رأت في أيام الطهر فهو طهر (7).

translation:
Whiteness, neither yellowness nor blood, means she should perform ghusl (ritual purification) and pray and fast. If she sees blood, she should cease praying, and when she sees purity again, she should pray. If she sees blood, she is considered mustahada (experiencing irregular bleeding), and her affairs are organized.

If she sees blood for more than ten days, she should refrain from praying for ten days, perform ghusl on the eleventh day, and use a cotton pad. If the blood does not saturate the cotton, she should pray each prayer with wudu (ablution). If the blood overcomes the cotton but does not flow, she should perform ghusl for the night prayer and the dawn prayer, and perform wudu for the rest. If the blood overcomes and flows, she should perform ghusl for the night prayer and the dawn prayer, as well as for both the Zuhr and Asr prayers, delaying the Zuhr slightly and hastening the Asr. She should perform ghusl once for both Maghrib and Isha prayers, delaying the Maghrib slightly and hastening the Isha until her period ends. When she begins her menstrual period, she should stop praying.

If a woman sees yellow discharge during her menstrual days, it is considered menstrual blood; if she sees it during the days of purity, it is considered purity. 

This text includes references from various religious texts, such as "al-Mustadrak," "al-Kafi," "Fuqaha' al-Rida," "Bihar al-Anwar," and others, which discuss rulings related to menstruation and purity.

وإن (1) رأت الصفرة في أيام طمثها، تركت الصلاة لذلك بعدد أيامها التي كانت تقعد في طمثها، ثم تغتسل وتصلي، فإن رأت صفرة بعد غسلها فلا غسل عليها، يجزيها الوضوء عند كل صلاة وتصلي (2).
فإن طمثت المرأة بعد ما تزول الشمس ولم تصل الظهر، فليس عليها قضاء تلك الصلاة (3).
وإذا رأت الصفرة والشيء ولا (4) تدري أطهرت أم لا، فلتلصق (5) بطنها بالحائط، ولترفع رجلها اليسرى كما ترى الكلب يفعل إذا بال، وتستدخل (6) الكرسف، فإن كان دم خرج ولو مثل رأس الذباب، (فإن خرج فلم) (7) تطهر، وإن لم يخرج فقد طهرت (8).
وإذا رأت الدم خمسة أيام (والطهر خمسة أيام) (9)، (أو ترى الدم أربعة أيام والطهر ستة) (10) أيام (11)، فإذا رأت الدم لم تصل، وإذا رأت الطهر صلت، تفعل

translation:
If a woman sees a yellowish discharge during her menstrual period, she should refrain from praying for the number of days she usually experiences her period. Once these days have passed, she must perform a full ritual wash (ghusl) and then she may resume her prayers. However, if she notices a yellowish discharge after performing ghusl, she does not need to perform another ghusl; it suffices for her to perform ablution (wudu) before each prayer.

If a woman menstruates after the sun has passed its zenith and she has not prayed the Dhuhr (noon) prayer, she is not required to make up for that prayer.

If she observes a yellowish discharge and something unsure whether she is pure or not, she should press her belly against the wall, lift her left leg like a dog does when urinating, and insert cotton. If blood appears, even as small as a fly's head, then she is not pure. If no blood appears, then she is considered pure.

If she sees blood for five days and then cleanliness for five days, or she sees blood for four days and cleanliness for six days, whenever she sees blood she does not pray, and when she sees cleanliness, she resumes her prayers.

The above text references Islamic jurisprudence related to women's prayer obligations during and after their menstrual cycles. It refers to various classical sources and religious texts on how to handle specific circumstances regarding menstrual purity and prayer obligations.

ذلك ما بينها (1) وبين ثلاثين يوما، فإذا مضت ثلاثون يوما ثم رأت دما صبيبا اغتسلت واستثفرت واحتشت (2) بالكرسف في وقت كل صلاة، وإذا رأت صفرة توضأت (3).
وإذا طهرت المرأة (4) عند العصر فليس عليها أن تصلي الظهر، إنما تصلي الصلاة التي تطهر عندها (5).
وإذا (6) رأت الحبلى الدم، فعليها أن تقعد أيامها للحيض، فإذا زاد على الأيام الدم، استظهرت بثلاثة أيام ثم هي مستحاضة (7).
وإن ولدت المرأة قعدت عن الصلاة عشرة أيام إلا أن تطهر قبل ذلك، فان استمر بها الدم تركت الصلاة عشرة أيام، فإذا كان يوم حادي عشر، اغتسلت واحتشت واستثفرت (8)، وعملت بما تعمل المستحاضة (9).

translation:
The time span between the two events (1) is thirty days. Once thirty days pass and blood is seen flowing, she must perform Ghusl (ritual purification), and secure and pad with cotton during each prayer time. If she sees a yellowish discharge, she should perform ablution (3). 

If a woman purifies herself at the time of 'Asr (afternoon prayer), she is not required to pray Dhuhr (noon prayer), and should only perform the prayer at which she became purified (5). 

If a pregnant woman sees blood, she should refrain from her prayers during her regular menstruation days. If the bleeding exceeds those days, she should observe three additional days, after which she is considered to have istihaadah (non-menstrual bleeding) (7). 

If a woman gives birth, she should refrain from prayer for ten days unless she purifies herself before that. If bleeding continues, she should cease praying for ten days, but on the eleventh day, she must perform Ghusl, secure herself, and act according to how a woman with istihaadah would (9).

وقد روي أنها تقعد ثمانية عشر يوما (1).
وروي عن أبي عبد الله الصادق - عليه السلام - أنه قال: أن نساءكم لسن (2) كالنساء الأول، إن نساءكم أكبر (3) لحما وأكثر دما فلتقعد حتى تطهر (4).
وقد روي أنها تقعد ما بين أربعين يوما إلى خمسين يوما (5).
وإذا وقع الرجل على امرأته (6) وهي حائض، فإن عليه أن يتصدق على مسكين بقدر شبعه (7).
وروي إن جامعها في أول الحيض فعليه أن يتصدق بدينار، وإن (8) كان في وسطه (9) فنصف دينار، وإن كان في آخره فربع دينار (10).

translation:
It has been narrated that she should sit for eighteen days. It is also reported from Abu Abdullah Al-Sadiq, peace be upon him, that he said: "Your women are not like the women of old; your women have more flesh and more blood, so they should refrain until they become pure." It has also been narrated that she should sit between forty to fifty days.

If a man has intercourse with his wife while she is menstruating, he is required to give charity to a poor person equivalent to a full meal. It is narrated that if he has intercourse during the beginning of the menstruation, he should give one dinar in charity; if in the middle, half a dinar; and if towards the end, a quarter of a dinar.

This information is referenced in various sources, including the "Bihar al-Anwar," volume 81, page 111, hadith 33, and "Al-Wasa'il," volume 2, page 390, among others. The compiler of "Al-Faqih" commented that the narrations suggesting a waiting period of forty days or more until purification are attributed to precautionary measures (taqiyya) and are only issued by those who oppose.

These traditions regarding the requirement for charity during menstruation are also documented in "Bihar al-Anwar," volume 81, page 116, hadith 39, and "Al-Wasa'il," volume 2, page 328, among others.

وإن جامعت أمتك وهي حائض تصدقت بثلاثة أمداد (1) من طعام (2).
واعلم أن دم العذرة (3) لا يجوز الشفرتين (4)، ودم الحيض حار يخرج بحرارة شديدة، ودم المستحاضة بارد يسيل منها وهي لا تعلم (5).
وإذا اشتبه على المرأة دم الحيض ودم القرحة، فربما كان في فرجها قرحة، فعليها أن تستلقي على قفاها وتدخل إصبعها، فإن خرج الدم (من الجانب الأيمن فهو من القرحة، وإن) (6) خرج من الجانب الأيسر من الحيض (7)، وإن افتضها زوجها ولم يرقأ (8) دمها، ولا تدري دم الحيض هو أم دم العذرة، فعليها أن تدخل القطنة، فان خرجت (9) القطنة مطوقة بالدم فهو من العذرة، وإن خرجت القطنة

translation:
If a servant engages in intercourse with his maid while she is menstruating, he should give in charity three measures of food. Be aware that the blood of virginity does not pass the labia, whereas menstrual blood is hot and flows with intense heat, and the blood of istihadah (prolonged or irregular bleeding) is cold and flows without the woman being aware. 

If a woman is uncertain whether the blood is menstrual or from a sore, she might have a sore in her vagina. She should lie on her back and insert her finger. If the blood comes from the right side, it is from the sore; if it comes from the left side, it is menstrual blood. If her husband has deflowered her and the bleeding does not stop, and she is unsure whether it is menstrual blood or virginity blood, she should insert a piece of cotton. If the cotton comes out encircled with blood, it is from virginity; if not, it is menstrual.

1 - A "mudd" is the amount that two hands can hold of food, which is a quarter of a sa'. See "Majma' al-Bahrain: 2/180 - Mudd -".
2 - Refer to Al-Bihar: 81/116, end of hadith 39, and Al-Mustadrak: 2/22, end of hadith 2. Also in Fiqh al-Rida: 236, and Al-Faqih: 1/53, end of hadith 9, and Al-Hidaya: 69 similarly.
3 - Virginity blood *Majma‘ al-Bahrain: 2/142 – ‘Adhara -".
4 - The labia: the flesh surrounding the vagina like lips surround the mouth *Majma‘ al-Bahrain: 1/522 – Shafr -".
5 - Fiqh al-Rida: 194, similar to him, in Al-Bihar: 8/93 hadith 12. Also in Al-Hidaya: 22 similarly, and likewise in Al-Faqih: 1/54 from his father's letter. In Al-Kafi: 3/91 hadith 1 - hadith 3, and Al-Tahdhib: 1/151 hadith 1 - hadith 3, about its ending, both in Al-Wasa'il: 2/275 – Books of Menstruation – chapter 3, hadith 1 - hadith 3.

In Al-Tahdhib: 1/385 hadith 8 with a difference in the phrasing at the beginning, and narrated in Al-Kafi: 3/94 hadith 3, where it says, "If the blood comes from the right side, it is from menstruation, and if it comes from the left side, it is from the sore” both in Al-Wasa'il: 2/307 – Books of Menstruation – chapter 16 hadith 1 and hadith 2.
8 - “Flowing” A, C, D, Al-Mustadrak. What does not stop flowing from the blood: that which does not cease *Majma‘ al-Bahrain: 1/207 – Riq’*.

منغمسة فهو من الحيض (1).
وإذا صلت المرأة من الظهر ركعتين فحاضت، قامت من مجلسها ولم يكن عليها إذا طهرت قضاء الركعتين، وإن كانت في صلاة المغرب وقد صلت ركعتين فحاضت، قامت من مجلسها، فإذا طهرت قضت الركعة (2).

translation:
Certainly! Here is the translated text:

Immersed as it is from menstruation (1).
If a woman is praying and starts menstruating after praying two units of the Dhuhr prayer, she should rise from her place and is not required to make up those two units once she has purified herself. However, if she is in the Maghrib prayer and has completed two units before menstruation starts, she should rise from her place, and once she is purified, she needs to make up for the missed unit (2).

1. From Al-Mustadrak: 2/6, Hadith 1, and from Fiqh Al-Ridha: page 194, it is similar. Also found in Al-Faqih: 1/54 from the epistle of his father, and in Al-Mahasn: page 307, Hadith 21, and the end of Hadith 22, in Al-Kafi: 3/94, Hadith 2 and the end of Hadith 1, and in Al-Tahdhib: 1/152, Hadith 4, and page 385 within Hadith 7 similarly, sourced from Al-Wasa'il: 2/272 - chapters on menstruation - chapter 2, Hadith 1 - Hadith 3. Also in Al-Bihar: 81/93 within Hadith 12 from Fiqh Al-Ridha.

2. From Al-Mustadrak: 2/33, Hadith 2, and similarly in Al-Faqih: 1/52. Found in Al-Kafi: 3/103, Hadith 5, Al-Tahdhib: 1/392, Hadith 33, and Al-Istibsar: 1/144, Hadith 3 with slight variation in wording, sourced from Al-Wasa'il: 2/360 - chapters on menstruation - chapter 48, Hadith 3. It was also issued in Al-Mukhtalif: 39 by Ibn Babawayh.

The scholar said: The narration should be interpreted for someone who missed the Maghrib prayer rather than Dhuhr, and the makeup of the single unit refers to completing the remaining prayer, with the use of “unit” for the entire prayer being metaphorical.

7 باب غسل الميت، وتكفينه، وتحنيطه، وتشييعه، ودفنه، والصلاة عليه إذا دخلت على مريض فقل: أعيذك بالله العظيم، رب العرش العظيم، من شر كل عرق نعار (1)، ومن شر حر النار، سبع مرات (2).
فإذا صار في حال النزع فلقنه كلمات الفرج، وهي (3): لا إله إلا الله الحليم الكريم، لا إله إلا الله العلي العظيم، سبحان الله رب السماوات السبع ورب الأرضين السبع، وما فيهن وما بينهن، ورب العرش العظيم (4).

translation:
Chapter 7: Washing the Deceased, Shrouding, Embalming, Funerals, Burial, and the Funeral Prayer

If you visit a sick person, say: "I seek refuge for you with Allah, the Almighty, Lord of the Great Throne, from the evil of every pulsing vein and the heat of the fire," seven times.

When the person is in the throes of death, instruct them with the words of reassurance, which are: "There is no deity but Allah, the Forbearing, the Generous, there is no deity but Allah, the Most High, the Great. Glory be to Allah, Lord of the seven heavens and the seven earths, and all within and between them, and Lord of the Great Throne."

Notes:
1 - "A vein pulsating" means it is gushing with blood. [Refer to Lisan al-Arab: 5/221].
2 - Referenced similarly in "Tibb al-A'imma: 118," and cited in "Wasail: 2/465 - Chapter of Dying - B 40, H 7." It's also similarly mentioned in "Makarem al-Akhlaq: 392," and cited in "Bihar al-Anwar: 81/228, H 40."
3 - This phrase is not present in version "B."
4 - Cited in "Al-Mustadrak: 2/128, H 3." It's also found in "Al-Kafi: 3/122, H 3," and "Al-Tahdheeb: 1/288, H 7" with slight variations in the beginning, and in "Al-Kafi: 3/124, H 7 and H 9," "Al-Faqeeh: 1/77, H 1," and "Al-Tahdheeb: 1/288, H 8" similarly. They are also cited in "Wasail: 2/459 - Chapter of Dying - B 38 H 1 - H 3." In "Al-Hidaya: 23" with slight variations.

فان عسر عليه نزعه واشتد عليه، فحوله إلى (1) مصلاه الذي كان يصلي فيه أو عليه (2) (3).
واقرأ عند رأسه (والصافات صفا) حتى تستتمها، فإنها لم تقرأ عند كل (4) مكروب إلا عجل الله راحته (5).

ولا يجوز أن يحضر الجنب والحائض عند التلقين، لأن الملائكة تتأذى بهما (10)،

translation:
If he finds it difficult to remove it and it becomes severe for him, then move him to his prayer place where he used to pray or on it. Recite at his head "By those [angels] lined up in rows" (Al-Saffat) until you complete it, for it has never been recited for someone distressed without God hastening their relief. When he passes away, say: "Indeed, we belong to God, and indeed, to Him we will return. O God, record him with You among the humble, elevate his rank in the highest levels, succeed his descendants among the remaining, and count him with You, O Lord of the worlds."

It is not permissible for someone in a state of major ritual impurity or a menstruating woman to be present during the talqeen because the angels are troubled by them.

It is permissible for them to perform his washing and to pray over him, but they should not lower him into his grave. If they are present at the time of the declaration of faith (tahniyah) and cannot avoid it, they should leave before his soul departs. Be cautious not to touch the dying person when they are in the throes of death.

text:
صفة غسل الميت أن يصب (1) الماء في إجانة (2) كبيرة، ثم يلقى (3) عليها السدر وتؤخذ (4) رغوته (5) في طشت (6)، ثم ينوم (7) الميت على سرير مستقبل القبلة، ثم ينزع القميص عن رأسه إلى موضع عورته، ويغطى به، ولا يكشف (8) عن العورة، ثم يؤخذ (9) من الماء ثلاث حميديات (10) ثم يقلب على ميامنه، فيصب عليه ثلاث حميديات من قرنه إلى قدمه، (ثم يقلب على مياسره، فيصب عليه ثلاث حميديات من قرنه إلى قدمه) (11)، فهذا الغسل الأول.
ثم يجعل الماء في الاجانة بعد ما تنظف من ماء السدر، ويلقى في الماء شيء

translation:
The method of washing a deceased person involves pouring water into a large basin, then adding some sidr leaves. The foam is collected in a dish. The deceased is then laid out on a bed facing the Qibla. The shirt is removed from the person's head to the private area, covering it, without exposing the private parts. Then, three large scoops of water are taken and the body is turned onto its right side, pouring three scoops from head to foot. Subsequently, the body is turned onto its left side, and again, three scoops are poured from head to foot. This constitutes the first washing.

Afterward, the basin is cleaned of the sidr water, and fresh water is poured into it. A specific formulation is implied but not explicitly detailed in the text.

Note: Explanatory glossary has been provided for terms such as:
1 - Large basins or utensils where the wash water is poured and mixed.
2 - Sidr foam refers to the frothy top layer that forms when sidr leaves are mixed with water.
3 - The term "hamidiyat" refers to large scoops or containers, likely used for pouring water during the washing ritual.

text:
من جلال الكافور (1) وشئ من ذريرة (2)، ثم يغسل كما غسل من السدر، فإذا فرغ من ماء الكافور، غسل الأواني بماء القراح (3)، وفعل به كما فعل به في ماء السدر والكافور، ثم يغسل القوم أيديهم إلى المرفقين، ثم يؤخذ قطن (4) ويلقى عليه الذريرة ويجعل على مقعدته، ثم يشد فخذيه بخرقة على مقعدته ويستوثق القطن بهذه الخرقة (5).
ثم يكفن (في قميص، يجعل القميص) (6) غير مزرور ولا مكفوف (7)، وإزار يلف على جسده بعد القميص، ثم يلف في حبر يماني عبري (8)، (أو أظفار نظيف (9)) (10).

translation:
From the small amount of camphor and a touch of powdered aromatic plant, the body is washed just as it was with the lotus leaves. After completing the camphor water wash, the utensils are rinsed with clear water, and the same process is repeated as with the lotus leaves and camphor water. Then, the people wash their hands up to the elbows. Next, cotton is taken, sprinkled with powdered aromatic plant, and placed at the back. The thighs are then wrapped with a cloth around the back to secure the cotton in place.

The body is then shrouded (in a shirt, with the shirt placed) without buttons or sewn edges, and a wrap is tied around the body over the shirt. It is then wrapped in a Yamani Hebrew shroud (or in a clean shroud).

1. A small amount of camphor: the slight or modest amount, as referred in "Majma’ al-Bahrain: 1/389 - Jall."
2. "Powdered aromatic plant from the lotus," according to the authoritative sources. The powdered aromatic plant: crushed sweet cane... most likely referring to any ground aromatic powder, as mentioned in "Majma’ al-Bahrain: 1/90 - Dhurur."
3. Clear water: water unmixed with anything, according to "Majma’ al-Bahrain: 2/482 - Qurrah."
4. "Take some cotton" from sources A, J, D. "Takes some cotton" from the authoritative sources.
5. Referenced from authoritative sources: 2 / 169 H 4, up to the mention of lotus and camphor water, and on p. 219 H 4 supplement. See al-Kafi: 3 / 141 H 5, referenced in al-Wasa'il: 2 / 480 - Chapters on washing the deceased - B 2 H 3. See al-Fiqh: 1 / 90 supplement H 16, and al-Hidaya: 24.
6. "Place the shirt" A, D. "In a shirt" B.
7. "Wrapped" A, D. And the edge of the garment sewn: stitches at its edges, as mentioned in "Majma’ al-Bahrain: 2 / 56 - Kaff."
8. Not mentioned in "A." "Hebrew" B. A Hebrew garment: attributed to a place called ‘Eber,’ a town, or side of a valley, according to "Majma’ al-Bahrain: 2 / 112 - ‘Eber."
9. "And aromatic shrouds" A, D. Sheikh in Tahdhib: 1 / 292 supplement H 21 - after mentioning the shrouding of the Prophet—peace and blessings be upon him and his family—with three garments, two Sahari robes, and a Yamani Hebrew or aromatic: the correct in my opinion was from Dhofar, which are towns. Al-Hamwi said in the dictionary: 4 / 60: Dhofar, a city in Yemen near Sana’a, to which the Yamani agate belongs.
10. Referenced from the authoritative sources: 2 / 219 supplement H 4. In al-Fiqh: 1 / 90 H 15 beginning, referenced in al-Wasa'il: 3 / 51 - Chapters on shrouding - B 28 H 3, and see Da'aem al-Islam: 1 / 231, referenced in Al-Bihar: 81 / 333 H 34. Mentioned by Shahid in Thakra: 48 about Ali ibn Babawayh on the method of shrouding: then cut his shroud, starting with a cloth, spreading the Yamani Hebrew over it, the wrapping over the Hebrew, and the shirt over the wrapping, and write on his shirt, wrap, and Hebrew. Then Sadouq said in Al-Muqni’ as his father, which corresponds to what's mentioned in al-Hidaya: 23, and apparently was missing from Al-Muqni’.

text: والكافور السائغ للميت أوقية (1)، (والوسط أربع) (2) مثاقيل (3)، وأقله مثقال (4)، ويجعل على جبينه (5) وعلى فيه وموضع مسامعه (6)، ويلقى فضل الكافور على صدره (7)، ويجعل معه جريدتان خضراوان من النخل (8)، إحداهما على جنبه الأيمن ما بين ترقوته إلى صدره، والأخرى فوق القميص وتحت الإزار على يساره في ذلك المكان (9)، فإذا فعل ذلك به وضع على السرير أو على الجنازة (10) وحمل (11).

translation:
The permissible amount of camphor for the deceased is one ounce, the medium amount is four mithqals, and the minimum is one mithqal. It should be placed on the forehead, the mouth, and the area around the ears. The excess camphor is placed on the chest. Additionally, two fresh, green palm branches are placed with the body; one on the right side from the collarbone to the chest, and the other above the garment and beneath the shroud on the left side in the same area. After these steps have been completed, the deceased is laid on the bed or the bier and then carried. 

References to further textual sources indicate thorough documentation of these practices, including discussions and variations found in classic works such as "Al-Kafi," "Al-Tahdheeb," and "Al-Istibsar," among others. The references show the intricate details and historical variations in the preparation of the deceased for burial as discussed by scholars.

text:
فإذا حضرت جنازة فامش خلفها ولا تمش أمامها، فإنما يؤجر من يتبعها لا من تبعته (1).
فإنه روي: إتبعوا الجنازة ولا تتبعكم فإنه من عمل المجوس (2).
وروي: إذا كان الميت مؤمنا فلا بأس أن (3) تمشي (4) قدام جنازته، فإن الرحمة تستقبله، والكافر لا تتقدم (5) جنازته، فإن اللعنة تستقبله (6).
وقال النبي - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -: أميران وليسا بأميرين، ليس لمن تبع جنازة أن يرجع حتى تدفن أو يؤذن له، ورجل يحج مع امرأة ليس له أن ينفر (7) حتى تقضي مناسكها (8).
واعلم أن من غسل ميتا مؤمنا فقال إذا قلبه: اللهم هذا (9) بدن عبدك المؤمن وقد أخرجت روحه منه وفرقت بينهما، فعفوك عفوك، غفر الله له ذنوب سنة إلا الكبائر (10).

translation:
When attending a funeral, walk behind the procession and not in front of it. The reward is for those who follow the funeral, not for those who precede it (1). It has been narrated: "Follow the funeral and do not let it follow you, for that is the practice of the Magi" (2). It is also narrated: "If the deceased is a believer, there is no harm in walking ahead of the coffin since mercy goes before it. However, if the deceased is a non-believer, do not precede the coffin, as a curse goes before it" (3).

The Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) said: "There are two leaders who are not true leaders: one who follows a funeral and is not allowed to leave until it is buried or unless permitted, and a man on a pilgrimage with a woman who is not allowed to depart until she has completed her rites" (4).

Know that if someone washes a deceased believer and says while turning him: "O Allah, this is the body of Your believing servant, whose soul You have removed and separated from the body. Forgive, forgive," then Allah will forgive the washer a year's worth of sins, except for major sins (5).

text:
وقال أبو عبد الله - عليه السلام -: من غسل ميتا مؤمنا فأدى فيه الأمانة غفر له (1)، قيل: وكيف يؤدي فيه الأمانة؟ قال: لا يخبر بما رأى (2).
وإذا مات الميت، وقد كان (3) دخل وقت الصلاة وهو حي ثم مات، فليقض عنه وليه تلك الصلاة (4).
وإذا مات ميت وهو جنب، فإنه يغسل غسلا واحدا يجزي عنه (5) لجنابته ولغسل الميت، (لأنهما حرمتان اجتمعتا في حرمة واحدة) (6) (7).
(وإن كان الميت) (8) مجدورا أو محترقا، فخشيت أنك إذا (9) مسسته سقط من جلده شيء، فلا تمسه ولكن صب عليه الماء صبا، فإن سقط منه شيء فاجمعه في أكفانه (10).
وإن كان الميت محرما غسلته وفعلت به ما تفعل (11) بالمحل، إلا أنه لا يمس

translation:
Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever washes a deceased believer and fulfills their duty with honesty, forgiveness is granted to them." It was asked: "How does one fulfill their duty with honesty?" He replied: "By not disclosing what they have seen."

When a person passes away and the time for prayer had already arrived while they were still alive, their heir should perform that prayer on their behalf.

If a deceased person was in a state of ritual impurity (janabah), they should be given a single ritual bath that suffices for both the impurity and the washing of the deceased (since both are obligations that converge in a single act).

If the deceased was afflicted with smallpox or was burned, and you fear that touching them might cause their skin to peel off, do not touch them; rather, pour water over them. If anything falls off, gather it within the shroud.

If the deceased was in a state of ihram (a state of consecration during pilgrimage), you should wash them and treat them as you would treat a non-consecrated person, except that you do not apply perfume.

Footnotes/references included in the Arabic text refer to traditional Islamic texts such as "Al-Bihar", "Amali Al-Saduq", and others, detailing the source of the teachings.

text:
طيبا (1).
وإن كان الميت أكله السبع فاغسل ما بقي منه، وإن لم يبق منه إلا عظام، جمعتها وغسلتها وصليت عليها، ودفنتها (2).
وإذا ماتت جارية في السفر مع الرجال، فلا تغسل وتدفن كما هي بثيابها (3) إن كانت بنت خمس سنين، وإن كانت بنت (4) أقل من خمس سنين، فلتغسل ولتدفن (5).
وإذا مسست ميتة فاغسل يدك، وليس عليك غسل، إنما يجب ذلك في الانسان وحده (6).

translation:
Tayyib (1).
If a person has been partially eaten by wild animals, wash whatever remains of them, and if only the bones are left, gather and wash them, pray over them, and then bury them (2).
If a young girl dies while traveling with men, she should not be washed but buried as she is in her clothes (3) if she is five years old. If she is younger than five (4), she should be washed and then buried (5).
If you touch a dead body, wash your hand, but a full ablution is not required unless it concerns a human (6).

text:
ولا بأس بأن ينظر الرجل إلى امرأته بعد الموت، وتنظر المرأة إلى زوجها ويغسل كل واحد منهما صاحبه إذا مات (1).
والمرجوم يغسل ويحنط ويكفن، ثم يرجم بعد ذلك، وكذا (2) القاتل إذا أريد قتله قودا (3) (4).
والمرأة إذا ماتت في سفر وليس معها ذو محرم، فإنها تدفن كما هي بثيابها، وكذلك الرجل إذا لم يكن معه رجال ولا ذو محرم، دفن كما هو بثيابه (5).
والمصلوب ينزل عن الخشبة بعد ثلاثة أيام ويغسل ويدفن، ولا يجوز صلبه أكثر من ثلاثة أيام (6).

translation:
It is permissible for a man to look at his wife after her death, and for a woman to look at her husband. Each may wash the other if one of them passes away. 

A person who has been sentenced to stoning (rajm) is to be washed, embalmed, and shrouded before the punishment is carried out. Similarly, a murderer sentenced to death by retribution (qisas) should receive the same treatment. 

If a woman dies while traveling and there is no male relative (mahram) with her, she should be buried in her clothes as they are. Similarly, if a man dies without men or a mahram present, he should be buried as he is, in his clothes.

A crucified individual is to be taken down from the cross after three days, washed, and buried. It is not permissible for the crucifixion to extend beyond three days.

text:
الصلاة على الميت فإذا صليت على الميت فقف عند صدره (1) وكبر وقل: أشهد أن لا إله إلا الله وحده لا شريك له، وأشهد أن محمدا عبده ورسوله، أرسله بالحق (2) بشيرا ونذيرا بين يدي الساعة.
وكبر (3) الثانية وقل: اللهم صل على محمد وآل محمد، وارحم محمدا وآل محمد، وبارك على محمد وآل محمد، كأفضل ما صليت وباركت وترحمت على إبراهيم (وآل إبراهيم) (4) إنك حميد مجيد.
وكبر الثالثة، وقل: اللهم اغفر للمؤمنين والمؤمنات، والمسلمين والمسلمات، الأحياء منهم والأموات.
وكبر الرابعة، وقل: اللهم عبدك (5) وابن عبدك وابن أمتك نزل بك، وأنت خير منزول به، اللهم إنا (6) لا نعلم منه إلا خيرا، وأنت أعلم به منا، اللهم إن كان

translation:
Prayer for the deceased: When you perform the prayer for the deceased, stand at their chest and say, "I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, with no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger. He was sent with the truth as a bearer of good news and a warner before the Hour."

Then, say the second Takbir and recite, "O Allah, bless Muhammad and the family of Muhammad, have mercy on Muhammad and the family of Muhammad, and bestow blessings upon Muhammad and the family of Muhammad, as You did upon Ibrahim (and the family of Ibrahim). Indeed, You are praiseworthy and glorious."

Say the third Takbir, and recite, "O Allah, forgive the believing men and women, and the Muslim men and women, the living and the dead."

Say the fourth Takbir, and recite, "O Allah, Your servant, the son of Your servant, and the son of Your maidservant has come to You, and You are the best to whom one can come. O Allah, we know of him only good, and You are more knowledgeable about him than we are. O Allah, if..."

text:
محسنا فزد في إحسانه، وإن كان مسيئا فتجاوز عنه واغفر له، اللهم اجعله عندك في أعلى عليين، واخلف على أهله في الغابرين (1)، وارحمه برحمتك يا أرحم الراحمين.
وكبر الخامسة، ولا تبرح [من مكانك] (2) حتى ترى الجنازة على أيدي الرجال (3).
وسئل بعض الصادقين - عليهم السلام - ولم يكبر على الميت خمس تكبيرات؟ فقال: إن الله عز وجل فرض (على الناس) (4) خمس صلوات، وجعل للميت من كل صلاة تكبيرة. (5) واعلم أن أولى من يتقدم للصلاة (على الجنازة) (6) من يقدمه ولي الميت، وإذا كان في القوم رجل من بني هاشم فهو أحق بالصلاة عليه إذا قدمه ولي الميت، فان تقدم من غير أن يقدمه الولي فهو غاصب (7).

translation:
If someone has done good, increase their reward, and if they have done wrong, pardon and forgive them. O Allah, place them in the highest ranks of paradise, and provide for their family among those left behind, and have mercy on them, O Most Merciful of the merciful.

Say the fifth takbir, and do not leave your position until you see the funeral being carried by the men.

Some of the pious individuals were asked: why do we say five takbirs over the deceased? They replied: Allah, the Almighty, has ordained five prayers for people, and has assigned a takbir for the deceased from each prayer.

Know that the one who should lead the funeral prayer is the person appointed by the deceased's family. If there is a man among the people from Banu Hashim, he is more entitled to lead the prayer if appointed by the deceased's family. If he leads without their appointment, he is considered to be usurping that right.

text:
ولا بأس أن (1) تصلي وحدك على الجنازة، وإذا صلى رجلان (على جنازة) (2)، قام أحدهما خلف الإمام ولم يقم بجنبه (3).
ونهى رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - أن يصلى (4) على قبر، أو يقعد عليه، أو يبنى عليه (5).
وإذا صليت على امرأة فقف عند صدرها (6).
والمحترق يصلى عليه، ويصب الماء عليه صبا ويدفن (7).
ولا بأس أن يصلي الجنب والحائض على الجنازة، إلا أن الحائض تقف ناحية ولا تختلط بالرجال (8).
[وروي أنه لا يجوز للرجل أن يصلي على جنازة بنعل حذو] (9).

translation:
It is acceptable to perform the funeral prayer alone, and if two men perform the prayer for a funeral, one of them should stand behind the imam without standing beside him. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his family, forbade offering prayers on a grave, sitting on it, or building on it. When performing the funeral prayer for a woman, one should stand at her chest. The burnt body should be prayed over, water should be poured over it, and it should be buried. It is also permissible for a person in a state of major ritual impurity or a menstruating woman to perform the funeral prayer. However, the menstruating woman should stand to the side and not mix with the men. 

[It is narrated that it is not permissible for a man to perform the funeral prayer while wearing shoes with laces.]

1. Referenced sources indicate variations in the text and confirm the position of the imam in congregational prayer.
2. The prohibition by the Prophet may imply not bowing or performing obligatory or supererogatory prayers on a gravesite, though it's open to interpretation.
3. References from various Islamic texts provide nuanced interpretations and slight variations in the traditions.
4. Contextual background from other Islamic scholarly sources.

text:
وإذا اجتمع جنازة رجل وامرأة وغلام ومملوك، فقدم (1) المرأة إلى القبلة، واجعل المملوك بعدها، واجعل الغلام بعد المملوك، واجعل الرجل بعد الغلام مما يلي الإمام، ويقف الإمام خلف الرجل، ويصلي عليهم جميعا صلاة واحدة (2).
وإذا كبرت على جنازة تكبيرة أو تكبيرتين، فوضعت جنازة أخرى معها، فإن شئت كبرت الآن عليهما جميعا (3) خمس تكبيرات، وإن شئت فرغت من الأولى واستأنفت الصلاة على الثانية (4).
وإذا صليت على جنازة وكانت مقلوبة (5)، فسوها وأعد الصلاة عليها (6).
وروي إذا اجتمع ميتان أو ثلاثة موتى أو عشرة، فصل عليهم جميعا صلاة واحدة، تضع ميتا واحدا، ثم تجعل الآخر إلى ألية الرجل، ثم تجعل رأس (7) الثالث إلى ألية الثاني شبه المدرج، تجعلهم على هذا ما بلغوا من الموتى، وقم في الوسط وكبر خمس تكبيرات، تفعل كما تفعل إذا صليت على واحد (8).

translation:
When the funeral of a man, woman, boy, and servant are gathered, place the woman closest to the qibla, then put the servant after her, followed by the boy, and finally the man closest to the imam. The imam should stand behind the man and perform a single prayer over all of them.

If you have already pronounced one or two takbirs over a funeral, and another funeral is brought to join it, you may either pronounce five takbirs over both together, or you may complete the prayer on the first and start a new prayer on the second.

If you have prayed over a funeral that was upside down, adjust the position and perform the prayer again.

It is narrated that if two, three, or even ten deceased are gathered, you should pray over all of them with a single prayer. Place one deceased body, then set the next at the foot of the first, then place the head of the third at the foot of the second, aligning them like steps. Continue this arrangement according to the number of deceased, stand in the middle, and pronounce five takbirs. This practice should be the same as when praying over one deceased.

translation:
**Chapter 8: Praying Over a Child**

Know that a child is not prayed over until they comprehend prayer. However, if you join a group praying over a child, you should say: "O Allah, make him a forerunner for his parents and for us."

10 باب الصلاة على المستضعف وإذا صليت على المستضعف (2) فقل: اللهم اغفر للذين تابوا واتبعوا سبيلك، وقهم عذاب الجحيم (3).

translation:
Chapter 9: Praying for Those Whose Sect is Unknown

If the sect of the deceased is unknown to you, say: "O Allah, this soul is one that You have given life to, and You have caused to die. O Allah, let it join with those it chose to follow and gather it with those it loved."

Chapter 10: Praying for the Weak

When praying for the weak, say: "O Allah, forgive those who repent and follow Your path, and protect them from the torment of Hell."

11 باب الصلاة على المنافق وإذا صليت على المنافق فقل بين التكبيرة الرابعة والخامسة: اللهم اخز عبدك في عبادك وبلادك، اللهم أصله أشد نارك، اللهم أذقه حر عذابك، فإنه كان يوالي أعداءك، ويعادي أولياءك، ويبغض أهل بيت نبيك.
فإذا رفع فقل: اللهم لا ترفعه ولا تزكه (1).
12 باب زيارة القبور وإذا زرت قبر المؤمن فقل: اللهم ارحم غربته، وصل وحدته، وآنس وحشته، وآمن روعته، وأسكن إليه من رحمتك رحمة يستغني بها عن رحمة من سواك، واحشره مع من كان يتولاه (2).

translation:
## Chapter 11: Praying Over a Hypocrite

When you pray over a hypocrite, say between the fourth and fifth takbir: "O Allah, disgrace Your servant among Your servants and in Your lands. O Allah, subject him to the severest of Your fires. O Allah, make him taste the heat of Your punishment, for he supported Your enemies, opposed Your friends, and hated the family of Your Prophet."

When he is lifted, say: "O Allah, do not elevate him and do not purify him." (1)

## Chapter 12: Visiting Graves

When you visit the grave of a believer, say: "O Allah, have mercy on his estrangement, soothe his loneliness, comfort his solitude, remove his fear, and bestow upon him from Your mercy such contentment that he needs no mercy from anyone else. Gather him with those he loved." (2)

13 [باب التعزية] وعز ولي الميت، فإنه روي عن أبي عبد الله - عليه السلام - أنه قال: من عزى حزينا (1) كسي في الموقف حلة (2) يحبر بها (3) (4).
وروي عن أمير المؤمنين - عليه السلام - أنه قال: ما من مؤمن ولا مؤمنة يضع يده على رأس يتيم ترحما له (5)، إلا كتب الله له بعدد كل شعرة مرت عليها يده حسنة (6).

translation:
**Chapter 13 [Consolation]**

Console the guardian of the deceased, for it is narrated from Abu Abdullah - peace be upon him - that he said: "Whoever consoles a grieving person shall be clothed with a garment (1) at the standing place (on the Day of Judgment) (2) with which they will be adorned joyfully (3) (4)."

It is also narrated from the Commander of the Faithful - peace be upon him - that he said: "No believing man or woman places their hand on the head of an orphan compassionately (5) without God recording for them, for every strand of hair their hand passes over, a good deed (6)."

1. "A believer" A, D.
2. A garment: A covering or dress, whether a cloak or other, and it is only considered a garment if it consists of two pieces, or a garment with a lining "Majma' al-Bahrain: 1/563 - Hall".
3. Adorned joyfully in the passive voice, either with an open 'b' for cheerful adornment, meaning they will be delighted by it, or with a doubled 'b' from decoration, meaning the garment becomes an adornment for them, making them beautified by it "Majma' al-Bahrain: 1/444 - Hibr -".
4. Reported in Al-Wasa'il: 3/214 - Chapters on Burial - Chapter 46, Hadith 7, and in Al-Bihar: 82/111, Hadith 55, cited from Al-Kafi: 3/205, Hadith 1, and Rewards of Deeds: 235, Hadith 2, and Al-Hidaya: 28, similarly, also in Al-Faqih: 1/110, Hadith 1.
5. Not in "A".
6. Reported in Al-Wasa'il: 21/374 - Chapters on Children's Rulings - Chapter 13, Hadith 2, and from Rewards of Deeds: 237, Hadith 1, similarly. And in Al-Faqih: 1/119, Hadith 12, similarly cited in Al-Wasa'il: 3/286 - Chapters on Burial - Chapter 91, Hadith 2. And in Al-Hidaya: 28, similarly.

text:
وقال أبو عبد الله - عليه السلام -: ما من عبد مؤمن مسح يده على رأس يتيم رحمة له، إلا أعطاه الله تبارك وتعالى بكل شعرة نورا يوم القيامة (1).
وروي أن اليتيم إذا بكى اهتز له العرش، فيقول الله جل جلاله: من هذا الذي أبكى عبدي الذي سلبته أبويه في صغره؟ فوعزتي وجلالي وارتفاعي في علو مكاني لا يسكته عبد مؤمن إلا أوجبت له الجنة (2).
footnote:
١ - عنه الوسائل: ٢١ / ٣٧٤ - أبواب أحكام الأولاد - ب ١٣ ح ١ وعن الفقيه: ١ / ١١٩ ح ١١ مثله، وكذا في ثواب الأعمال: ٢٣٧ ح ٢.
٢ - فقه الرضا: ١٧٢ مثله، وكذا في الفقيه: ١ / 119 ح 15، عنه الوسائل: 3 / 287 - أبواب الدفن - ب 91 ح 5.
translation:
Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, said: "There is no believing servant who compassionately places their hand on the head of an orphan, except that God, the Blessed and Exalted, will grant them a light for every strand of hair on the Day of Judgment."

It is narrated that when an orphan cries, the Throne of God shakes, and God, Glorified and Exalted be He, says: "Who is it that has made my servant, whom I deprived of their parents in childhood, cry? By My might, majesty, and exaltedness in My lofty place, no believing servant can calm him except that I make Paradise obligatory for them."

1 - From "Al-Wasa'il": 21/374, under chapters of the rights of children, section 13, hadith 1, and in "Al-Faqih": 1/119, hadith 11, with similar wording, and also in "Thawab al-A'mal": 237, hadith 2.

2 - In "Fiqh al-Rida": 172, with similar wording, and also in "Al-Faqih": 1/119, hadith 15, referenced in "Al-Wasa'il": 3/287, under chapters of burial, section 91, hadith 5.

وإياك أن تستخف بها (3)، أو تكسل عنها أو يشغلك عنها شيء من غرض (4) الدنيا (5)، (فقد قال) (6) رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -: ليس مني من استخف بصلاته، لا يرد علي الحوض لا والله، ليس مني من شرب مسكرا لا يرد علي الحوض لا والله (7).

translation:
Prayer Gates

Know that prayer is the pillar of religion. It is the first thing a servant will be judged on; if it is accepted, everything else will be accepted, and if it is rejected, everything else will be rejected. Beware of taking it lightly, neglecting it, or letting anything from worldly matters distract you from it. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his family, said: "He who takes his prayer lightly is not of me; he shall not come to my Pond on the Day of Judgment, no, by Allah! He who drinks intoxicants is not of me; he shall not come to my Pond on the Day of Judgment, no, by Allah!"

text:
فإذا قمت إلى الصلاة فاقبل عليها (١)، ولا تمتخط، ولا تبزق (٢)، ولا تتثأب ولا تمط (٣)، ولا تمس الحصى (٤)، ولا تلتفت (٥)، واخشع في صلاتك فإن الله يقول: ﴿الذين هم في صلاتهم خاشعون﴾ (٦) يعني غض الطرف (٧).
وقوله تعالى: ﴿والذين هم على صلواتهم يحافظون﴾ (8) يعني الفريضة (9)، من صلاها لوقتها، عارفا بحقها، لا يؤثر عليها غيرها، كتب الله له بها براءة لا يعذبه (10).

translation:
When you stand for prayer, focus entirely on it. Do not blow your nose, do not spit, do not yawn, and do not stretch. Do not touch the pebbles, and do not look around. Be humble in your prayer, as God says: "Those who are humble in their prayers" (Quran 23:2), which means to lower one's gaze.

And His saying: "And those who guard their prayers" (Quran 23:9), refers to the obligatory prayer. Whoever performs it on time, knowing its due right, and prefers it over other matters is granted by God a guarantee that He will not punish him.

References can be found in various respected texts, including but not limited to sources like Al-Mustadrak, Al-Kafi, Al-Faqih, and Al-Tahdhib with varying degrees and slight differences in wording across these texts.

text:
ولا تستند إلى حائط إلا أن تكون مريضا (1).
ولا تعجل في قراءتك، وإذا مررت بآية فيها رحمة أو عذاب فاسأل (2) الله الجنة، وتعوذ به من النار (3).
واخضع لله (4)، ولا تحدث نفسك إن قدرت على ذلك (5)، وتأن في دعائك (6).
ولا تعبث فيها بيديك ولا برأسك ولا بلحيتك، ولا تكفر (7) فإنما يصنع ذلك المجوس، ولا تلثم (8)، ولا تحتفز (9)، ولا تقع على قدميك، ولا تفرقع (10) أصابعك (11).

translation:
Do not lean against a wall unless you are ill. Do not rush through your reading, and when you come across a verse about mercy or punishment, ask Allah for Paradise and seek refuge in Him from the Fire. Submit to Allah, and refrain from internal dialogue if you are able to do so, and be deliberate in your supplications.

Do not fiddle with your hands, head, or beard, and do not perform excessive bowing like the Magi do. Do not cover your mouth, do not crouch, do not sit back on your feet, and do not crack your knuckles.

text:
ولا تقدم رجلا على رجل، واجعل بين قدميك (قدر شبر أو) (1) إلى أكثر من ذلك (2).
ولا تنفخ في موضع سجودك، فإذا أردت النفخ فليكن قبل دخولك في الصلاة (3).
وإياك والتورك (4) في الصلاة فإنه قد عذب قوم على ذلك (5).
والتأوه في الصلاة كلام (6).
والالتفات يقطع الصلاة إذا كان التفاتك (في الصلاة) (7) بكلية (8)، وهو من اختلاس الشيطان (9).

translation: Do not place one foot over the other, and keep a distance between your feet (about a span or) to more than that. Do not blow on your place of prostration; if you wish to blow, let it be before you enter the prayer. Beware of resting your hands on your hips during prayer, as a group was punished for doing so. Groaning in prayer is considered speech. Turning your head breaks the prayer if you do it entirely, and it is a form of distraction from Satan.

text:
وإياك وسدل (1) الثوب في الصلاة، فإن أمير المؤمنين - عليه السلام - خرج على قوم يصلون قد أسدلوا أرديتهم فقال: مالكم قد أسدلتم ثيابكم، كأنكم يهود قد خرجوا من فهرهم؟ - يعني من بيعهم - (2).
ولا بأس بالصلاة (3) في القميص الواحد إذا كان كثيفا (4).
ولا بأس برد «السلام عليكم» في صلاة مفروضة، تقول: «سلام عليكم» كما سلم عليك (5).
ولا بأس للمصلي أن يتقدم أمامه بعد أن يدخل في الصلاة إلى القبلة ما شاء، وليس له أن يتأخر (6).

هو أن يضع وسط الأزار على رأسه، ويرسل طرفيه على يمينه وشماله من غير أن يجعلهما على كتفيه «مجمع البحرين:

translation:
Beware of letting your garment hang down during prayer (1), as the Commander of the Faithful - peace be upon him - once exited and found people praying with their cloaks hanging down. He remarked: "Why have you let your garments hang down, as if you are Jews who have just exited their synagogues?" - meaning, their places of worship (2). 

It is permissible to pray (3) in a single shirt if it is thick (4). 

There is no harm in replying to the greeting "Peace be upon you" during an obligatory prayer by saying "Peace be upon you" just as it was greeted to you (5).

It is permissible for the one who prays to move forward towards the Qibla as much as they wish after commencing the prayer, but they are not allowed to step back (6).

1 - Sidl: This refers to wrapping oneself with a garment, inserting hands from inside to bow and prostrate while wearing it in this manner, which was practiced by the Jews and thus they were forbidden from it. It has also been said that it involves placing the middle of the shawl on the head, letting the ends fall on the right and left without placing them on the shoulders "Majma' al-Bahrain: 1/355 - Sidl -".

translation:
Chapter 1: Places Where Prayer is Disliked

It is disliked to pray in the following places: in water, bathhouses, graves, snow, the plain of Baidā', and on busy roads; in Magian temples, ant nests, camel resting places, watercourses, marshlands, resounding valleys, Wadi Shaqra, and Wadi Dajnan.

1 - Baidā': A specific land between Mecca and Medina, about a mile from Dhu al-Hulayfah towards Mecca, resembling desolation or destruction. (Majma’ al-Bahrain: 1/269 - Bayd)
2 - "Masaq" A. Busy roads refer to the frequently traveled paths. (Majma’ al-Bahrain: 1/437 - Masan)
3 - "Mawatn" A. Camel resting places refer to the spots where camels kneel near water sources. (Majma’ al-Bahrain: 2/203 - A’tn)
4 - Resounding valleys, Wadi Shaqra, and Dajnan: are places of geological subsidence and are amongst those frowned upon. (Majma’ al-Bahrain: 1/527 - Shaqra)
5 - Refer to various Islamic texts: al-Hidayah (32), al-Mahasn (13 H39, 365 H113, 366 H115 & H116), al-Kafi (3/389 H10, 390 H11 & H12), al-Faqih (1/156 H2 & H3, 4/265 H4), al-Khisaal (434 H21), al-Tahdhib (2/219 H71, 375 H92 & H93, 5/425 H121), al-Sara'ir (3/644), and al-Wasa'il (5/142 - Chapters on Prayer Locations - B 15 H 6, 155 B 23, 157 B 24 H 1 & H2).

2 باب ما يصلى فيه من الثياب، وما لا يصلى فيه، وغير ذلك إعلم أن كل ما أكلت لحمه فلا بأس بالصلاة في شعره ووبره (1).
ولا بأس بالصلاة في الفراء الخوارزمية، وما يدبغ بأرض الحجاز (2).
ولا بأس بالصلاة في السنجاب (3) والسمور (4)، والفنك (5) (6).

translation:
Chapter 2: On the Clothing Suitable for Prayer and What is Not Allowed

Be aware that prayer is permissible in garments made from the hair or fur of any animal whose meat is permissible to eat. There is no issue with praying in fur from Khwarazm, or that which is tanned in the land of Hijaz. Likewise, one may pray in garments made from the Siberian squirrel, sable, and fennec.

1 - Refer to "Fiqh al-Ridha" p. 157, and "Al-Hidaya" p. 33 for similar references, as well as in "Al-Faqih" 1/170 in the letter of his father. It can also be found in "Al-Kafi" 3/397 under Hadith 1, "Al-Tahdhib" 2/209 under Hadith 26, and "Al-Istibsar" 1/383 under Hadith 1. See also "Tuhaf al-Uqool" p. 252, referenced in "Al-Wasael" 4/345 - Chapters on the Clothing of the Prayer - Chapter 2 Hadith 1 and the addendum of Hadith 2 and Hadith 8.

2 - Similar mentions in "Al-Faqih" 1/172, the end of Hadith 61, are found in "Al-Kafi" 3/398 Hadith 4, and these are referenced in "Al-Wasael" 4/462 - Chapters on the Clothing of the Prayer - Chapter 61 Hadith 1. The beginning is supported by "Al-Tahdhib" 2/210 Hadith 31, and "Al-Istibsar" 1/384 Hadith 5.

3 - The Siberian squirrel is an animal resembling a jerboa, larger than a mouse, with extremely soft fur from which fur coats are made. See "Majma' al-Bahrain" 1/433 under 'Sanjob.'

4 - Sable is a well-known creature, from whose skin valuable fur coats are made. They are found in the land of the Turks and resemble a leopard. They can be shiny black or light brown. Refer to "Majma' al-Bahrain" 1/416 under 'Samur.'

5 - The fennec is a small, wild creature not eaten for its meat. Its fur is used and often imported from the lands of Sicily. It is cooler than sable, more moderate, and warmer than the Siberian squirrel. It is said to be from the offspring of the Roman fox, as stated in "Majma' al-Bahrain" 2/431 under 'Fannak.'

6 - Refer to "Al-Dhakira" p. 144, and in "Al-Tahdhib" 2/211 Hadith 34, "Al-Istibsar" 1/385 Hadith 7 with slight variations, and referenced in "Al-Wasael" 4/352 - Chapters on the Clothing of Prayer - Chapter 5 Hadith 1. Additionally, see "Al-Kafi" 3/400 Hadith 14, and "Al-Faqih" 1/171 Hadith 55.

text:
ولا تصل في ثعلب، ولا في الثوب الذي يليه (1) من تحته وفوقه (2)، إلا في حال التقية، فلا بأس بالصلاة فيه (3).
ولا بأس بالصلاة في الخز (4) إذا لم يكن مغشوشا بوبر الأرانب (5).
ولا تصل في جلد الميتة على كل حال (6)، ولا تصل في السواد (7). ولا تصل في حرير، ولا (8) وشي (9) ولا ديباج (10)، إذا كان إبريسما محضا (11) إلا أن (يكون الثوب) (12)

translation: You must not pray in a garment made of the hides of predatory animals, nor in the cloth directly touching the skin from beneath or above, except in situations of necessity; in such cases, it is permissible to pray in it. There is no objection to praying in 'khaz' if it is not adulterated with rabbit fur. You should not pray in the skin of a dead animal under any circumstances, nor should you pray in black attire. Additionally, you should not pray in silk, nor in brocade or dibaaj if the fabric is pure silk, unless the garment is altered as mentioned in religious texts.

text:
سداه (1) إبريسم ولحمته (2) قطن أو كتان (3).
ولا يجوز أن يصلى في بيت فيه خمر محصور في آنية (4).
وروي أنه يجوز (5).
وإياك أن تصلي في ثوب أصابه خمر. (6) ولا تصل في ثوب يكون في علمه (7) مثال طير أو غير ذلك (8).

translation:
The warp (1) is made of silk, and the weft (2) is made of cotton or linen (3). It is not permissible to pray in a house where there is enclosed wine in vessels (4). However, it has been narrated that it is permissible (5). Be careful not to pray in a garment that has been stained with wine (6). Do not pray in a garment that has an image of a bird or anything else woven into its design (7).

1 - Warp: The threads that run lengthwise in the fabric, "Al-Mu‘jam Al-Wasīṭ: 1/424."
2 - Weft: The crosswise yarns woven over and under the warp yarns "Al-Mu‘jam Al-Wasīṭ: 2/819."
3 - Fiqh Al-Ridha: 157 similarly mentions this, as does Al-Faqih: 1/171 at the end of narration 56 regarding his father's teachings. text:
ولا تصل وبين يديك امرأة تصلي، إلا أن يكون بينكما بعد (1) عشرة أذرع، ولا بأس بأن تصلي المرأة خلفك (2).
ولا تصل في خاتم عليه نقش مثال الطير، أو غير ذلك (3).
ولا تصل وفي يدك (4) خاتم حديد (5).
ولا بأس بالصلاة في القرمز (6) (7).
وإن جعلت في جبتك بدل القطن قزا (8) فلا بأس بالصلاة فيه (9).
ولا تصل وقدامك تماثيل (10)، ولا في بيت فيه تماثيل، ولا في بيت فيه بول

translation: Do not pray while a woman is praying in front of you unless there is a distance of ten cubits between you. It is permissible for a woman to pray behind you. Do not pray wearing a ring engraved with the likeness of a bird or anything else. Do not pray with an iron ring on your hand. There is no harm in praying in garments dyed with crimson. If, instead of cotton, you use silk in your cloak, there is no harm in praying in it. Do not pray in front of statues, in a house with statues, or in a house containing urine.

Certainly! Here is the translation of the provided Arabic text into English:

---

It is disliked to pray in a house that contains a dog.  
It is also disliked to pray in a garment dyed intensely with safflower or stained with saffron.  
Prayers in anything made of iron are not permitted, except if it is a weapon.  
There is no harm in performing prayers while wearing sandals.  
It is disliked to pray in a garment that is transparent or revealing, referred to as polished or shiny.

1. Referenced from "Al-Mustadrak" 3/348, Hadith 1. Also see "Al-Faqih" 1/159, Hadith 21 and from it in "Al-Wasa'il" 5/175 - The Sections of the Place of the Worshipper - Section 33, Hadith 4.
2. "Asfar": a known plant used for dyeing, "Majma' al-Bahrain" 2/193 - 'Asaf'.
3. Referenced from "Al-Mustadrak" 3/230, Hadith 1, and similarly in "Al-Tahdhib" 2/373, Hadith 82, and from it in "Al-Wasa'il" 4/461 - The Sections of the Garments of the Worshipper - Section 59, Hadith 3.
4. Referenced from "Al-Mustadrak" 3/220, beginning of Hadith 3, and in "Al-Kafi" 3/400, end of Hadith 13, and "Al-Tahdhib" 2/227 end of Hadith 102, similar, and from them in "Al-Wasa'il" 4/419 - The Sections of the Garments of the Worshipper - Section 32, end of Hadith 6.
5. Referenced from "Al-Mustadrak" 3/222, Hadith 3, and see "Al-Kafi" 1/493 within Hadith 2, and Volume 3/489, Hadith 13, "Al-Faqih" 1/358, Hadith 9, "Uyoun Akhbar Al-Ridha - Peace be upon him" 2/16, Hadith 40, and "Al-Tahdhib" 2/233, Hadith 124, and from it in "Al-Wasa'il" 4/424 - The Sections of the Garments of the Worshipper - within Section 37.
6. "Shaf" refers to the garment becoming thin enough to show the skin of the wearer, "Lisan al-Arab: 179". It was noted "Awṣaf" might be a transcription error for "Aw waṣaf" as in "Al-Dhikrā", where Al-Shaheed said: "Shaf" means the skin is visible, and "Waṣaf" means it describes the body shape. In the manuscript of Al-Sheikh, it is written as "Awṣaf" with one "wa", while commonly known with two "wa"s. Alternatively, "ṣaff" could mean "shaf" as Ibn Manzur mentioned: "Tashreeḥ," which is when the flesh is exposed till it becomes thin and transparent, "Lisan al-Arab: 9/159".
7. "Ṣaql" translates to "polishing", "Lisan al-Arab: 11/380".
8. Referenced from "Al-Mustadrak" 3/211, Hadith 1, and in "Al-Kafi" 3/402, Hadith 24, "Al-Tahdhib" 2/214, Hadith 45 and Hadith 46, and "Al-Dhikrā", with slight variation in wording, and from it in "Al-Wasa'il" 4/388 - The Sections of the Garments of the Worshipper - Section 21, Hadith 3 and 4.

رمى المصنف في الفقيه رواة الحديث بالجهالة ثم قال: ولكنها رخصة اقترنت بها علة صدرت عن ثقات، ثم اتصلت بالمجهولين والانقطاع، فمن أخذ بها لم يكن مخطئا، بعد أن يعلم أن الأصل هو النهي، وإن الاطلاق هو رخصة، والرخصة رحمة.

translation:
(Do not perform prayers on the mats of the Jews and Christians.) 

(It is narrated that) there is no harm if a man prays with fire, a lamp, or an image before him, because what he prays to is closer to him than what is in front of him.

The author of "Al-Fiqih" labeled the narrators of this hadith as unknown and then said: "However, it is a concession accompanied by a reason issued by trustworthy individuals and connected to the unknown and broken chains. Therefore, whoever applies it is not in error, once it is understood that the original rule is prohibition, and the allowance is a concession, and a concession is a mercy."

The Sheikh stated: "This is an odd narration, and even so, it is not a musnad (connected) narration, and what falls into this category should not be preferred over numerous musnad narrations."

translation:
Chapter 3: On What is Permissible to Prostrate Upon and What is Not

Prostrate on the earth or on what the earth produces, except for what is consumed as food or worn. Do not prostrate on hair, wool, leather, silk, glass, iron, lead, brass, copper, ashes, or feathers.

translation:
Do not prostrate on the mats of Medina because their borders are made of leather. 

There is no harm in prostrating on Tabari. If it is a dark night and you fear harm from a scorpion or thorn, it is permissible to prostrate on your sleeve if it is made of cotton or linen. If there is an ailment such as a boil on your forehead, excavate a small pit so that when you prostrate, the boil rests in it. If there is an ailment on your forehead that prevents you from prostrating on it, then prostrate on the right side of your forehead. If you cannot do that, then prostrate on the left side of your forehead.

translation:
If you are able, prostrate on the back of your hand, but if you are unable, prostrate on your chin. There is no harm in standing while placing your palms, knees, and thumbs on surfaces other than the ground. It is commendable to touch the ground with your nose. It is sufficient for the placement of the forehead, from the hairline to the eyebrows, to cover the area of a dirham. Your prostration should resemble how an emaciated camel descends, remaining almost suspended, ensuring that no part of your body rests on another.

Chapter 4: The Great Limbs Used in Prostration

Know that prostration is performed on seven parts: the forehead, the palms, the knees, and the big toes.

وافتح لنا باب رحمتك واجعلنا من عمار مساجدك جل (ثناء وجهك) (1). فإذا أردت أن تخرج، فأخرج رجلك اليسرى قبل اليمنى، وقل: اللهم صل على محمد وآل محمد، وافتح لنا باب فضلك (2).
وعليك بالسكينة والوقار (3) والتخشع (4) إذا دخلت المسجد (5)، فإنه روي: أن في التوراة مكتوبا: إن بيوتي في الأرض المساجد، فطوبى لمن تطهر في بيته ثم زارني في بيتي، وحق للمزور أن يكرم الزائر (6).
وقال النبي - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -: من أسرج في مسجد من مساجد الله سراجا، لم تزل الملائكة وحملة العرش يستغفرون له ما دام في ذلك المسجد ضوء من السراج (7).
ولا تأت المسجد وأنت جنب، ولا المرأة الحائض حتى تغتسل (8).

translation:
Open for us the gate of Your mercy and make us among those who inhabit Your mosques. (Your praise is exalted.) When you wish to leave, take out your left foot before your right, and say: O Allah, bless Muhammad and the family of Muhammad, and open for us the gate of Your grace.

The virtues of tranquility, dignity, and humility should be observed when entering a mosque, as it is narrated that it is written in the Torah: "My houses on earth are the mosques, and blessed is the one who purifies themselves in their house and then visits Me in My house. It is fitting for the one visited to honor the visitor."

The Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) said: "Whoever lights a lamp in one of Allah's mosques, the angels and the bearers of the Throne will continue to seek forgiveness for them as long as there is light from that lamp in the mosque."

Do not enter the mosque if you are in a state of major ritual impurity (junub) or if a woman is menstruating until she performs a ritual bath.

translation:
Chapter 6: The Call to Prayer (Adhan) and Iqama

When you wish to recite the Adhan, raise your voice with it, for God Almighty has assigned a breeze to carry the Adhan up to the heavens. Know that for the caller between the Adhan and the Iqama is a reward like that of a martyr dripped in his own blood for the sake of God. Whoever calls the Adhan for ten years seeking the pleasure of God, God will forgive his sins as far as his sight and voice reach into the sky. Every damp and dry entity that hears it will bear witness to him. He will receive a share from everyone who prays with him, and he will earn a good deed from everyone who prays by his call.

translation:
Sure! Here is the translation:

---

There is no harm in giving the call to prayer (Adhan) while not in a state of ablution, whether you are facing the Qibla (the direction of Mecca) or turned away from it, whether you are going, coming, standing, or sitting. You may speak during your Adhan if you wish. However, when you perform the Iqama (the final call to prayer), you should be in a state of ablution and facing the Qibla. If you are the Imam (the leader of the prayer), you should perform the Adhan only while standing.

When the sun passes the zenith, the time for the two prayers (Dhuhr and Asr) has begun, although Dhuhr (noon prayer) precedes Asr (afternoon prayer). Perform six units of prayer, focusing in the first unit, and recite in it "Say: He is Allah, the One" (Surah Al-Ikhlas).

This guidance is supported by references from various authoritative Islamic texts, indicating the importance of adhering to these practices during prayer.

---

ثم تؤذن بعد ست ركعات، وتصلي بعد الأذان ركعتين، ثم تقوم (2) وتصلي الفريضة (3).

ثم أقم، وعليك بالتخشع والإقبال على صلاتك (7)، وكبر ثلاث تكبيرات وقل: اللهم أنت الملك (الحق المبين) (8) لا إله إلا أنت، سبحانك وبحمدك، إني (9) ظلمت نفسي فاغفر لي، إنه (10) لا يغفر الذنوب إلا أنت.

translation:
The second surah to be recited is (Say, O disbelievers), and in all other supererogatory prayers, you may recite whatever you wish, with the best being (Say, He is Allah, the One) (1). Then, after six units of prayer, the call to prayer (adhan) is made, followed by two units of prayer after the adhan. Then, you stand (2) and perform the obligatory prayer (3).

Let the adhan and iqama (the call to commence prayer) be recited standing still (4) (5), and there should be a sitting between them except for Maghrib prayer, where a single breath suffices between the adhan and iqama (6).

After that, commence the prayer, focusing on humility and full attention to your prayer (7). Begin with three takbirs (saying "Allahu Akbar") and say: O Allah, You are the King, the True Manifest (8); there is no deity but You. Glory be to You, and all praise to You. Indeed, I (9) have wronged myself, so forgive me, for (10) none forgives sins except You.

Then, say two more takbirs and declare: Here I am, ready and eager to serve You. All good is in Your hands, and evil is not attributed to You. The rightly guided is the one You guide, Your servant and the son of Your servant (11), from You, with You, for You, and to You, not...

ثم كبر تكبيرتين وقل: وجهت وجهي للذي فطر السماوات والأرض، عالم الغيب والشهادة، الرحمن الرحيم على ملة إبراهيم، ودين محمد - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -، وولاية أمير المؤمنين علي بن أبي طالب - عليه السلام - حنيفا مسلما، وما أنا من المشركين، إن صلاتي ونسكي ومحياي ومماتي لله رب العالمين، لا شريك له، وبذلك أمرت، وأنا من المسلمين، أعوذ بالله السميع العليم من الشيطان الرجيم، بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم، ثم اقرأ فاتحة الكتاب (2)، واقرأ أي سورة (3) القرآن شئت (4).
فإذا ختمت السورة فكبر واحدة، تجهر بها إن أحببت (5)، ثم اركع، فإذا ركعت فقل: اللهم لك ركعت، وبك آمنت، ولك خشعت، ولك أسلمت، وبك اعتصمت، وعليك توكلت، وأنت ربي، خشع لك سمعي وبصري وشعري وبشري ولحمي ودمي وعظامي ومخي وعصبي، تبارك الله رب العالمين.
ثم قل: سبحان ربي العظيم وبحمده، ثلاث مرات، فإن قلت خمسا فهو حسن، وإن قلت سبعا فهو أفضل (6)، ويجزيك أن (7) تقول: (سبحان الله سبحان الله

translation:
There is no refuge or safety from You except to You. Glory and mercy be to You, blessed and exalted. Glory be to You, Lord of the Sacred House. 

Then, say two Takbirs (Allahu Akbar – God is the Greatest) and say: "I have directed my face towards the One who created the heavens and the earth, the Knower of the unseen and the seen, the Most Merciful, the Most Compassionate, upon the creed of Abraham and the religion of Muhammad - may peace and blessings be upon him and his family - and the guardianship of the Commander of the Faithful, Ali ibn Abi Talib - peace be upon him - as a monotheistic Muslim, and I am not among the polytheists. Indeed, my prayer, my sacrifices, my life, and my death are for Allah, the Lord of all worlds, without any partner. This is what I have been commanded, and I am among the Muslims. I seek refuge with Allah, the All-Hearing, the All-Knowing, from the accursed Satan. In the name of Allah, the Most Merciful, the Most Compassionate."

Then, recite the opening chapter of the Quran (Al-Fatiha) and any other chapter of the Quran that you wish. 

When you conclude the chapter, say one Takbir aloud if you wish, and then bow (Ruku). When you bow, say: "O Allah, to You I have bowed, in You I believe, to You I submit, in You I place my trust, You are my Lord. To You is humbled my hearing, my sight, my hair, my skin, my flesh, my blood, my bones, my brain, and my nerves. Blessed be Allah, the Lord of all worlds."

Then say: "Glory be to my Lord, the Almighty, and by His praise," three times. If you say it five times, it is good, and if seven times, it is even better. It suffices to say: "Glory be to Allah, Glory be to Allah."

واعف عني، إني لما أنزلت إلي من خير فقير (1).
ثم تشهد وقل: بسم الله، والحمد لله، والأسماء الحسنى كلها لله، أشهد أن لا إله إلا الله وحده لا شريك له، وأشهد أن محمدا عبده ورسوله، أرسله بالحق بشيرا ونذيرا بين يدي الساعة (2)، ثم صل الركعتين الأخيرتين، واقرأ في كل ركعة منهما بالحمد وحدها، وإن شئت سبحت فقل (3): سبحان الله، والحمد لله، ولا إله إلا الله، والله أكبر، ثلاث مرات (4).
فإذا صليت الركعة الرابعة فتشهد وقل: بسم الله وبالله، والأسماء الحسنى كلها لله، أشهد أن لا إله إلا الله، وحده لا شريك له، وأشهد أن محمدا عبده ورسوله، أرسله بالحق بشيرا ونذيرا بين يدي الساعة.
التحيات لله (5)، الصلوات الطيبات (6) الطاهرات (7) الزاكيات الغاديات الرائحات الناعمات السابغات (8) لله ما طاب وطهر وزكا وخلص، وأشهد أن لا إله إلا الله وحده لا شريك له، وأن محمدا عبده ورسوله، وأشهد أن الله نعم الرب وأن (9) محمدا - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - نعم الرسول.
ثم اثن على ربك بما قدرت عليه من الثناء الحسن (10).

translation:
Pardon me, for I am in need of whatever good You may bestow upon me (1). Then testify and say: In the name of Allah, all praise is due to Allah, and all the beautiful names belong to Allah. I bear witness that there is no deity but Allah, alone, without partner. And I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger, sent with the truth as a bearer of glad tidings and a warner before the Hour (2).

Then perform the last two units of prayer, and recite Al-Fatiha alone in each unit. If you wish, you can glorify Allah by saying (3): "Glory be to Allah, praise be to Allah, there is no deity but Allah, and Allah is the Greatest" three times (4).

When you have completed the fourth unit, testify and say: In the name of Allah, and with Allah, and all the beautiful names belong to Allah. I bear witness that there is no deity but Allah, alone, without partner. And I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger, sent with the truth as a bearer of glad tidings and a warner before the Hour.

Greetings belong to Allah (5), all the pure (6), good, abundant, and blissful prayers belong to Allah, whatever is pure, good, abundant, and flawless is for Allah. I bear witness that there is no deity but Allah, alone, without partner, and that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger. I also testify that Allah is the best Lord and that Muhammad – peace and blessings be upon him and his family – is the best Messenger.

Then praise your Lord with as much praise as you can (10).

text:
ثم سلم وقل: اللهم أنت السلام، ومنك السلام، ولك السلام، وإليك يعود السلام.
السلام عليك أيها النبي ورحمة الله وبركاته، السلام على الأئمة الراشدين المهديين (1)، السلام على جميع أنبياء الله، ورسله، وملائكته، السلام علينا وعلى عباد الله الصالحين (2).
[وأدنى ما يجوز في التشهد أن يقول الشهادتين ويقول: بسم الله وبالله ثم يسلم] (3).
فإذا كنت إماما فسلم وقل: السلام عليكم مرة واحدة وأنت مستقبل القبلة، وتميل بعينيك (4) إلى يمينك، وإن لم تكن إماما (فقل: السلام عليكم و) (5) تميل بأنفك إلى يمينك (6)، وإن كنت خلف إمام تأتم به، فتسلم تجاه القبلة واحدة ردا على الإمام، وتسلم على يمينك واحدة، وعلى يسارك واحدة، إلا أن لا يكون على يسارك أحد فلا تسلم (على يسارك) (7)، إلا أن تكون بجنب الحائط فتسلم على يسارك (8).
ولا تدع التسليم على يمينك، كان على يمينك أحد، أو لم يكن (9).

translation:
Then, conclude the prayer and say: "O Allah, You are peace, and from You comes peace, and to You returns peace. Peace be upon you, O Prophet, and the mercy of Allah and His blessings. Peace be upon the rightly guided and enlightened leaders, peace upon all the prophets of Allah, His messengers, and His angels. Peace be upon us and upon the righteous servants of Allah."

[At the very least in the Tashahhud, one should say the two testimonies of faith, and say: 'In the name of Allah and with Allah,' then conclude with peace.]

If you are leading the prayer, finish by facing the Qibla, saying "Peace be upon you" once, and incline your gaze to your right. If you are not the imam, say "Peace be upon you" and turn your nose to your right. If you are praying behind an imam, respond by facing the Qibla with one "Peace be upon you" directed toward the imam, and say it once to your right and once to your left, unless there is no one on your left, in which case do not say it on your left unless you are by a wall, in which case you do say it to your left.

Do not omit the conclusion of peace to your right, whether or not there is anyone on your right.

text: 7 باب (1) تسبيح فاطمة الزهراء - عليها السلام - وتسبح تسبيح فاطمة الزهراء - عليها السلام - وهو أربع وثلاثون تكبيرة، وثلاث وثلاثون تسبيحة، وثلاث وثلاثون تحميدة (2)، فإن في ذلك ثوابا عظيما (3). ثم قل: لا إله إلا الله، إلها واحدا ونحن له مسلمون (4)، لا إله إلا الله، لا نعبد إلا إياه، مخلصين له الدين ولو كره المشركون، لا إله إلا الله، ربنا ورب آبائنا الأولين، لا إله إلا الله وحده وحده، أنجز وعده، ونصر عبده، وأعز جنده، وغلب (5) الأحزاب وحده، فله الملك وله الحمد، يحيي ويميت، ويميت ويحيي، (وهو حي لا يموت) (6)، بيده الخير، وهو على كل شيء قدير (7).

translation:
Chapter 7 (1) The Tasbih of Fatimah al-Zahra, peace be upon her. The Tasbih of Fatimah al-Zahra, peace be upon her, consists of thirty-four takbirs (saying "Allahu Akbar"), thirty-three tasbihs (saying "Subhan Allah"), and thirty-three tahmids (saying "Alhamdulillah") (2). This practice carries great reward (3). Then say: "There is no god but Allah, the One; we are content to belong to Him (4). There is no god but Allah; we worship none but Him, sincere in our faith to Him, even if the polytheists dislike it. There is no god but Allah, our Lord and the Lord of our forefathers. There is no god but Allah alone. He fulfilled His promise, granted victory to His servant, and glorified His army, defeating (5) the confederates alone. To Him belongs the kingdom and all praise. He gives life and causes death, and causes death and gives life, (and He is the Ever-Living who never dies) (6). In His hand is all good, and He is capable of all things (7)."

8 باب أدنى (1) ما يجزي من الدعاء بعد (2) المكتوبة إعلم أن أدنى ما يجزي من الدعاء بعد المكتوبة، أن تقول: اللهم صل على محمد وآل محمد، اللهم إنا نسألك من كل خير أحاط به علمك، ونعوذ بك من كل شر أحاط به علمك.

translation:
## Chapter 8: The Minimum Required Supplication After Obligatory Prayers

Know that the minimum supplication required after the obligatory prayers is to say: "O Allah, bless Muhammad and the family of Muhammad. O Allah, we ask You for all the goodness that Your knowledge encompasses, and we seek refuge with You from all evil that Your knowledge encompasses. O Allah, we ask for Your grace in all our affairs, and we seek refuge with You from the disgrace of this world and the punishment of the Hereafter."

If you are leading the prayer, you should not extend it, as Imam Abu Abdullah – peace be upon him – said: "When you lead a group in prayer, keep it light, but when you pray alone, you can take your time, for it is an act of devotion."

translation:
Chapter 9: A Woman's Prayer

When a woman stands in her prayer, she should keep her feet together and place her hands on her thighs. She should not bow too low, to avoid raising her backside. When she intends to prostrate, she should first sit, then prostrate so that her body is close to the ground. 

When she wants to stand up from prostration, she should lift her head and sit on her buttocks, unlike the manner in which a man squats, and then rise to a standing position without raising her backside, moving smoothly. When she sits for the tashahhud, she should raise her legs and bring her thighs together.

1 - "Close to the ground" refers to being in close contact. Reference: Majma' al-Bahrayn, 2/120. 
2 - "Squat" in this context refers to sitting on one’s calves between the two prostrations. Reference: Majma' al-Bahrayn, 2/533.

translation:
If you are uncertain in the Maghrib prayer and do not know whether you have prayed one or two units, then perform the Salaam (conclusion of prayer), then stand up and pray one more unit. If you are uncertain whether you are in the third or fourth unit, and you are sure of having completed two units, with doubt lingering between the third and fourth, then add one more unit and disregard the doubt. If your thought leans towards the third, perform the Salaam and then pray two additional units (four prostrations).

Al-Sadiq, peace be upon him, was asked about someone who does not know if they prayed two or three units. He said: They should repeat the prayer. It was asked: And where is what is narrated from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him and his family, that a competent jurist does not repeat the prayer? He said: 

The author of Al-Bihar, referencing sources such as "Al-Mustadrak" and "Tahdhib", mentions a possibility for interpreting such doubts. It could mean completing the third unit if the doubt arises while standing, based on having ensured the two units. Alternatively, if doubts occur after completing a unit, it might refer to performing a precautionary prayer after the Salaam, possibly considering the extra as an additional unit, rendering the prayer and the additional two units as supererogatory. However, this interpretation contrasts with more widely accepted views, which generally adhere to continuing based on predominant certainty without additional precaution.

Furthermore, Al-Majlisi in "Al-Bihar" reports the opinion of Shahid in "Al-Lum'a", stating that a precautionary measure involves performing two units sitting if doubting between two and leaning towards the third, as reported by Ammar Al-Sabati, according to Al-Sadiq, peace be upon him, a narrative from the Fatimid school.

The correct stance, as affirmed by the prominent jurists, is that any error regarding additional or missing units in Maghrib necessitates the repetition of the prayer.

translation:
The subject matter discusses cases of doubt in prayer, specifically regarding whether three or four units (Rak'ahs) have been performed:

Indeed, this is applicable to three and four Rak'ahs. It is narrated from some of them, peace be upon them, that one should base their actions on what their mind has inclined towards and perform two prostrations of forgetfulness (Sujood al-Sahw) and recite a brief testimony (Tashahhud) for them.

If you do not know whether you have prayed two or four Rak'ahs, then you should repeat the prayer. It is narrated to end with the salutations, then stand up and pray two additional Rak'ahs without speaking, reciting "Al-Fatiha" in them.

If you have prayed four Rak'ahs, these two will be considered a supererogatory prayer (Nafila), but if you have prayed two, these will complete the four Rak'ahs. However, if you speak, you must perform the two prostrations of forgetfulness.

1. This view is mentioned in various sources, including "al-Dhikrā," "al-Bihar," "al-Wasā'il," "Tahdheeb," "al-Istibsār," "al-Kāfi," and "Ma'ani al-Akhbar," with slight variations in wording.
2. Allāmah al-Majlisi, in "al-Bihar," states that performing Sujood al-Sahw with reliance on personal assumption is generally against common opinion. He only attributes the sujood necessitated by relying on the majority to al-Ṣadūq, referencing Shahīd's opinion in "al-Dhikrā" on the requirement of the two prostrations in relation to the narration of Ishaq ibn Ammar, found in "Tahdheeb." Look into "Sharh al-Lum'a."
3. Referenced in "al-Bihar," "al-Mustadrak," "Tahdheeb," and "al-Istibsār," among others, for a similar view.
4. Sheikh attributed this to the Maghrib or Fajr prayer, which do not permit doubt.
5. Sources for this include "al-Mukhtalif," "al-Bihar," and "al-Mustadrak," along with "Tahdheeb" and "al-Istibsār."
6. The phrase "without speaking" is noted in the "Mustadrak."
7. Not included in one of the sources referenced.
8. Referenced in "al-Mukhtalif," "al-Bihar," "al-Mustadrak," "al-Kāfi," "al-Faqih," "Tahdheeb," and "al-Istibsār," with minor differences, as noted in "al-Wasā'il."

وإن لم تدر أربعا (1) صليت أم خمسا، أو زدت أو نقصت، فتشهد وسلم وصل ركعتين وأربع سجدات وأنت جالس بعد تسليمك (2).
وفي حديث آخر تسجد سجدتين بغير ركوع ولا قراءة، فتشهد فيهما تشهدا (3) خفيفا (4).
فإن استيقنت أنك صليت خمسا فأعد الصلاة (5).
وروي فيمن استيقن أنه صلى خمسا، إن كان (6) جلس في الرابعة فصلاة الظهر له تامة فليقم فليضف إلى الركعة الخامسة ركعة، فتكون الركعتان نافلة، ولا شيء عليه (7).
وروي أنه من استيقن أنه صلى ستا فليعد الصلاة (8).

translation:
If you are uncertain whether you have prayed four or five units, or if you have added or omitted something, then perform the Tashahhud, salute, and pray two more units and four prostrations while seated after your Salam.

In another narration, you should perform two prostrations without bowing or recitation, and perform a brief Tashahhud during them.

If you are certain that you have prayed five units, then you must repeat the prayer.

It has been narrated regarding one who is certain that they have prayed five units, if they have sat during the fourth unit, then the Dhuhr prayer is complete. One should then stand and add an additional unit, making these two units supererogatory, and there is no blame upon them.

It has also been narrated that if one is certain they have prayed six units, they should repeat the prayer.

text:
وإن لم تدر ثلاثا صليت أم أربعا، وذهب وهمك إلى الثالثة، فأضف إليهما الرابعة، وإن ذهب وهمك إلى الرابعة فتشهد، وسلم، واسجد سجدتي السهو (1).
وروى أبو بصير (2): إن كان ذهب وهمك إلى الرابعة فصل ركعتين، وأربع سجدات جالسا، فإن كنت صليت (ثلاثا، كانتا هاتان تمام الأربع، وإن كنت صليت أربعا) (3)، كانتا هاتان نافلة، كذلك إن لم تدر زدت أم نقصت (4).
وفي رواية محمد بن مسلم، إن ذهب وهمك إلى الثالثة فصل ركعة واسجد سجدتي السهو بغير قراءة، وإن اعتدل وهمك فأنت بالخيار، إن شئت صليت ركعة من قيام، وإلا (5) ركعتين من جلوس، فان ذهب وهمك مرة إلى ثلاث ومرة إلى أربع، فتشهد وسلم وصل ركعتين وأربع سجدات وأنت قاعد، تقرأ فيهما بأم القرآن (6).
