translation:
Chapter 1: The Khums

Muhammad ibn Abi Umayr narrated: The khums (a religious tax) is due on five things: treasures, minerals, diving proceeds, spoils of war, and Ibn Abi Umayr forgot the fifth one.

Zakariya ibn Malik al-Ju'fi asked Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) about the statement of Allah Almighty: "And know that whatever you gain of war booty, indeed a fifth of it is for Allah and for the Messenger and for the near relatives, the orphans, the needy, and the traveler" (Quran 8:41). He replied: "The share for Allah is for the Messenger (peace be upon him and his family) to spend in the cause of Allah. As for the share of the Messenger, it is for his relatives. And the share for those near of kin is for his relatives."

1. In some sources, it's referred to as "Chapter on Khums."
2. Muhammad ibn Ziyad ibn Isa, Abu Ahmad al-Azdi, narrated from al-Ridha (peace be upon him); he died in 217 AH. Al-Najashi mentioned him in his book of Rijal as being of great stature and highly esteemed among both supporters and opponents. Al-Tusi also mentioned him in his Rijal among the companions of Imam al-Ridha (peace be upon him), describing him as trustworthy. Al-Allameh al-Hilli also mentioned him in his Rijal.
3. This hadith is found in the sources such as Al-Wasa'il, Volume 9, Page 486, under the chapters about the obligations of khums, and Al-Mustadrak, Volume 7, Page 282. In Al-Khisal, similar narration can be found on Page 291, Hadith 53, and with slight differences on Page 290, Hadith 51. Also referenced in Al-Bihar, Volume 96, Page 189, Hadiths 1 and 2, and Al-Wasa'il, Volume 9, Page 494, Chapters on Khums, Hadiths 6 and 7.
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, in Al-Khisal suggested that the fifth thing forgotten by Ibn Abi Umayr is the wealth inherited by someone who knows it contains both lawful and unlawful elements but cannot identify the owners of the unlawful portion, nor can he identify the unlawful part to avoid it, thus requiring him to pay khums from it.
4. In some sources, noted as "al-Ja'fari," which is a transcription error as referenced in Al-Tusi's Rijal, Page 200.
5. Quran 8:41.
6. In some texts, it's referred to as "And the right of those near of kin" instead.
7. Sometimes listed as "his relatives."

translation:
The orphans referred to are the orphans of his household, so he made these four shares for them. As for the poor and wayfarers, you know that we do not consume charity nor is it permissible for us; it is intended for the poor and wayfarers.

And any non-Muslim who purchases land from a Muslim must pay a fifth.

Imam Al-Ridha (peace be upon him) was asked about what is extracted from the sea, such as pearls, rubies, and peridots. He said: if its value reaches a dinar, a fifth must be paid.

Abu Basir asked Imam Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) about the zakat obligation on the Imam. He replied: "O Abu Muhammad, do you not know that the world belongs to the Imam? He may distribute it as he wishes and give it to whom he desires. This is permissible for him by God's will. Indeed, the Imam never spends a night without bearing a right owed to God that he is questioned about."

Sources and references for this text come from several Islamic texts like "Al-Wasa’il" and "Al-Tahdhib," among others, which provide various narrations and teachings related to the share of orphans, rules for non-Muslims owning land, obligations on treasures from the sea, and duties of the Imam regarding zakat.

Muhammad bin Muslim asked Abu Ja'far - peace be upon him - about the salt flats, (and he - peace be upon him - said: And what are the salt flats?) He replied: A salty, barren land where water gathers and becomes salty. He - peace be upon him - said: It is like a mine, on which there is a fifth (to be paid). He asked: And what about sulfur and petroleum that come from the earth? He replied: These and similar things also require a fifth to be paid.

translation:
Repentance from His servants and He accepts charities, and indeed, Allah is the Most Forgiving, Most Merciful. Halabi asked about the charity of a boy who has not yet reached puberty, and he said: Yes, there is no harm in it as long as it is placed in the appropriate category for charity.

He was asked about the words of Allah the Almighty: "And do not aim at the bad of it, you spend [from]" (Surah Al-Baqarah 2:267), and he said: When people embraced Islam, they possessed earnings from usury and illicit wealth. A person would deliberately choose from his wealth and give it as charity. Allah forbade them from this, as charity is only suitable when it comes from good, lawful earnings.

Sufyan bin 'Uyaynah said: I asked Abu Abdullah - peace be upon him - about whether charity is forbidden for all prophets and their offspring. He replied: No, haven't you heard the words of Joseph’s brothers - peace be upon him -: "Confer favor upon us, indeed, Allah rewards the charitable." (Surah Yusuf 12:88). Charity was permissible for them, while war gains were forbidden. For us, charity is forbidden because it is the impurities of people's hands and a purification.

Certainly, here's the translation:

---

Have you not heard the words of Almighty God: "Take from their wealth a charity by which you purify them and cause them increase, and invoke [Allah's blessings] upon them. Indeed, your invocations are reassurance for them" (Quran, 9:103).

And know that the charities of the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him and his family, are permissible for the descendants of Hashim and their allies.

It is narrated that Fatimah, peace be upon her, allocated her charities to the descendants of Abdul-Muttalib and the descendants of Hashim.

Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, was asked about the charity that is prohibited for the descendants of Hashim, and he said: "It is the zakat." It was asked: "Is the charity of some permissible for others among them?" He replied: "Yes."

It has been narrated: "Give zakat to those among the descendants of Hashim who seek it, for it is permissible for them, and it is only forbidden for the Prophet and the Imam who comes after him, and for the Imams," peace be upon them.

أما الواجب: فصيام شهر رمضان، وصيام شهرين متتابعين لمن أفطر يوما من شهر رمضان عمدا متعمدا، وصيام شهرين متتابعين في قتل الخطأ لمن لم يجد العتق واجب، قال الله عز وجل: ﴿ومن قتل مؤمنا خطأ فتحرير رقبة مؤمنة ودية مسلمة إلى أهله إلا أن يصدقوا﴾ (1) إلى قوله: (فمن لم يجد فصيام شهرين
footnote: ١ - النساء: ٩٢.
translation:
The Chapters on Fasting

1. The Chapter on the Forty Types of Fasting

Know that fasting falls into forty categories. Ten of these are obligatory, akin to the obligation of fasting the month of Ramadan. Ten types of fasting are forbidden. In fourteen types, the individual has the choice to fast or break the fast, as he wishes. There are three categories associated with fasting by permission, fasting as a form of discipline, permissible fasting, and fasting due to travel and illness.

As for the obligatory: it includes fasting during the month of Ramadan, fasting for two consecutive months for anyone who deliberately breaks a fast during Ramadan, and fasting for two consecutive months as expiation for accidental killing if one does not have the means to free a believing slave. As Allah, the Exalted, said: "And whoever kills a believer by mistake, then [the freeing of] a believing slave and a compensation payment presented to the deceased's family, unless they remit it as charity" (Quran, An-Nisa 4:92). "But whoever does not find [one or cannot afford to], then a fast for two months consecutively."

وصيام شهرين متتابعين في كفارة الظهار واجب لمن لم يجد العتق، قال الله تعالى: (والذين يظاهرون من نسائهم ثم يعودون لما قالوا فتحرير رقبة من قبل أن يتماسا ذلكم توعظون به والله بما تعملون خبير فمن لم يجد فصيام شهرين متتابعين (٢)).
وصيام ثلاثة أيام في كفارة اليمين لمن لم يجد الإطعام واجب، قال الله عز وجل: ﴿فمن لم يجد فصيام ثلاثة أيام ذلك كفارة أيمانكم إذا حلفتم﴾ (٣).
وصوم دم المتعة واجب، قال الله عز وجل: ﴿فمن لم يجد فصيام ثلاثة أيام في الحج وسبعة إذا رجعتم تلك عشرة كاملة﴾ (٤).
(وصيام أذى) (٥) حلق الرأس واجب، قال الله عز وجل: ﴿فمن كان منكم مريضا أو به أذى من رأسه ففدية من صيام أو صدقة أو نسك﴾ (٦) فصاحبها فيها بالخيار، فان صام صام (ثلاثة أيام) (٧).
و صوم جزاء الصيد واجب، قال الله عز وجل: ﴿ومن قتله منكم متعمدا فجزاء مثل ما قتل من النعم يحكم به ذوا عدل منكم هديا بالغ الكعبة أو كفارة طعام مساكين أو عدل ذلك صياما ليذوق وبال أمره﴾ (8).
وقال علي بن الحسين - عليه السلام - للزهري: يا زهري أو تدري كيف يكون عدل ذلك صياما؟ قال: لا أدري، قال - عليه السلام -: يقوم (9) الصيد قيمة (10)، ثم تفض (11) تلك القيمة على البر، ثم يكال ذلك البر أصواعا فيصوم لكل نصف صاع يوما، وصوم النذر واجب، وصوم الاعتكاف واجب.

translation:
The fasting of two consecutive months in expiation for zihar is obligatory for those who cannot afford to free a slave. Allah Almighty said: "And those who pronounce thihar from their wives and then go back on what they said, [there must be] the freeing of a slave before they touch one another. This is what you are admonished to do. And Allah is All-Aware of what you do. But he who does not find [a slave] must fast for two consecutive months." (Al-Mujadila: 3-4).

Fasting for three days is required in expiation for breaking an oath for those who cannot afford to feed [the needy]. Allah the Exalted said: "But if someone cannot [afford that], then he must fast for three days. That is the expiation for [breaking] your oaths when you swear." (Al-Maida: 89).

Fasting for Dam of Enjoyment is obligatory. Allah the Exalted said: "But for whoever cannot find [an animal], then a fast of three days during [Hajj] and of seven when you have returned; those are ten [complete] days." (Al-Baqara: 196).

Fasting in compensation for [the harm caused by] shaving the head is obligatory. Allah the Exalted said: "So whoever among you is ill or has an ailment of the head [making shaving necessary must offer] a ransom of fasting or charity or sacrifice." (Al-Baqara: 196). The individual has the choice, and if he fasts, he should fast for three days.

Fasting as a recompense for hunting is obligatory. Allah the Exalted said: "And whoever kills it intentionally, the penalty is an equivalent from sacrificial animals to what he killed, as judged by two just men among you as an offering [to Allah] delivered to the Ka’bah, or an expiation: the feeding of needy people, or the equivalent of that in fasting, that he may taste the consequence of his deed." (Al-Maida: 95).

Ali bin Al-Husain - peace be upon him - said to Al-Zuhri: "O Zuhri, do you know how the equivalent of that would be in fasting?" He replied: "I do not know." He - peace be upon him - said: "The animal is evaluated, and that value is distributed as food [for the needy]; then that food is measured by sa', and one fasts for each half sa' a day." Fasting due to a vow is obligatory, and fasting for spiritual retreat (I’tikaaf) is obligatory.

text:
وأما الصوم الحرام: فصوم يوم الفطر، ويوم الأضحى، وثلاثة أيام التشريق (1) وصوم يوم الشك أمرنا به ونهينا عنه، أمرنا أن نصومه مع شعبان، ونهينا عنه (2) أن ينفرد الرجل بصيامه في اليوم الذي يشك فيه الناس، فإن لم يكن صام من شعبان شيئا ينوي ليلة الشك أنه صائم من شعبان، فإن كان من شهر رمضان أجزأ عنه وإن كان من شعبان لم يضره.
فقال الزهري: وكيف يجزي صوم تطوع عن فريضة؟ فقال - عليه السلام -: لو أن رجلا صام يوما من شهر رمضان تطوعا، وهو لا يدري ولا يعلم أنه من شهر رمضان، ثم علم بعد ذلك، أجزأ عنه، لأن الفرض إنما وقع على اليوم بعينه.
وصوم الوصال (3) حرام وصوم الصمت حرام، وصوم الدهر حرام، وصوم نذر المعصية حرام.
وأما الصوم (4) الذي صاحبه فيه بالخيار، فصوم يوم الجمعة، والخميس، والاثنين، وصوم البيض، وصوم ستة أيام من شوال بعد شهر رمضان، ويوم عرفة، ويوم عاشوراء، كل ذلك صاحبه فيه بالخيار إن شاء صام، وإن شاء أفطر.
وأما صوم الإذن، فإن المرأة لا تصوم تطوعا إلا بإذن زوجها، والعبد لا يصوم تطوعا إلا بإذن سيده، والضيف لا يصوم تطوعا إلا بإذن صاحبه.
قال رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -: من نزل على قوم فلا يصومن (5) تطوعا إلا بإذنهم.
وأما صوم التأديب، فإنه يؤمر الصبي إذا راهق بالصوم تأديبا وليس بفرض، وكذلك من أفطر لعلة من (6) أول النهار، ثم قوي بعد ذلك أمر بالامساك بقية يومه تأديبا وليس بفرض.

translation:
As for prohibited fasting, it includes fasting on the day of Eid al-Fitr, the day of Eid al-Adha, and the three days of Tashreeq. Fasting on the day of doubt (the day before the start of Ramadan when there is uncertainty) is both instructed and forbidden. We are instructed to fast it along with Sha'ban, but forbidden to fast it alone when people are uncertain. If someone has not fasted anything from Sha'ban, they should intend on the night of doubt to fast as if it were part of Sha'ban. If it turns out to be Ramadan, it suffices for that day, and if it remains part of Sha'ban, there is no harm.

Al-Zuhri asked, "How can voluntary fasting cover an obligatory fast?" He (peace be upon him) replied: "If a person fasted a day of Ramadan voluntarily, unaware that it was a day of fasting in Ramadan, and later found out, it suffices for him, as the obligation is specifically tied to the day itself."

Continuous fasting (without breaking at sunset) is forbidden, as is fasting in silence, fasting forever, and fasting due to a vow made in sin.

For fasting where one has the option, it includes fasting on Fridays, Thursdays, and Mondays, the White Days (the 13th, 14th, and 15th of the lunar month), six days of Shawwal following Ramadan, the day of Arafah, and the day of Ashura. In all these cases, one may choose to fast or not.

Regarding fasting with permission, a woman should not fast voluntarily without her husband's permission, a slave without his master's permission, and a guest should not fast without the host's permission. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) said: "Whoever stays with a people should not fast voluntarily without their permission."

For disciplinary fasting, it involves instructing an adolescent to fast for training, and it is not obligatory. Similarly, if someone breaks their fast due to illness in the morning and later recovers, they are encouraged to refrain from eating for the rest of the day for discipline, though it is not obligatory.

text:
وأما صوم الإباحة، فمن أكل أو شرب ناسيا، أو تقيأ من غير تعمد، فقد أباح الله ذلك له، وأجزأ عنه (١) صومه.
وأما صوم السفر والمرض، فإن العامة اختلفت فيه، فقال قوم: يصوم (٢)، (وقال قوم:) (٣) لا يصوم (٤)، وقال قوم: إن شاء صام، وإن شاء أفطر. وأما نحن فنقول: يفطر (٥) في الحالتين جميعا، فان صام في السفر أو في حال المرض فعليه القضاء في ذلك، لأن الله عز وجل يقول: ﴿فمن كان منكم مريضا أو على سفر فعدة من أيام أخر﴾ (6) (7).

translation:
The permissibility of fasting applies to those who accidentally eat or drink or vomit without intent; God has permitted that for them, and their fast is valid. As for fasting while traveling or being ill, there is a difference of opinion among the public. Some said one should fast, others said one should not fast, and some said that it is optional—if one wishes, they may fast, and if they wish, they may break the fast. However, we assert that one should break the fast in both cases. If one fasts while traveling or when ill, they must make up for it, as God Almighty says: "So whoever among you is ill or on a journey [during them] – then an equal number of days [are to be made up] from other days" (Quran, 2:184).

Chapter 2: Sightseeing the Crescent of Ramadan. Know that fasting during the month of Ramadan is based on sighting the moon, and breaking the fast is also based on sighting, not on opinion and conjecture. The sighting is not that ten people stand and one of them claims to see [the moon].

text:
ذا وينظر تسعة فلا يرونه، لأنه إذا رآه واحد رآه عشرة، وإذا رأيت (علة، أو) (1) غيما فأتم شعبان ثلاثين (2).
وقد يكون شهر رمضان تسعة وعشرين، ويكون ثلاثين، ويصيبه ما يصب الشهور من النقصان والتمام (3).
واعلم أنه لا تجوز الشهادة في رؤية الهلال دون خمسين رجلا عدد القسامة (4) ويجوز شهادة رجلين عدلين إذا كانا من خارج المصر (5) وكان بالمصر علة فأخبرا أنهما رأياه، وأخبرا عن قوم صاموا للرؤية (6).
ولا تجوز شهادة النساء (7) في الهلال (8).
واعلم أن الهلال إذا غاب قبل الشفق فهو لليلة (9)، وإذا غاب بعد الشفق

translation:
When nine look, they cannot see it, because if one sees it, then ten have seen it. If you see (a reason or) clouds, complete Sha'ban for thirty days.

The month of Ramadan can be twenty-nine or thirty days long, and, like other months, it can be incomplete or complete.

Be aware that testimony for sighting the crescent moon is not accepted unless there are fifty men, as per the number required for oath-taking. However, the testimony of two just men is acceptable if they are from outside the city and if there is a hindrance in the city, and they report seeing it, along with others who began fasting upon sighting it.

The testimony of women is not accepted for the sighting of the crescent moon.

Know that if the crescent sets before twilight, it is for the previous night, but if it sets after twilight...

فهو لليلتين (1).
وإذا رؤي (2) فيه ظل الرأس فهو لثلاث ليال (3).
وقال أبو عبد الله - عليه السلام -: قد يكون الهلال لليلة وثلث، وليلة ونصف، وليلة وثلثين، ولليلتين إلا شيء وهو لليلة (4) (5).
وروي إذا تطوق الهلال فهو لليلتين (6).

translation:
The crescent moon is for two nights. When the shadow of the head is seen on it, it indicates three nights. Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, said: "The crescent can be for a night and a third, a night and a half, a night and two-thirds, or for two nights minus something, and it is for one night as well." It is narrated that if the crescent moon is encircled, it indicates two nights. 

If you see the crescent moon at midday or towards its end, then complete the fast until nightfall. If you encounter any ambiguity, count thirty days before breaking the fast.

قال أبو عبد الله - عليه السلام -: إذا رؤي الهلال قبل الزوال فذلك اليوم من شوال، وإذا رؤي بعد الزوال فذلك اليوم (1) من شهر رمضان (2).
فإذا رأيت هلال شهر رمضان فاستقبل القبلة، ولا تشر إليه، وارفع يديك إلى الله تبارك وتعالى، وخاطب الهلال، تقول: ربي وربك الله رب العالمين، اللهم أهله علينا بالأمن والايمان، والسلامة والاسلام، والمسارعة إلى ما تحب وترضى، اللهم قد حضر شهر رمضان، وقد افترضت علينا صيامه، وأنزلت فيه القرآن هدى للناس وبينات من الهدى والفرقان، اللهم أعنا على صيامه وقيامه، وتقبله منا، وسلمنا فيه (3) (وتسلمه منا) (4) وسلمه لنا في يسر منك وعافية، إنك على كل شيء قدير يا أرحم الراحمين (5).
3 باب صوم اليوم الذي يشك فيه سئل أمير المؤمنين - عليه السلام - عن اليوم المشكوك فيه، فقال: لأن أصوم يوما

translation:
Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, said: If the new moon is sighted before midday, that day belongs to Shawwal, and if it is sighted after midday, that day belongs to the month of Ramadan.

When you see the crescent of Ramadan, face the Qibla, do not point at it, and raise your hands to God, the Blessed and Exalted. Address the crescent, saying: "My Lord and your Lord is Allah, the Lord of the Worlds. O Allah, let this moon bring us security and faith, safety and Islam, and hastening to that which You love and are pleased with. O Allah, the month of Ramadan has arrived, and You have enjoined upon us its fasting, and You revealed in it the Qur’an as a guidance for mankind and clear proofs of guidance and criterion. O Allah, help us in fasting and praying during it, accept it from us, safeguard us during it, and safeguard it for us with ease and wellness from You. Truly, You have power over all things, O Most Merciful of the merciful."

Chapter on Fasting on a Doubtful Day: Amir al-Mu'minin, peace be upon him, was asked about the doubtful day, and he said: I might as well fast...

من شعبان أحب إلي من أن أفطر يوما من شهر رمضان (1).
وقال أبو عبد الله - عليه السلام -: إذا صح هلال رجب فعد تسعة وخمسين يوما وصم يوم ستين (2).
وسأله بشير النبال عن صوم يوم الشك، فقال - عليه السلام -: صمه، فإن كان من شعبان كان تطوعا، وإن كان من رمضان فيوم وفقت له (3).
وسأله عبد الله بن سنان عن رجل صام شعبان، فلما كان شهر رمضان أضمر يوما من شهر رمضان [فبان] (4) أنه من شعبان، لأنه وقع حد (5) الشك، فقال - عليه السلام -: يعيد ذلك اليوم، وإن أضمر من شعبان [فبان] (6) أنه من شهر (7) رمضان فلا شيء عليه (8).
وسأله عبد الكريم بن عمرو (فقال: جعلت فداك، إني) (9) جعلت على نفسي

translation:
It is more beloved to me than fasting a day in the month of Ramadan. (1)

Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) said: "If the crescent of Rajab becomes visible, count fifty-nine days and fast on the sixtieth day." (2)

Bashir al-Nabbal asked him about fasting on the day of doubt, and he (peace be upon him) said: "Fast it. If it turns out to be from Sha'ban, then it is considered a voluntary fast, and if it is from Ramadan, then it is a day for which you have been facilitated." (3)

Abdullah ibn Sinan asked him about a man who fasted Sha'ban, and when the month of Ramadan arrived, he made the intention for a day of Ramadan, but it turned out to be from Sha'ban because it fell within the boundary of doubt. He (peace be upon him) said: "He should repeat that day. However, if he intended it to be from Sha'ban and it turned out to be from Ramadan, then there is nothing upon him." (4)

He was asked by Abdul Karim ibn Amr who said: "May I be your ransom; I have made a vow upon myself." (9)

text:
أن أصوم حتى يقوم القائم - عليه السلام -، فقال - عليه السلام -: لا تصم في السفر ولا في (1) العيدين، ولا أيام التشريق، ولا اليوم الذي يشك فيه (2).
وسأله عمران الزعفراني، فقال: إن السماء تطبق علينا بالعراق (3) اليومين والثلاثة، فأي يوم نصوم؟
فقال - عليه السلام -: أنظر اليوم الذي صمت فيه (4) من (5) السنة الماضية، فعد منه خمسة أيام وصم يوم الخامس (6).
وقال أبو الحسن الرضا - عليه السلام -: يوم الأضحى في اليوم الذي يصام فيه، ويوم عاشوراء في (7) اليوم الذي يفطر فيه (8).

translation:
I intend to fast until the Riser (peace be upon him) appears. He (peace be upon him) said, "Do not fast while traveling, nor on the two Eids, nor during the Days of Tashreeq, nor on a day of doubt."

'Imran Al-Za‘farani asked him, saying: "In Iraq, the skies are often overcast for two or three days. When should we start fasting?" He (peace be upon him) replied, "Look at the day you began fasting last year, count five days from it, and begin fasting on the fifth day."

Abu Al-Hasan Al-Ridha (peace be upon him) said: "Eid al-Adha falls on a day of fasting, and Ashura falls on a day of breaking the fast."

The compiler of "Wasa'il" first interprets this to mean that Eid al-Adha usually coincides with the start of Ramadan, and Ashura often coincides with the start of Shawwal. Secondly, it suggests that the day of fasting is like a festival due to the great reward, while the day of breaking the fast is akin to a day of calamity due to the missed reward.

4 باب ما يفطر الصائم وما لا يفطره واجتنب في صومك خمسة أشياء تفطرك (1): الأكل، والشرب، والجماع، والارتماس في الماء، والكذب على الله ورسوله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - (وعلى الأئمة) (2) - عليهم السلام - (3).
ولا بأس بالقبلة في شهر رمضان للصائم (4)، وأفضل ذلك أن يتنزه عنها (5)، فقد قال أمير المؤمنين - عليه السلام -: أما يستحيي أحدكم أن لا يصبر يوما إلى الليل؟ إنه كان يقال: إن بدو القتال اللطام (6).

translation:
Chapter 4: What Invalidates the Fast and What Does Not

During your fast, avoid five things that break the fast: eating, drinking, engaging in sexual intercourse, immersion in water, and lying against God and His Messenger (peace and blessings be upon him and his family), and the Imams (peace be upon them).

There is no harm in kissing during Ramadan for those who are fasting, but it is preferable to abstain from it. Amir al-Mu’minin (peace be upon him) said: "Isn't it shameful that one cannot endure until nightfall? It was said: The beginning of strife is a slap."

References are cited which include various religious texts that support these rulings, emphasizing the authenticity and importance of adhering to these guidelines during fasting in Ramadan, as found in works such as "Al-Kafi," "Al-Tahdhib," "Al-Istibsar," and others.

text:
ولو أن رجلا لصق بأهله في شهر رمضان فأمنى فليس (1) عليه شيء (2).
وسئل النبي - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - عن الرجل يقبل امرأته وهو صائم؟ فقال (3): هل هي إلا ريحانة يشمها (4).
وسأل حماد بن عثمان أبا عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن رجل أجنب في شهر رمضان من أول الليل، وأخر الغسل إلى أن طلع الفجر؟ فقال: كان رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - يجامع نساءه من أول الليل ثم يؤخر الغسل حتى يطلع الفجر (5)، ولا أقول (6) كما يقول هؤلاء الأقشاب (7): يقضي (8) يوما مكانه (9).

translation:
If a man has intimate relations with his family during the month of Ramadan and ejaculates, there is nothing required of him (1).

The Prophet - peace and blessings be upon him - was asked about a man who kisses his wife while fasting, and he replied (3): "Is she not just like a sweet basil (Reihaana) that he enjoys its scent (4)?"

Hammad ibn Uthman asked Abu Abdullah - peace be upon him - about a man who became in a state of janaba (impurity) during Ramadan from the start of the night and delayed ghusl (ritual purification) until dawn. He replied: "The Messenger of Allah - peace and blessings be upon him - would have relations with his wives from the start of the night and delay the ghusl until dawn (5), and I do not say (6) as those base ones (7) do: that he must make up a day in its place (8)."

text:
ولا بأس بالسواك للصائم بالنهار متى شاء (1)، ولا بأس بأن (2) يستاك بالماء وبالعود الرطب (3).
وإذا استاك فأدمى ودخل (4) الدم جوفه فقد أفطر (5).
وسأله (6) سماعة بن مهران عن القيء في شهر رمضان؟ فقال: إن كان شيء (7) يبدره فلا بأس، وإن كان شيء يكره نفسه فقد أفطر (8).
وسئل أبو جعفر - عليه السلام - عن القلس (9) يفطر الصائم؟ قال: لا (10).
ولا بأس أن يتمضمض الصائم، ويستنشق، ويكتحل، ويحتجم، ويشم الريحان، ويتبخر (11)، ويزق الفرخ، ويمضغ الخبز للرضيع من غير أن يبلع شيئا.

translation:
There is no harm in a fasting person using the tooth-stick (siwak) during the day whenever they wish, and it is also permissible to use water and a moist stick. If one uses the siwak and it leads to bleeding and blood enters the throat, then the fast is broken.

Sama'a bin Mehran asked him about vomiting during the month of Ramadan. He said: If something suddenly comes out, there is no harm, but if one intentionally induces it, the fast is broken.

Abu Ja'far, peace be upon him, was asked about whether regurgitation breaks the fast. He said: No, it does not.

There is no problem for a fasting person in rinsing the mouth, inhaling water through the nose, using kohl, undergoing cupping, smelling basil, using incense, feeding a chick by mouth, or chewing bread for an infant without swallowing anything.

It is permissible for a cook to taste the broth to discern its flavor—whether it is sweet or sour. One can chew gum, instill medicine in one's ear if complaining of a condition, and use nasal drops, but it is not permissible to use enemas.

A woman should not sit in water as it may enter her through the front, whereas a man may soak in it as long as he does not fully immerse himself.

translation:
### Chapter 5: About Those Who Break Their Fast or Engage in Intercourse During Ramadan

Know that whoever engages in intercourse during Ramadan or intentionally breaks their fast, is required to free a slave, fast for two consecutive months, or feed sixty needy people, each with a mud (a specific measure) of food. Additionally, they must make up for that day, which would be hard to replicate. If they are unable to do so, they should give charity according to their means.

It is related that a man from the Ansar came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and said: "I have perished, and I have caused others to perish." The Prophet asked: "What has led to your destruction?" The man replied: "I approached my wife during Ramadan while I was fasting." The Prophet (peace be upon him) instructed him to free a slave. The man said: "I cannot afford that." The Prophet then said: "Fast for two consecutive months." The man responded: "I am unable to do that." The Prophet further instructed: "Feed sixty needy people." The man stated: "I do not have the means for that."

Then, the Prophet (peace be upon him) was brought a bunch of dates containing fifteen sa' (a larger measure), and he said to him... [The remainder of the text seems to have variations and annotations from different sources.]

The Prophet - peace and blessings be upon him and his family - said: "Take this and give it in charity." The man replied: "By the One who sent you with the truth as a Prophet, there is no household between its two black stony tracts that is in greater need of it than ours." He said: "Then take it and eat it, and feed your family, for it will be an expiation for you."

6. Chapter: Whoever has sexual relations, or breaks their fast forgetfully during Ramadan or at other times. If someone fasting forgets and eats or drinks during Ramadan or at other times, it is provision granted to them by Allah Almighty, and they should complete their fast with no need for making up for it. Similarly, if someone has sexual intercourse during Ramadan forgetfully, it is as if they ate and drank forgetfully during Ramadan, and there is nothing upon them.

وسأل محمد بن مسلم أبا جعفر - عليه السلام - عن قول الله عز وجل: ﴿وعلى الذين يطيقونه فدية طعام مسكين﴾ (٣) قال: الشيخ الكبير، والذي يأخذه العطش، وعن قوله: ﴿فمن لم يستطع فاطعام ستين مسكينا﴾ (4) قال: من مرض أو عطش (5).

translation:
Chapter 7: Those Who Are Unable to Fast

If an elder, youth, or pregnant woman cannot manage fasting due to thirst and hunger, or if a woman fears it may harm her child, they are all allowed to break their fast. Each must give charity, equivalent to a measure of food, for each day missed.

Muhammad ibn Muslim asked Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him) about the words of Allah Almighty: "And upon those who can fast with difficulty, they have a ransom, feeding a poor person" (Quran, 2:184). He replied, referring to the elderly and those overwhelmed by thirst. Concerning the verse "And whoever is not able to do so, then feeding sixty needy people" (Quran, 58:4), he said it applies to those who are ill or suffer from thirst.

Those who are too weak to fast and cannot afford charity are not required to do anything.

8 باب الوقت الذي يؤخذ الصبي فيه بالصوم إعلم أن الغلام يؤخذ بالصيام إذا بلغ تسع سنين - على قدر ما يطيقه - فان أطاق إلى الظهر أو بعده صام إلى ذلك الوقت، فإذا غلب عليه الجوع والعطش أفطر (1).
وإذا صام ثلاثة أيام ولاء أخذ بصوم الشهر كله (2).

### Chapter 8: The Age at Which a Boy Should Begin Fasting

It is known that a boy is required to start fasting when he reaches nine years old, to the extent that he is capable. If he can fast until noon or a bit after, then he should fast until that time. However, if he is overcome by hunger and thirst, he may break his fast.

If a boy successfully fasts for three consecutive days, he is then obligated to fast for the entire month.

There is also a narration that a boy should begin fasting between the ages of fourteen and fifteen, unless he shows the ability to fast before reaching this age.

These guidelines are mentioned in various sources, including "Fiqh al-Ridha," "Al-Faqih," "Al-Kafi," "Al-Tahdhib," and "Al-Istibsar," as well as other traditional Islamic texts.

It is narrated from Abu Abdullah - peace be upon him - that he said: A boy must fast when he reaches puberty, and a woman must fast and wear the veil when she menstruates, unless she is a slave, then she is not required to wear the veil unless she wishes to do so, but she must fast.

Chapter 9: The Shortening of the Traveler's Fast

If you travel during the month of Ramadan and break your fast, follow the guidelines I have explained regarding the extent to which you must shorten your fasting and prayer during travel. Be aware that anyone required to shorten their prayer during travel must also break their fast. Conversely, anyone obligated to perform the full prayer must fast; if they complete the full prayer, they must fast, and if they shorten their prayer, they break their fast.

Those who are obliged to maintain full prayer and fasting during travel are the makari and kari (those who rent out their animals for carrying goods or passengers).

translation: (Al-Ishtiqan - which refers to the postal service -), the shepherd, and the sailor, as it is their occupation. The person involved in hunting, if his hunting is for arrogance or extravagance, he must perform full prayers and break his fast during fasting. However, if his hunting is returned (i.e., intended) for the provision of his family, then he is obligated to shorten his prayers and fast. If a traveler begins the day in his hometown and then departs, he has the choice to either fast or break the fast. If dawn breaks while he is outside but has not yet entered a town, he also has the choice to either fast or break the fast. If he travels before noon, he should break his fast, and if he departs after noon, he should fast.

translation:
It is narrated that if one embarks on a journey after midday, one should break their fast and make up that day later. If a traveler breaks their fast, it is permissible for him to be intimate with his wife or female servant if he wishes, although a prohibition on this has been narrated.

Abu al-Hasan, peace be upon him, said: "Fasting during travel is not an act of piety." If a man fasts while traveling, and it has reached him that the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him and his family, forbade this, then he must make up for it, but if it has not reached him, then nothing is required of him.

Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, was asked about a man who sets out to accompany his brother on a two or three-day journey. He said: "If it is during the month of Ramadan, he should break his fast." I asked: "Which is better, to fast or to accompany him?" He replied: "To accompany him, for God has waived the fast for him when he accompanies his brother."

These narrations emphasize the Islamic ruling regarding fasting while traveling, highlighting that under certain conditions, travelers are exempt from fasting and have the option to make it up later, thus maintaining an emphasis on communal support and the ease of religious observances.

وسئل - عليه السلام - عن رجل أتى سوقا يتسوق بها، وهي من منزله على سبع (1) فراسخ، فان هو أتاها على الدابة أتاها في بعض يوم، وإن ركب السفن لم يأتها في يوم؟
قال: يتم الراكب الذي يرجع من يومه صومه (2)، ويفطر (3) صاحب السفن (4).
وإذا أردت سفرا وأردت أن تقدم من صوم السنة شيئا، فصم ثلاثة أيام للشهر الذي تريد الخروج فيه (5)، فلا تصومن في السفر شيئا من فرض ولا سنة ولا تطوع، إلا الصوم الذي ذكرته في أول الباب (6) من صوم كفارة صيد المحرم، (وصوم كفارة) (7) الاحلال من الإحرام إن كان به أذى من رأسه، وصوم ثلاثة أيام لطلب حاجة عند قبر النبي - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -، وهو يوم الأربعاء والخميس والجمعة، وصوم الإعتكاف في المسجد الحرام، أو (8) في مسجد رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -، أو (9) مسجد الكوفة، أو مسجد المدائن (10) (11).

The Prophet - peace be upon him - was asked about a man who went to a market for shopping, which was seven farsakhs (a measure of distance) away from his home. If he went there riding an animal, he could reach there within part of a day, but if he traveled by ship, he would not reach it in a day.

He said: The rider who returns the same day should continue his fast, but the one traveling by ship should break his fast.

And if you intend to travel and wish to fast for some days of the year, fast three days in the month you plan to leave. Do not fast while traveling, neither obligatory, nor supererogatory, except for the fast mentioned at the beginning of the chapter, which is for atonement for hunting during the pilgrimage. Also, you may fast as atonement for removing the state of Ihram if there was any harm to your head, and fast three days in seeking a need at the grave of the Prophet - peace be upon him and his family - on Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. Additionally, you may fast for retreat in the Sacred Mosque, or in the Mosque of the Prophet - peace be upon him and his family - or in the Mosque of Kufa, or the Mosque of Madain.

10 Chapter: Making Up for Missed Days of Ramadan

When you wish to make up missed fasting days from Ramadan, you can choose either to fast them consecutively or separately, as you prefer. It is narrated from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) that he said: "Fast for three days, then break your fast."

If you decide to make up for the fasting days of Ramadan, you have the option to break your fast until noon. However, if you break your fast after noon, you are required to give a penalty similar to one who breaks a fast during the month of Ramadan. It is narrated that if someone breaks the fast after noon, they must feed ten needy people, giving each one a "mud" of food. If they are unable to do so, they should fast one day in place of each missed one and fast for three days.

translation:
The text discusses several rulings related to fasting:

1. If a person wakes up without the intention to fast but later decides to do so, he may fast.

2. Imam Al-Sadiq, peace be upon him, was asked about a person who is voluntarily fasting and is then faced with a need. He said: This person has the option to continue or break the fast until the afternoon. If he remains fasting until the afternoon without having initially intended to fast, he may continue the fast for the rest of the day if he wishes.

3. If a man dies and owes fasting days, such as from Ramadan, it is incumbent upon his heir to make up the fast on his behalf. This also applies to days missed due to travel or illness, unless the person died from the illness before recovering, in which case no fast needs to be made up for him.

References are provided for various sources and collections of these rulings, including "Al-Masaalik," "Al-Mustadrak," "Al-Mukhtalif," and other Islamic texts. These references indicate the texts where similar discussions and rulings can be found.

وإذا كان للميت وليان فعلى أكبرهما من الرجال أن يقضي عنه، وإن لم يكن له ولي من الرجال قضى عنه وليه من النساء (1).
وإذا مرض الرجل وفاته صوم شهر رمضان كله ولم يصمه إلى أن دخل عليه شهر رمضان من (2) قابل، فعليه أن يصوم هذا الذي دخله، ويتصدق (3) عن الأول لكل يوم بمد من طعام، وليس عليه القضاء، إلا أن يكون صح فيما بين شهري رمضان، فإن كان كذلك ولم يصم فعليه أن يتصدق (4) عن الأول لكل يوم بمد من طعام ويصوم الثاني، فإذا صام الثاني قضى الأول بعده (5).
وإن (6) فاته شهر رمضان حتى يدخل الشهر الثالث من مرض، فعليه أن يصوم الذي دخله ويتصدق (7) عن الأول لكل يوم بمد من طعام ويقضي الثاني (8).
وإذا طهرت المرأة من حيضها وقد بقي عليها بقية يوم، صامت ذلك المقدار تأديبا، وعليها القضاء (9).

translation:
If the deceased has two heirs, the responsibility to fulfill any outstanding obligations falls on the oldest male. However, if there are no male heirs, then a female heir must fulfill these obligations on behalf of the deceased.

If a man falls ill and misses fasting the entire month of Ramadan, failing to make it up before the next Ramadan arrives, he must fast the current Ramadan and give charity for each missed day of the previous Ramadan, equivalent to a measure of food. He is not required to make up the missed fasts unless he recovered at some point between the two Ramadans. If he did recover but still did not fast, he must give charity for each missed day of the first Ramadan and fast during the second. Once he completes the fast for the second Ramadan, he should make up the fasts from the previous Ramadan thereafter.

Should a person remain ill through the second Ramadan into a third month, he must fast the third month and give charity equivalent to a measure of food for each missed day of the first Ramadan, and make up the second Ramadan fasts.

If a woman completes her menstrual cycle with a portion of the day remaining, she should fast for the remainder of that day as a discipline, but she is required to make up for that day later.

Notes provide references to the sources of these rulings, such as various Islamic legal texts and jurisprudence.

وإذا وجب على الرجل صوم شهرين متتابعين فصام شهرا ولم يصم من الشهر الثاني شيئا، فعليه أن يعيد صومه، ولم يجزه (1) الشهر الأول (2) (3)، إلا أن يكون أفطر لمرض فله أن يبني على ما صام فإن الله حبسه (4).
فان صام شهرا وصام من الشهر الثاني أياما ثم أفطر، فعليه أن يبني على ما صام (5).

translation:
If a man is required to fast for two consecutive months, and he completes one month but does not fast any days in the second month, he must start his fasting again, as the first month will not suffice him. However, if he breaks his fast due to illness, he is permitted to continue from where he left off, for it is by God's will that he was prevented.

If he completes one month and a few days of the second month, then breaks his fast, he is allowed to continue from where he left off.

Regarding voluntary fasting for someone who still owes fasts from the month of Ramadan, it is important to know that one cannot engage in voluntary fasting while a mandatory fast remains unfulfilled. This is affirmed in all the hadiths I have found on the matter.

translation:
Chapter 12: A Man Converts to Islam During Ramadan

Imam al-Sadiq, peace be upon him, was asked about a man who converted to Islam halfway through the month of Ramadan. What is required of him regarding his fasting? He said: He is only responsible for fasting during the period from when he converted to Islam, and he is not obligated to make up for the days that have passed before his conversion.

Chapter 13: The Virtue of Suhoor (Pre-dawn Meal)

It is narrated from Amir al-Mu'minin, peace be upon him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and his family, who said: "Indeed, Allah and His angels send blessings upon those who seek forgiveness and those who partake in Suhoor during the pre-dawn hours." So, let each of you have Suhoor, even if it is just a sip of water.

(Note references: The information is supported by various traditional Islamic texts, including "Al-Wasa'il," "Al-Faqih," "Al-Kafi," "Tahdhib," "Al-Istibsar," and "Al-Muqni'a." There are slight variations in manuscripts.)

The best pre-dawn meal (suhoor) consists of barley porridge and dates, and you are allowed to eat and drink until you are certain that dawn has broken. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family) said: "Take help by having the pre-dawn meal for fasting during the day, and by midday rest for standing in prayer at night."

Chapter 14: The time at which breaking the fast is permissible
Know that it is not permissible for you to break your fast until three stars appear, which ascend with the setting of the sun.

translation:
## Chapter 15: The Virtue of Fasting

You should fast on the first day of Rajab, as it is the day Noah boarded the Ark and commanded those with him, both jinn and humans, to fast that day.

Abu Ja'far, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever among you fasts on that day, the fire will be kept away from him for a distance of a year. Whoever fasts for seven days will have the seven gates of hell closed for him. Whoever fasts for eight days will have the eight gates of heaven opened for him. Whoever fasts for ten days will be granted his request. Whoever fasts for fifteen days will be told: 'Resume your deeds, for you have been forgiven.' Whoever does more, Allah will increase their reward."

And whoever fasts on the first day of the ten days of Dhu al-Hijjah, Allah will record for him the fast of eighty...

translation: For whoever fasts the nine days, God will record for them the reward of fasting a lifetime. And whoever fasts on the twenty-seventh day of Rajab, it is as if they have fasted for sixty months. It has also been narrated that the sleep of a fasting person is considered an act of worship, and their breath is glorification. On the twenty-fifth of Rajab, God sent Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) as a messenger. Whoever fasts on that day will be granted the atonement of two hundred years. On the twenty-ninth of Dhu al-Qi'dah, God sent down the Kaaba, which was the first blessing bestowed, and whoever fasts on that day will receive the atonement of seventy years. On the first day of Dhu al-Hijjah, Ibrahim, the close friend of the Merciful (peace be upon him), was born.

translation:
That day serves as atonement for sixty years. On the ninth of Dhu al-Hijjah, David's repentance—peace be upon him—was revealed, and whoever fasts on that day receives the expiation of ninety years. On the first day of Muharram, Zechariah—peace be upon him—prayed to his Lord, and whoever fasts on that day will have their prayers answered just as Zechariah's were.

On the tenth of Muharram, which is the Day of Ashura, God accepted Adam’s repentance—peace be upon him. On that day, the Ark of Noah—peace be upon him—settled on Mount Judi. It is also the day when Moses—peace be upon him—crossed the sea, Jesus, son of Mary—peace be upon him—was born, Jonah—peace be upon him—was brought out of the belly of the whale, Joseph—peace be upon him—was taken out of the well, the people of Jonah repented to God, and David killed Goliath. Whoever fasts on that day will have their sins of seventy years forgiven, and their hidden deeds pardoned.

16 باب الاعتكاف إعلم أنه لا يجوز الاعتكاف إلا في خمسة مساجد: في المسجد الحرام، ومسجد الرسول (1) - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -، ومسجد الكوفة، ومسجد المدائن، ومسجد البصرة.
والعلة في ذلك أنه لا يعتكف إلا في مسجد جامع (2) جمع فيه إمام عدل (3)، وقد جمع النبي - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - بمكة والمدينة، وأمير المؤمنين - عليه السلام - في هذه المساجد (4).
ولا يكون الاعتكاف إلا بصيام (5).

translation:
Chapter 16: The Practice of I'tikaf

Know that I'tikaf (spiritual retreat) is only permissible in five mosques: the Sacred Mosque (Al-Masjid Al-Haram), the Mosque of the Messenger - peace and blessings be upon him and his family -, the Mosque of Kufa, the Mosque of Al-Mada'in, and the Mosque of Basra. 

The reason for this is that I'tikaf is only valid if performed in a congregational mosque where a just Imam has led prayers. The Prophet - peace and blessings be upon him and his family - led prayers in Mecca and Medina, and the Commander of the Faithful - peace be upon him - in these mosques.

Moreover, I'tikaf is only permissible when observed with fasting.

The person in seclusion (I'tikaf) is permitted to leave for the Friday prayer and to fulfill necessary needs. It is narrated: "There is no I'tikaf except in a mosque where Friday prayers are held with an Imam and a sermon." If the person in seclusion falls ill, they may return to their family and are not required to make up the days missed. It is also narrated that observing the ten days of I'tikaf during the month of Ramadan is equivalent to performing two Hajj and two Umrah.

In the chapter of Zakat al-Fitr, pay the obligatory alms for yourself and everyone you support, whether young or old, free or enslaved, male or female. The prescribed amount is a measure (Sa') of dates, or a measure of raisins, or a measure of wheat, or a measure of...

It is also permissible to pay on behalf of yourself and those you support to one person, but it is not permissible to distribute what is due from one person to two people (4).
If you have a Muslim or dhimmi servant, you should pay their zakat al-fitr (5).

فان ولد لك مولود يوم الفطر (1) قبل الزوال فادفع عنه الفطرة، وإن ولد بعد الزوال فلا فطرة عليه، وكذلك إذا أسلم الرجل قبل الزوال أو بعده فعلى هذا (2).
ولا بأس باخراج الفطرة في أول يوم من شهر رمضان إلى آخره، وهي زكاة إلى أن تصلي العيد، فإذا أخرجتها بعد الصلاة فهي صدقة، وأفضل وقتها آخر يوم من شهر رمضان (3).
وروي أنه يجزي عن كل رأس نصف صاع من حنطة أو شعير (4).
وليس على المحتاج صدقة الفطرة (5)، [ومن حلت له لم تحل عليه] (6) (7).
وقال: أبو عبد الله - عليه السلام -: من لم يجد الحنطة والشعير، يجزي (8) عنه

translation:
If a child is born to you on the day of Eid al-Fitr before midday, you should give Zakat al-Fitr on their behalf. However, if the child is born after midday, then Zakat al-Fitr is not obligatory for them. Similarly, if a person converts to Islam before or after midday, the rule applies in the same way.

It is permissible to give Zakat al-Fitr from the first day of Ramadan until the last day. Before the Eid prayer, it is considered Zakat, but if given after the prayer, it counts as charity. The best time for giving it is on the last day of Ramadan.

It is narrated that for each person, half a sa' (a unit of measurement) of wheat or barley suffices.

Those in need are exempt from Zakat al-Fitr, and those eligible to receive it do not have to pay it.

Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, said: "If one is unable to find wheat or barley, it is sufficient for them to offer..."

(Note: The text ends here with an incomplete sentence.)

القمح (1) والسلت (2) والعدس والذرة، نصف صاع من ذلك كله (3).
ولم أرو في التمر والزبيب أقل من صاع (4).
وليس على من يأخذ الزكاة صدقة الفطرة (5).
فان أخرج الرجل فطرته وعزلها حتى يجد لها أهلا فعطبت، فان أخرجها من ضمانه فقد برئ، وإلا فهو ضامن لها حتى يؤديها إلى أربابها (6).
وكتب محمد بن القاسم بن الفضيل إلى أبي الحسن الرضا - عليه السلام - يسأله عن الوصي يزكي زكاة الفطرة عن اليتامى إذا كان لهم مال؟ فكتب - عليه السلام -: لا زكاة على يتيم (7).

Those who receive zakat are not obligated to give the zakat al-fitr (5). If a person separates his zakat al-fitr and sets it aside until he finds someone deserving of it, and it perishes in the meantime, he is absolved if it was taken out of his responsibility, otherwise, he is liable for it until he delivers it to its rightful owners (6).

باب الحج إعلم أن الحج على ثلاثة أوجه: قارن، ومفرد للحج، ومتمتع بالعمرة إلى الحج (١).
وليس لأهل مكة وحاضريها إلا القران والإفراد (٢)، وليس لهم التمتع إلى الحج لأن الله عز وجل يقول:
﴿فمن تمتع بالعمرة إلى الحج فما استيسر من الهدي﴾ (٣)، ثم قال: ﴿ذلك لمن لم يكن أهله حاضري المسجد الحرام﴾ (4) وحد حاضري المسجد الحرام أهل مكة وحواليها على ثمانية وأربعين ميلا، ومن كان خارجا عن هذا الحد فلا يحج إلا متمتعا بالعمرة إلى الحج، ولا يقبل الله غيره (5).

translation:
Chapter on Pilgrimage

Be aware that Hajj has three forms: Qiran, Ifrad, and Tamattu’. The people of Mecca and its surrounding residents are only allowed Qiran and Ifrad. They are not permitted Tamattu’ to Hajj because God Almighty states: "Whoever performs Umrah followed by Hajj must make whatever offering is feasible." Then He says: "This is for those whose families do not reside near the Sacred Mosque." The boundary of those considered "residents near the Sacred Mosque" includes the people of Mecca and those within a radius of forty-eight miles. Anyone outside this boundary can only perform Hajj through Tamattu’, and God does not accept anything else.

References are made to various sources such as "Fiqh al-Ridha," "Al-Hidayah," "Al-Kafi," "Al-Tahdhib," and "Al-Istibsar," detailing slight variations in wording and context regarding the rules and interpretations related to the forms of Hajj, specifically for the residents of Mecca and its surroundings.

text:
فإذا أردت الخروج إلى الحج فاجمع أهلك، وصل ركعتين، ومجد الله كثيرا، وصل على النبي - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - وقل: اللهم إني أستودعك اليوم (1) ديني، ونفسي، ومالي، وأهلي، وولدي، وجيراني، وأهل حزانتي (2)، الشاهد منا والغائب، وجميع ما أنعمت به (3) علي.
اللهم اجعلنا في كنفك (4) ومنعك، وعزك، وعياذك، عز جارك، وجل ثناؤك، وامتنع (5) عائذك، ولا إله غيرك، توكلت على الحي الذي لا يموت [و] (6) الحمد لله الذي لم يتخذ صاحبة ولا ولدا، ولم يكن له شريك في الملك، ولم يكن له ولي من الذل وكبره تكبيرا، (الله أكبر كبيرا) (7)، والحمد لله كثيرا، وسبحان الله بكرة وأصيلا (8).
فإذا خرجت من منزلك فقل: بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم، لا حول ولا قوة إلا بالله العلي العظيم، اللهم إني أعوذ بك من وعثاء السفر (9) وكآبة المنقلب (10)، وسوء المنظر في الأهل والمال والولد، اللهم إني أسألك في سفري هذا السرور والعمل بما يرضيك عني، اللهم اقطع عني بعده ومشقته واصحبني فيه، واخلفني في أهلي

translation:
When you intend to embark on the pilgrimage (Hajj), gather your family and perform two units of prayer. Exalt Allah abundantly, send blessings upon the Prophet—peace and blessings be upon him and his family—and say: "O Allah, today I entrust to You my religion, my soul, my wealth, my family, my children, my neighbors, and those dear to me, be they present or absent, and all the blessings You have bestowed upon me. O Allah, keep us in Your protection and support, in Your might and safety; great is Your neighborliness, exalted is Your praise, Your refuge is unattainable, and there is no god other than You. I rely upon the Ever-Living who does not die, and all praise is due to Allah, who has not taken a companion or a child, who has no partner in His dominion, and who has no protector out of humiliation. Magnify Him with great magnification, Allah is the Greatest, above all comparison, and all praise is due to Allah in abundance. Glory be to Allah at morning and evening."

When you leave your house, say: "In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. There is no power or strength except with Allah, the Most High, the Most Great. O Allah, I seek refuge in You from the hardship of travel, the distress of return, and the bad sights in family, wealth, and children. O Allah, I ask You on this journey for joy and deeds that please You. O Allah, spare me the distance and difficulty, accompany me on it, and take care of my family in my absence."

text:
بخير.
فإذا استويت على راحلتك، واستوى بك محملك، فقل: الحمد لله الذي هدانا للإسلام، وعلمنا القرآن، ومن علينا بمحمد - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -، سبحان الذي سخر لنا هذا (1) وما كنا له مقرنين، وإنا (2) إلى ربنا لمنقلبون، والحمد لله رب العالمين، اللهم أنت الحامل على الظهر، والمستعان على الأمر (3).
وإذا بلغت أحد المواقيت التي وقتها رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -، فإنه وقت لأهل الطائف قرن المنازل ولأهل اليمن (4) يلملم، ولأهل الشام المهيعة وهي الجحفة، ولأهل المدينة ذا الحليفة وهي مسجد الشجرة، ولأهل العراق العقيق (5). وأول العقيق المسلخ، ووسطه غمرة، وآخره ذات عرق (6).
ولا تؤخر الاحرام إلى ذات عرق (7).

translation:
Certainly! Here's the translation of the text:

---

When you are settled on your mount and your saddle is in place, say: "All praise is due to Allah who has guided us to Islam, taught us the Quran, and favored us with Muhammad - may Allah's blessings and peace be upon him and his family. Glory be to Him who has subjected this to us, and we could not have managed it by ourselves, and indeed to our Lord we will return. All praise is due to Allah, the Lord of all worlds. O Allah, You are the support on the back and the one whose help is sought in matters."

And when you reach one of the miqat points appointed by the Messenger of Allah - peace be upon him and his family - it is appointed for the people of Ta'if at Qarn al-Manazil, for the people of Yemen at Yalamlam, for the people of Sham at Mahya'a, which is Al-Juhfah, for the people of Madinah at Dhul Hulayfah, which is the Mosque of the Tree, and for the people of Iraq at Al-`Aqiq. The beginning of Al-`Aqiq is Al-Masilkh, its middle is Ghamrah, and its end is Dhatu Irq.

Do not delay the ihram until you reach Dhatu Irq.

---

text:
ولا تؤخر الإحرام إلى آخر وقت (1) إلا من علة (2) وأوله أفضل (3).
وإذا (4) بلغت، فاغتسل والبس ثوبي إحرامك (5)، ولا تقنع رأسك بعد الغسل، ولا تأكل طعاما فيه الطيب (6).
ولا بأس بأن تحرم في أي (7) وقت بلغت الميقات (8)، فان (9) أحرمت في دبر الفريضة فهو أفضل (10).

translation:
Do not delay entering the state of Ihram until the last moment unless there is a valid reason. Starting early is preferable. Once you reach the designated Miqat, perform the ritual bath (Ghusl), don the two garments of Ihram, and refrain from covering your head after bathing. Avoid eating food with any fragrance. It is permissible to enter the state of Ihram at the time you reach the Miqat. However, entering the state of Ihram immediately following the obligatory prayer is considered more virtuous.

text:
وإن (1) لم يكن وقت المكتوبة، صليت ركعتي الاحرام (وقرأت في الأولى (الحمد) و (قل هو الله أحد) وفي الثانية (الحمد) و (قل يا أيها الكافرون) وإن كان (2) وقت صلاة مكتوبة، فصل ركعتي الاحرام) (3) قبل الفريضة ثم صل الفريضة، وأحرم في دبرها ليكون أفضل (4).
فإذا فرغت من صلاتك فاحمد الله، واثن عليه، وصل على النبي (5) - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -، وقل: اللهم إني أسألك أن تجعلني ممن استجاب لك، وآمن بوعدك، واتبع أمرك، وإني عبدك وفي قبضتك، لا (أوقي) (6) إلا ما وقيت (7)، ولا آخذ إلا ما أعطيت.
اللهم (8) إني أريد ما أمرت به (من التمتع) (9) بالعمرة إلى الحج، على كتابك وسنة نبيك صلواتك عليه وآله، فان عرض لي عارض يحبسني (10)، فحلني (11) حيث حبستني لقدرك الذي قدرت علي، اللهم إن لم تكن حجة فعمرة، أحرم لك شعري، وبشري، ولحمي، ودمي، وعظامي، ومخي، وعصبي من النساء، والثياب (12)، والطيب، أبتغي بذلك وجهك الكريم، والدار الآخرة.
ويجزيك أن تقول: هذا مرة واحدة حين (13) تحرم (14).

translation:
If it is not the time for the obligatory prayer, you should perform the two Rak'ahs of Ihram prayer, reciting in the first Rak'ah Surah Al-Fatiha and Surah Al-Ikhlas (Say, "He is Allah, [who is] One"), and in the second Rak'ah Surah Al-Fatiha and Surah Al-Kafirun (Say, "O disbelievers"). However, if it is the time for an obligatory prayer, perform the two Rak'ahs of Ihram prayer before the obligatory prayer, then perform the obligatory prayer and enter Ihram right after it, as this is considered better.

After completing your prayer, praise Allah and glorify Him, and send blessings upon the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him and his family. Then say: O Allah, I ask You to make me among those who respond to You, believe in Your promise, and follow Your command. Indeed, I am Your servant and in Your grasp. I cannot be protected from anything except by Your protection, nor do I take anything except what You give.

O Allah, I intend to perform what You have commanded, which is enjoying the 'Umrah leading to Hajj, following Your Book and the Sunnah of Your Prophet, Your blessings upon him and his family. If something occurs that prevents me, then release me where You have withheld me, to the extent that You have decreed for me. O Allah, if not a Hajj, then make it an 'Umrah. I dedicate to You my hair, my skin, my flesh, my blood, my bones, my marrow, and my nerves from women, clothes, and perfume, seeking thereby Your noble face and the Hereafter.

It suffices to say this once when you enter Ihram.

text:
ثم قم فامض هنيئة فإذا استوت بك الأرض راكبا كنت أم ماشيا، فقل: لبيك اللهم لبيك، لبيك لا شريك لك لبيك، إن الحمد والنعمة لك والملك، لا شريك لك (1) لبيك، هذه (الأربع مفروضات) (2).
ثم تقول: لبيك ذا المعارج لبيك، لبيك تبدئ والمعاد إليك لبيك، لبيك داعيا إلى دار السلام لبيك، لبيك غفار الذنوب لبيك، لبيك مرهوبا ومرغوبا إليك (لبيك، لبيك أنت الغني ونحن الفقراء إليك لبيك، لبيك (3) ذا الجلال والاكرام) (4) لبيك، لبيك إله الحق (5) لبيك، لبيك ذا النعماء والفضل الحسن الجميل لبيك، لبيك كشاف الكرب العظام لبيك، لبيك عبدك (وابن عبديك) (6) لبيك، لبيك يا كريم لبيك، لبيك [أتقرب إليك بمحمد (وآل محمد) (7) - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - لبيك] (8)، [لبيك] (9) بحجة وعمرة معا (10) لبيك، لبيك (هذه عمرة متعة) (11) إلى الحج لبيك، لبيك تمامها وبلاغها عليك لبيك.
تقول هذه: في دبر كل صلاة مكتوبة، أو نافلة، وحين ينهض بك بعيرك، أو علوت شرفا، أو هبطت واديا، أو لقيت راكبا، أو استيقظت من منامك، أو ركبت، أو نزلت، وبالأسحار، وإن تركت بعض التلبية فلا يضرك، غير أنها أفضل، وأكثر من ذي المعارج (12).

translation:
Once you get up and proceed for a while, whether riding or walking on level ground, say: "Here I am, O Allah, here I am. Here I am, You have no partner, here I am. Verily, all praise and blessings belong to You, and the dominion, You have no partner" (1). Here I am, this being the four obligatory ones (2).

Then say: "Here I am, O Owner of Ascension, here I am. Here I am to the One who initiates and to whom returns belong, here I am. Here I am, who calls to the abode of peace, here I am. Here I am, Forgiver of sins, here I am. Here I am, the One whom we fear and hope for, here I am. Here I am, You are the Self-Sufficient and we are in need of You, here I am. Here I am, O the Most Glorious and Honorable" (4), here I am. Here I am, O God of Truth (5), here I am. Here I am, the Bestower of blessings and the one who offers praiseworthy grace, here I am. Here I am, the Reliever of great distress, here I am. Here I am, Your servant (and the son of Your servants) (6), here I am. Here I am, O Generous one, here I am. Here I am, [I draw closer to You by Muhammad (and the family of Muhammad) (7) - May Allah's blessings be upon him and his family - here I am] (8). Here I am with Hajj and Umrah together (10), here I am. Here I am, (this is the Umrah of enjoyment) (11) leading to Hajj, here I am. Here I am, its completion and accomplishment are up to You, here I am.

You say this at the end of every obligatory or voluntary prayer, when your camel stands up with you, or when you ascend a height, descend into a valley, meet a rider, wake up from sleep, mount or dismount. This is also said in the early morning hours. If you omit some of the 'Talbiyah', it does not harm you, but it is better to say it more often, especially the ‘Owner of Ascension’ part (12).

text:
ولا بأس أن تدهن حين تريد أن تحرم بدهن الحناء والبنفسج (1) وسليخة البان (2) (3) وبأي دهن شئت، إذا لم يكن فيه مسك، أو عنبر، أو زعفران، أو ورس، قبل أن تغتسل للاحرام، ولا تجمر (4) (ثوبا لاحرامك) (5) (6).
والسنة في الاحرام تقليم الأظفار، وأخذ الشارب، وحلق العانة (7).
وإذا اغتسل الرجل بالمدينة لاحرامه ولبس ثوبين، ثم نام قبل أن يحرم، فعليه إعادة الغسل (8). وروي ليس عليه إعادة الغسل (9).

translation:
It is permissible for one to apply henna oil, violet oil, salikha oil (a type of fragrance resembling peeled bark), or any oil you wish when intending to enter the state of Ihram, provided it does not contain musk, ambergris, saffron, or aloeswood, and this should be done before performing the ritual wash for Ihram. You should not perfume (your Ihram clothing).

The Sunnah during Ihram includes trimming the nails, shaving the moustache, and cleaning the pubic area.

If a man performs the ritual wash in Medina for his Ihram and wears two garments, but then sleeps before entering the state of Ihram, he should repeat the ritual wash. However, it is also reported that it is not necessary to repeat the wash.

References:
1. Al-Mustadrak: 9/213, Hadith 2. Variants are found in Al-Faqih: 2/201, Hadith 6 and Al-Tahdhib: 5/303, Hadith 31, and others, all collected in the appropriate sections of the religious jurisprudence texts.

2. Salikha is a type of fragrance derived from a tree known for its pleasant oil.
   
3. Al-Mustadrak and other sources confirm the practice mentioned, with detailed references found in other religious texts.

4. To perfume clothing by burning incense is described in "Lisan al-Arab: 4/145."

5 & 6. Variations of the phrase related to Ihram clothing are found in different religious texts.

7. Reference to related practices in authentic collections like Al-Kafi and Al-Tahdhib indicates slight variations in wording but similar meaning.

8 & 9. Al-Mustadrak and other sources discuss the requirement and the difference of opinion regarding repeating the ritual wash, which is detailed in other religious scriptures.

text:
وإن لبست ثوبا من قبل أن تلبي فانزعه (من فوق وأعد الغسل ولا شيء عليك، وإن لبسته بعد ما لبيت فانزعه) (1) من أسفل، وعليك دم شاة، وإن كنت جاهلا فلا شيء عليك (2).
ولا بأس أن تمسح رأسك بمنديل إذا اغتسلت للاحرام (3) (4).
واعلم أن غسل ليلتك يجزيك ليومك، وغسل يومك يجزيك لليلتك (5).
ولا بأس للرجل أن يغتسل بكرة ويحرم عشية (6).
واتق في إحرامك الكذب، واليمين الكاذبة والصادقة - وهو الجدال - (7).
واتق الصيد (8).

translation:
If you put on clothing before declaring your intention (talbiyah), remove it from above and perform the washing again, and there is no penalty upon you. However, if you wear it after declaring your intention, remove it from below and you must offer the sacrifice of a sheep. If you were unaware, there is no penalty upon you.

It is permissible to wipe your head with a handkerchief after washing for ihraam.

Know that washing at night suffices for the day, and washing during the day suffices for the night.

There is no harm for a man to bathe in the morning and enter ihraam in the evening.

In your state of ihraam, avoid lying, false oaths, and truthful oaths that lead to disputes. Avoid hunting as well.

text:
والجدال قول (1) الرجل: لا والله وبلى والله (2).
فان جادلت مرة، أو مرتين وأنت صادق فلا شيء عليك (3)، (وإن جادلت ثلاثا وأنت صادق فعليك دم شاة (4)) (5).
فان جادلت مرة كاذبا فعليك دم شاة (6)، فان جادلت مرتين كاذبا فعليك دم بقرة (7).

translation:
Disputation is when a man says: "No, by God" and "Yes, by God."

If you argue once or twice while being truthful, there is nothing upon you. However, if you argue three times while being truthful, then a sheep's blood is required as expiation.

If you argue once while lying, a sheep's blood is required as expiation. If you argue twice while lying, the expiation is the blood of a cow.

The sources reference various Islamic jurisprudential texts and collections, indicating the origins and validations of these rulings, but they revolve around the themes of expiation and the seriousness of swearing falsely.

text:
فان جادلت ثلاث مرات كاذبا فعليك بدنة (1). والفسوق: الكذب، فاستغفر الله منه، والرفث: الجماع (2).
فان جامعت وأنت محرم في الفرج فعليك بدنة والحج من قابل، ويجب أن يفرق (3) بينك وبين أهلك حتى تقضيا (4) المناسك ثم تجتمعان (5)، فان أخذتما على طريق غير (6) الذي كنتما أخذتما فيه عام أول لم يفرق بينكما (7).
وعلى المرأة إذا جامعها الرجل بدنة، فان أكرهها لزمته بدنتان ولم يلزم المرأة شيء (8) (9).

translation:
If you engage in false argumentation three times, you must offer a camel as a penalty. Falsehood is considered a form of immorality, so seek forgiveness from God for it. "Rafath" refers to intimate relations.

If you engage in sexual intercourse during the state of ihram, you are required to offer a camel as a penalty, and your pilgrimage must be repeated the following year. Furthermore, you must be separated from your spouse until you complete the pilgrimage rituals, after which you may reunite. If you take a different route than the one you took the previous year, separation is not required.

If a woman is coerced into physical intimacy, the man must offer two camels, while the woman is not held accountable. 

This guidance is referenced in several Islamic jurisprudence texts and commentaries, which discuss the consequences and atonement for violating certain pilgrimage and moral codes.

text:
فإن كان جماعك دون الفرج فعليك بدنة، وليس عليك الحج من قابل (1).
وإن وقعت على أهلك بعد ما تعقد (2) الاحرام وقبل أن تلبي، فليس عليك شيء (3).
واغتسل النبي - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - بذي الحليفة للاحرام، وصلى، ثم قال (4): هاتوا ما عندكم من لحوم الصيد، فأتي بحجلتين (5) فأكلهما قبل أن يحرم (6).
وإن كان معك أم (ولد لك) (7) فأحرمت قبل أن تحرم، فإن لك أن تنقض إحرامها وتواقعها إن أحببت (8).

٥ / ٣٢٠ ح ١٦، والاستبصار: ٢ / 191 ح 2.
translation:
If intercourse occurs outside the vagina, you must offer a sacrificial camel, and you are not obliged to perform the Hajj the following year (1). If you engage with your spouse after entering into the state of Ihram but before declaring the intention to start, there is no penalty upon you (3).

The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) performed a ritual washing at Dhul-Hulaifa for Ihram, prayed, and then said (4): "Bring me your game meat." Two partridges were brought to him (5), and he ate them before entering the state of Ihram (6).

If you have a bondwoman (whom you have acknowledged as your child’s mother) (7), and she assumes Ihram before you do, you are allowed to annul her Ihram and engage with her if you wish (8).

1 - Source: Mustadrak, 9/291, Hadith 3. Similar narration in Al-Fiqh, 2/213, from his father's letter, and in Al-Kafi, 4/373, Hadith 3, and in Al-Tahdhib, 5/318, part of Hadith 10, and page 319, part of Hadith 11, and Al-Istibsar, 2/192, start of Hadith 1 and end of Hadith 2, with variations in wording, from which the references in Al-Wasa'il, 13/119, chapters on Expiations for Enjoyment, chapter 7, Hadith 1 and 2 are derived.

2 - The term “contracted” B.

3 - Source: Mustadrak, 9/287, Hadith 1. Similar in Al-Fiqh, 2/213, start of Hadith 1, and the references in Al-Wasa'il, 13/107, chapters on Expiations for Enjoyment, chapter 1, Hadith 2. Also in Al-Tahdhib, 5/82, Hadith 82, and Al-Istibsar, 2/188, Hadith 2 with slight variation in wording, from which the references in Al-Wasa'il, 12/433, chapters on Prohibitions of Ihram, chapter 11, Hadith 1 are derived.

4 - The variant "then stood up and then said" in A.

5 - The "hajl" is a known bird similar in size to a pigeon, with a red beak, also called a partridge, singular hajlah (Majma' al-Bahrain, 1/465, Hajl).

6 - Source: Mustadrak, 9/165, end of Hadith 1. Similar narration in Al-Fiqh, 2/208, Hadith 9, except it mentions "Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) performed the washing" instead of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), and in Al-Kafi, 4/330, Hadith 6, with slight variation in Al-Tahdhib, 5/83, Hadith 84, which are referenced in Al-Wasa'il, 12/335, chapters on Ihram, chapter 14, Hadith 6 and 7.

text:
ووضع عن النساء أربعا: الإجهار بالتلبية، والسعي بين الصفا والمروة، ودخول الكعبة، واستلام الحجر الأسود (1).
ولا بأس أن تلبي وأنت على غير طهر، وعلى كل حال (2).
ولا بأس أن تحرم في ثوب له علم (3).
وكل ثوب يصلى فيه فلا بأس أن تحرم فيه (4).
فإن كان عندك ثوب مصبوغ بالزعفران وأحببت أن تحرم فيه، فاغسله حتى يذهب ريحه ويضرب إلى البياض ثم أحرم فيه (5).
ولا بأس أن تحرم في ثوب مصبوغ ممشق (6) (7).

translation:
In relation to women, four things are not required: raising the voice during the Talbiyah, performing the Sa’i between Safa and Marwah, entering the Kaaba, and touching the Black Stone.

There is no issue with reciting the Talbiyah when you are not in a state of ritual purity, regardless of your situation.

It is permissible to enter Ihram wearing a garment with a pattern or decoration.

Any garment that can be used for prayer is also permissible for entering Ihram.

If you have a garment dyed with saffron and wish to enter Ihram in it, wash it until its smell is gone and it turns white, then wear it for Ihram.

There is no problem with entering Ihram in a garment dyed with ochre (red clay).

References: Various hadith collections and Islamic jurisprudence sources are noted as having similar statements, showing consistency across different texts and teachings on the subject.

وإذا أصاب ثوبك جنابة وأنت محرم فلا تلبسه حتى تغسله، وإحرامك تام (1).
ولا بأس أن تحرم في خميصة (2) سداها إبريسم ولحمتها من خز، إنما يكره الخالص منها (3).
ولا بأس أن تلبس الطيلسان (4) المزرور (5) وأنت محرم، وإنما كره أمير المؤمنين - عليه السلام - ذلك مخافة أن (6) يزره الجاهل عليه (7)، وأما الفقيه فلا بأس أن يلبسه (8).
وإن (9) اضطررت إلى لبس القباء وأنت محرم ولم تجد ثوبا غيره، فالبسه مقلوبا، ولا تدخل يديك في [يدي] (10) القباء (11).

translation:
If your garment becomes impure due to seminal discharge while you are in a state of Ihram, do not wear it until you wash it, and your Ihram remains valid. There is no harm in entering Ihram wearing a cloak whose warp is made of silk and whose weft is made of khaz (a fabric blend). However, pure silk is disliked. It is also permissible to wear a buttoned cloak while in Ihram. The Commander of the Faithful, peace be upon him, only disliked this because he feared that an ignorant person might button it up. As for a knowledgeable person, there is no harm in him wearing it. If you are compelled to wear a qabā’ (a type of robe) while in Ihram and you cannot find any other garment, then wear it inside out and do not put your arms through the sleeves of the qabā’.

ولا بأس أن يلبس المحرم الجوربين، والخفين، إذا اضطر إليهما (4).
ويكره أن ينام المحرم على الفراش الأصفر، والمرفقة (5).

translation:
If you wear a garment that is not suitable for Ihram attire, remove it and repeat your washing. If you wear a shirt, tear it and remove it from under your feet. It is permissible for a pilgrim in Ihram to wear socks and footwear if necessary. It is disliked for a pilgrim in Ihram to sleep on a yellow mattress or pillow. A pilgrim may carry weapons if he fears for his safety. Ihram should not be entered while wearing a woolen garment. It is permissible for the pilgrim to wear over his two garments any cloak or coat to keep warm.

ولا بأس أن تحرم في ثوب فيه حرير (1).
والمرأة تلبس ما شاءت من الثياب غير الحرير والقفازين (2)، ويكره (3) النقاب ولا بأس أن تسدل الثوب على وجهها إلى طرف الأنف قدر ما تبصر (4).
ولا تلبس المحرمة الحلي، ولا الثياب المصبغة (5) إلا صبغا لا يردع (6) (7).
وإن مر بها رجل استترت منه بثوبها، و لا تستتر بيدها من الشمس (8).
ولا بأس أن تلبس الخز (9) والقز (10).

translation:
It is permissible to enter the state of Ihram wearing a garment containing silk. A woman may wear any clothing she wishes except for silk and gloves. The wearing of a niqab is discouraged, but it is permissible for her to lower her garment over her face to the extent of her nose so that she can still see. A woman in Ihram should not wear jewelry or dyed clothes except those dyed with a color that does not leave a trace.

If a man passes by, she should cover herself with her garment but not shield herself from the sun with her hand. It is also permissible to wear garments made of mixed materials like khazz and qazz.

References:
1. These rulings are noted in classical texts such as "Qurb al-Isnad," "Al-Kafi," and "Al-Faqih," and are further elaborated in "Al-Wasa'il." Definitions of terms such as the gloves (quffaz) can be found in "Al-Qamus al-Muhit" and "Majma' al-Bahrain."
2. The discouragement of wearing the niqab is understood as a prohibition in the "Al-Wasa'il."
3. The permission to lower the garment is explained in sources like "Al-Mustadrak," "Al-Kafi," and "Al-Tahdhib," and mentioned in "Al-Istibsar."
4. The restriction on jewelry and dyed clothing is discussed in "Al-Mustadrak" and other sources like "Al-Kafi" and "Al-Tahdhib."
5. The permissibility of wearing garments made of khazz and qazz is also substantiated in these classical texts.

This translation preserves the religious and historical context of the practices associated with the Ihram state during Islamic rituals.

text:
ولا بأس أن تلبس المرأة القميص وتزر عليها، والديباج (1)، وتلبس المسك (2) والخلخالين (3)، ولا تتلثم (4).
ولا بأس أن تحرم في الذهب والفضة (5) (6).
ولا بأس أن تسدل الثوب على وجهها من أعلاه إلى النحر إذا كانت راكبة (7)، وتلبس السراويل وهي محرمة، لأنها تريد بذلك الستر (8).
ولا يجوز للمرأة أن تتنقب، لأن إحرام المرأة في وجهها، وإحرام الرجل في رأسه (9).

translation:
There is no objection to a woman wearing a shirt and buttoning it, silk (1), musk (2), and anklets (3), but she should not cover her face with a veil (4). It is also permissible for her to wear gold and silver (5) (6).

There is no issue with letting the garment hang over her face from the top to the chest when she is riding (7), and she may wear trousers while in ihram as she intends to maintain modesty (8). However, a woman is not permitted to wear the niqab, as a woman's ihram is related to her face, while a man's ihram is related to his head (9).

text:
وإياك أن تمس شيئا من الطيب وأنت محرم، ولا من الدهن، (واتق الطيب) (1) وامسك على أنفك من الريح الطيبة، ولا تمسك عليه (2) من الريح المنتنة، فإنه لا ينبغي للمحرم أن يتلذذ بريح طيبة، واتق الطيب في زادك، فمن ابتلي بشيء من ذلك فليعد غسله (3) وليتصدق بصدقة بقدر ما صنع، وإنما (يحرم عليك) (4) من الطيب أربعة أشياء: المسك، والعنبر، والورس (5)، والزعفران، غير أنه يكره للمحرم الأدهان الطيبة، إلا المضطر (6) إلى الزيت أو (7) شبهه، فلا بأس أن يتداوى به (8).
وإن أكلت زعفرانا متعمدا وأنت محرم أو طعاما فيه طيب، فعليك دم شاة، وإن كنت ناسيا فاستغفر الله، وتب إليه، ولا شيء عليك (9).
وكل من أكل طعاما لا ينبغي له أكله وهو محرم ساهيا، أو ناسيا، فلا شيء عليه، ومن فعله متعمدا فعليه دم (10)، كما ذكرناه (11).

translation:
Avoid touching any perfume while you are in a state of ihram, or any kind of oil. (Beware of perfume) and hold your nose against pleasant scents, but do not hold it against unpleasant odors, as it is not appropriate for someone in ihram to enjoy pleasant fragrances. Be mindful of any perfume in your provisions. If you are faced with any such situation, wash it off and give charity equivalent to what you used. There are four types of perfume that are prohibited for you: musk, amber, wars (a plant similar to sesame, found only in Yemen), and saffron. However, it is disliked for someone in ihram to use fragrant oils, unless there is a necessity for oil or something similar for medicinal purposes.

If you deliberately consume saffron while in ihram or food containing perfume, you must sacrifice a sheep. If you do so out of forgetfulness, then seek forgiveness from God, repent to Him, and there is no penalty on you.

Anyone who accidentally or mistakenly eats food that should not be consumed while in ihram has no penalty. However, if done deliberately, a sacrificial penalty is required, just as previously mentioned.

text:
ولا بأس أن تشم الإذخر (1) والقيصوم (2)، والخزامى (3)، والشيح (4)، وأشباهه وأنت محرم (5).
وإن أكلت خبيصا (6) فيه زعفران حتى شبعت منه وأنت محرم، فإذا فرغت من مناسكك وأردت الخروج من مكة، فابتع بدرهم تمرا وتصدق به، فيكون كفارة لذلك ولما دخل عليك في إحرامك مما لا تعلم (7).
وروي عن إسماعيل بن جابر أنه عرضت له ريح (8) في وجهه، من علة أصابته وهو محرم، فقال لأبي عبد الله - عليه السلام -: إن الطبيب يعالجني ووصف لي سعوطا (9) فيه مسك، قال - عليه السلام -: استعط به (10).
ولا (تنظر في (11) المرآة وأنت محرم) (12)، فإنه من الزينة (13).

translation:
You may smell plants like al-Izkhir, qaysoum, khuzama, and shih, and similar ones, without any issue while you are in the state of Ihram.

If you eat a dish called "khabis" that contains saffron until you are full while in the state of Ihram, and once you have completed your pilgrimage and intend to leave Mecca, then purchase dates worth a dirham and give them as charity. This will serve as an expiation for this and for anything that might have unintentionally happened during your Ihram that you are unaware of.

It is narrated from Ismail ibn Jabir that he had a wind ailment on his face while he was in Ihram. He spoke to Abu Abdullah - peace be upon him - saying: "The doctor is treating me and has prescribed a nasal medication containing musk." He - peace be upon him - replied: "Use it for treatment."

Also, do not look in the mirror while you are in Ihram, as it is considered a form of adornment.

text:
ولا بأس أن يكتحل المحرم إذا كان رمدا بكحل ليس فيه طيب (1).
ولا بأس أن يكتحل بصبر (2) ليس فيه زعفران، ولا ورس (3).
وروي: أنه لا بأس للمرأة أن تكتحل بالكحل كله، إلا كحل أسود لزينة (4).
ولا بأس أن يحتجم المحرم إذا خاف على نفسه، ولا يحلق قفاه (5).
وإذا خرجت (6) بالمحرم جروح، فلا بأس أن يتداوى بدواء فيه زعفران إذا كان ريح الأدوية غالبة على الزعفران، وإذا كانت (7) ريح الزعفران غالبة على الدواء، فلا يجوز أن يتداوى به (8).

translation:
It is permissible for a pilgrim in the state of ihram to apply kohl if they have an eye ailment, provided that the kohl does not contain any fragrance. Additionally, it is permissible to use aloe-based kohl that does not contain saffron or waras.

It is narrated that there is no objection to women using any type of kohl except black kohl for beautification purposes. 

A pilgrim may undergo cupping if they fear for their health, but they should not shave the back of their head.

If a pilgrim develops wounds, it is permissible to use a medication that contains saffron, provided that the scent of the medicine is stronger than that of the saffron. However, if the scent of the saffron is stronger, then it is not permissible to use that medication.

text:
ولا بأس أن يعصر المحرم الدمل ويربط عليه الخرقة (1)، وكذلك إذا كانت به شجة (2)، أو كانت في خده قروح، فلا بأس أن يداويها، ويعصبها بخرقة (3).
وإذا أذى المحرم ضرسه فلا بأس (أن يقلعه) (4) (5).
ولا يجوز للمحرم أن يركب في القبة، إلا أن يكون مريضا، (وأما النساء فلا بأس) (6) (7).
(ولا بأس) (8) أن تستظل المرأة وهي محرمة، ولا بأس أن يضرب على المحرم الظلال، ويتصدق بمد لكل يوم (9).
