translation: And it is permissible for the pilgrim in the state of Ihram to squeeze a boil and bandage it, as well as if he has a cut or has sores on his cheek; there is no harm in treating and bandaging them. If a pilgrim's tooth causes pain, there is no harm in extracting it. However, it is not allowed for a pilgrim in Ihram to ride in a shaded enclosure unless he is ill, though it is permissible for women. It is also permissible for a woman in Ihram to seek shade, and there is no harm in a pilgrim being shaded, but he should give alms equal to a mod (a specific measure) for each day.

text:
ولا بأس أن تضرب القبة على النساء، والصبيان، وهم محرمون (1).
ولا يرتمس المحرم في (2) الماء، ولا الصائم (3).
ولا بأس أن يظلل المحرم على محمله إذا كانت (4) به علة (5)، أو (6) خاف المطر (7).
وإذا (8) أصابه حر الشمس، وتأذى به، فلا بأس أن يستتر بطرف ثوبه، ما لم يصب رأسه (9).

translation:
It is permissible to pitch a tent for women and children who are in the state of ihram (1). It is not allowed for a person in ihram to fully immerse in water (2), nor for someone who is fasting (3). There is no issue for a person in ihram to be shaded in their carriage if they suffer from an ailment (4) or fear rain (7). If someone is afflicted by the sun's heat and is harmed by it, there is no harm in covering themselves with part of their garment, as long as it does not touch their head (9).

وروي: لا يتغطى (1) المحرم من البرد، والحر (2).
ولا بأس أن يمشي تحت ظل المحمل (3)، ولا بأس أن يضع ذراعيه على وجهه من حر الشمس (4).
وإذا غطى المحرم رأسه ساهيا أو ناسيا فليلق القناع وليلب، وليس عليه شي (5).
ولا بأس أن ينام المحرم على وجهه وهو على راحلته (6)، ولا بأس أن يمسح وجهه من الوضوء متعمدا (7).
وسئل أبو جعفر - عليه السلام - ما الفرق بين الفسطاط وبين ظل المحمل؟ فقال: لا ينبغي أن يستظل (8) في ظل المحمل، والفرق بينهما أن المرأة تطمث في

translation:
It is narrated: A person in the state of ihram should not cover themselves due to cold or heat. However, it is permissible to walk under the shade of a howdah, and there is no harm in placing one's arms on their face to protect from the sun's heat. If a person in ihram covers their head out of forgetfulness or unknowingly, they should remove the covering and make an intention, and there is nothing upon them. It is also permissible for a person in ihram to sleep on their face while on their mount, and there is no harm in intentionally wiping their face after ablution.

Abu Ja'far, peace be upon him, was asked about the difference between a tent and the shade of a howdah. He said: It is not appropriate to seek shade in the shade of the howdah, and the difference between them is that a woman experiences menstruation in the shade of the tent.

References in religious texts vary in expression but convey these legal rulings about the conduct during the state of ihram.

text:
شهر رمضان فتقضي الصيام ولا تقضي الصلاة، (قال (1): صدقت جعلت فداك) (2) (3).
قال مصنف هذا الكتاب: معناه أن السنة لا تقاس.
ولا بأس للمحرم أن يلبس الهميان (4) فيشد على بطنه المنطقة التي فيها نفقته (5).
ولا بأس أن يشد العمامة على بطنه، ولا يرفعها إلى صدره (6).
ولا بأس أن يضع المحرم عصام القربة على رأسه إذا استسقى (7) (8).
ولا يجوز للمحرم أن يعقد إزاره في عنقه (9).
وإذا قلم (10) المحرم (11) أظفاره فعليه في كل إصبع مد من طعام، فان هو قلم

translation:
Ramadan is a month in which fasting is obligatory but prayers missed during this time do not need to be made up. (He said: "You are right, may I be your ransom.")

The author of this book comments: This means that tradition is not subject to rational analogy.

There is no objection for a person in the state of ihram to wear a 'himyan' (a money pouch tied at the waist), securing the belt containing his money around his stomach. Additionally, there is no objection to securing a turban around his stomach, as long as it is not raised up to his chest. It is also permissible for a person in ihram to place a strap of a water bag on his head if he is fetching water.

However, it is prohibited for a person in ihram to tie his lower garment around his neck. If a person in ihram trims his nails, he must offer a measure of food for each finger. If he trims...

عشرتها (1) فعليه دم شاة، فان قلم أظفار يديه ورجليه جميعا في مجلس واحد فعليه (2) دم (3)، وإن كان فعله في مجلسين فعليه دمان (4)، وإن كان جاهلا أو ناسيا أو ساهيا، فلا شيء عليه (5).
وسئل أبو عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن المحرم تطول أظفاره، أو ينكسر بعضها فيؤذيه ذلك، قال: لا يقص منها شيئا إن استطاع، وإن كانت تؤذيه فليقصها وليطعم (6) مكان كل ظفر قبضة من طعام (7).
وإذا نتف الرجل إبطه بعد الاحرام فعليه دم (8).
ومر رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - على كعب ابن عجزة (9) الأنصاري والقمل يتناثر من رأسه

translation:
If one shortens it (1), they are required to sacrifice a sheep. If they trim the nails of both their hands and feet in one sitting, then (2) a sacrifice (3) is required. If done in two sittings, two sacrifices (4) are required. However, if it is done out of ignorance, forgetfulness, or inadvertence, there is no obligation (5).

Abu Abdullah - peace be upon him - was asked about a pilgrim whose nails become long, or if some nails break and cause harm. He said: Do not trim them if possible, but if they cause harm, trim them and give (6) a handful of food for each nail (7).

If a person plucks his armpit hair after entering the state of ihram, a sacrifice is required (8).

The Messenger of Allah - peace and blessings be upon him and his family - passed by Ka'b ibn Ujrah (9) the Ansari, and lice were falling from his head.

text:
وهو محرم، فقال له: أتؤذيك هوامك؟ قال: نعم، فأنزلت هذه الآية (فمن كان منكم مريضا أو به أذى من رأسه ففدية من صيام أو صدقة أو نسك (1)) فأمره رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - أن يحلق رأسه وجعل عليه (2) الصيام ثلاثة أيام، والصدقة على ستة مساكين لكل مسكين مدان، والنسك شاة. وكل شيء في القرآن بلفظ «أو» فصاحبه فيه (3) بالخيار (4).
وإذا عبث المحرم بلحيته فسقط منها شعرة أو ثنتان (5) فعليه أن يتصدق بكف (6) أو بكفين من طعام (7).
وإذا حككت رأسك فحكه حكا رفيقا، ولا تحك (8) بالأظفار ولكن بأطراف الأصابع (9).
والمحرم يلقي (10) عنه الدواب كلها إلا القملة فإنها من جسده، وإن (11) أحب أن يحول قملة من مكان إلى مكان فلا يضر (12).

translation:
When he was in a state of ihram, someone asked him, "Are your pests bothering you?" He replied, "Yes." Consequently, this verse was revealed: "And whoever among you is ill or has an ailment of the head must offer compensation through fasting, charity, or sacrifice" (Al-Baqarah: 196). The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) instructed him to shave his head and made it obligatory for him to compensate by fasting for three days, giving charity to six needy individuals by providing two handfuls of food to each, or offering a sacrifice of a sheep. Whenever the word "or" is used in the Quran, the individual has the option to choose between the alternatives.

If a person in ihram plays with his beard and a hair, or two, fall out, he must give charity equivalent to one or two handfuls of food. If you scratch your head, do so gently, and do not use your nails, but rather the tips of your fingers.

A person in ihram should remove all insects, except for lice as they are part of the body; if he wishes to move a louse from one place to another, there is no harm in that.

text:
وسئل الصادق - عليه السلام - يجوز للمحرم أن يحك رأسه أو يغتسل بالماء؟ فقال: يحك رأسه ما لم يتعمد قتل دابة، ولا بأس (1) أن (2) يغتسل بالماء ويصب على رأسه ما لم يكن ملبدا (3)، (فإن كان ملبدا فلا يفيض) (4) على رأسه الماء إلا من احتلام (5).
وسأل ابن سنان (6) أبا عبد الله - عليه السلام - فقال: إن (7) وجدت علي قرادا (8) أو (9) حلمة (10)، أطرحهما (11) عني وأنا محرم؟ فقال (12): نعم وصغارا لهما، إنهما رقيا في (13) غير مرقاهما (14).

translation:
Imam Al-Sadiq, peace be upon him, was asked if a person in the state of Ihram is allowed to scratch their head or wash with water. He replied: "One may scratch their head as long as they do not intentionally kill any living creature, and there is no harm in washing with water and pouring it over the head as long as the hair is not matted." (1) "If the hair is matted, one should not pour water over it, except in the case of a nocturnal emission." (2)

Ibn Sinan (3) asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him: "If I find ticks (4) or large ticks (5) on me while in a state of Ihram, should I remove them?" He replied: "Yes, you should remove them and deter them from climbing to places they are not meant to be." (6)

---

1. In the original text, the phrase "as long as the hair is not matted" is not present in some versions.
2. This exception applies specifically to instances of major ritual impurity.
3. Abdullah ibn Sinan was one of the companions of Imam Al-Sadiq, peace be upon him, mentioned by Shaykh in his book on companions.
4. The term "ticks" refers to small parasites similar to lice that affect animals.
5. The term "large ticks" refers to a larger version of these parasites.
6. This additional context is referenced in various Islamic jurisprudence sources.

ولا بأس أن يدخل المحرم الحمام ولكن لا يتدلك (1).
وليس للمحرم أن يتزوج ولا يزوج محلا، فان زوج أو تزوج فتزويجه باطل (2).
وإن ملك رجل بضع امرأة وهو محرم قبل أن يحل، فعليه أن يخلي سبيلها وليس نكاحه بشيء، فإذا أحل خطبها (إن شاء) (3)، (فان شاء) (4) أهلها زوجوه، وإن شاؤوا (5) لم يزوجوه (6).
وإذا تزوج المحرم امرأة فرق بينهما، ولها المهر إن كان دخل بها (7).
وإن وقع رجل على امرأة وكانا محرمين، فان كانا جاهلين فليس عليهما شيء وإن كانا عالمين فعلى كل واحد منهما بدنة (8)، وإن استكرهها فعليه بدنتان وليس

translation:
It is permissible for a person in the state of ihram to enter the bathhouse, but they should not scrub themselves.

A person in ihram is not allowed to marry or give someone else in marriage. If someone does marry or officiates a marriage, such a marriage is null and void.

If a man gains possession of a woman in marriage while he is in the state of ihram, he must release her, as his marriage holds no validity. Once he exits the state of ihram, he may propose to her if he wishes, and her family can choose either to marry her to him or not, as they wish.

If a person in ihram marries a woman, they should be separated. She would be entitled to the dowry if they consummated the marriage.

If a man has intimate relations with a woman while both are in ihram, and they were ignorant of the prohibition, there is no penalty on them. However, if they were aware, each of them owes a sacrificial offering of a cow. If he forced her, he owes two cows as a penalty.

text:
عليها شيء (1).
وسأل ابن مسلم (2) أبا عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن الرجل يحمل امرأة أو (3) يمسها، فأمنى أو أمذى، فقال:
إن (4) حملها أو مسها بشهوة، فأمنى أو لم يمن، أو أمذى أو لم يمذ، فعليه دم شاة يهريقه، وإن (حملها أو مسها) (5) بغير شهوة فليس عليه شيء أمنى (6) أو لم يمن (7).
وسأله أبو بصير عن رجل واقع امرأة وهو محرم، قال - عليه السلام -: عليه جزور كوماء (8)، فقال: لا يقدر، فقال (9): ينبغي لأصحابه أن يجمعوا له، ولا يفسدوا عليه (10) حجه (11).
وإن نظر محرم إلى غير أهله فأنزل فعليه جزور أو بقرة، وإن لم يقدر فشاة (12).

translation:
If there is no consequence upon it.

Ibn Muslim asked Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) about a man who carries a woman or touches her and then ejaculates or emits pre-ejaculatory fluid. Abu Abdullah replied: If he carries her or touches her with lust, whether he ejaculates or not, or emits pre-ejaculatory fluid or not, he must offer the sacrifice of a sheep. If he carries her or touches her without lust, then there is no obligation on him, whether he ejaculates or not.

Abu Basir asked him about a man who engages in intercourse with a woman while in a state of ihram (sacred state during pilgrimage), and he (peace be upon him) said: He must offer a fat camel. Abu Basir said: What if he cannot afford it? He (peace be upon him) replied: His companions should contribute for him, and they should not spoil his pilgrimage.

If someone in a state of ihram looks at someone who is not among his relatives and ejaculates, he must offer a camel or a cow. If he cannot afford this, then he must offer a sheep.

text:
وإن نظر المحرم إلى المرأة (1) نظر شهوة فليس عليه شيء (2)، فان لمسها فعليه دم شاة، فان قبلها فعليه بدنة (3)، [وروي أن عليه دم شاة] (4).
وإن أتى المحرم أهله ناسيا فلا شيء عليه، إنما هو بمنزلة من أكل في شهر رمضان وهو ناس (5).
وسأل أبو بصير أبا عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن رجل محرم نظر إلى ساق امرأة (6)، أو إلى فرجها فأمنى، فقال: إن كان موسرا فعليه بدنة، وإن كان وسطا فعليه بقرة، وإن كان فقيرا فعليه شاة، وقال: إني لم أجعل عليه هذا لأنه أمنى، ولكن جعلته عليه لأنه نظر إلى ما لا يحل له (7) (8).

translation:
If a person in a state of ihram looks at a woman with lust, there is nothing upon him. However, if he touches her, he must sacrifice a sheep. If he kisses her, he must sacrifice a camel, although it is narrated that he must also sacrifice a sheep.

If a person in a state of ihram is intimate with his wife out of forgetfulness, there is no penalty on him; he is in the same position as someone who eats during Ramadan out of forgetfulness.

Abu Basir asked Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) about a man in ihram who looked at a woman's leg or her private parts and subsequently ejaculated. Abu Abdullah replied: If the man is wealthy, he must sacrifice a camel; if he is of moderate means, a cow; and if he is poor, a sheep. He clarified that this penalty is not because he ejaculated but rather because he looked at something forbidden.

References to the sources indicate various mentions and narrations of these rulings across different collections of Islamic legal texts.

text:
ومن واقع امرأته دون المزدلفة وقبل أن يأتي المزدلفة فعليه الحج من قابل (1).
والقارن إذا أحصر (2) وقد اشترط وقال (3): حلني حيث حبستني، فلا يبعث بهديه (4) ولا يستمتع من قابل ولكن يدخل في مثل ما خرج منه (5)، ولا يحل حتى يبلغ الهدي محله، فإذا بلغ الهدي محله أحل وانصرف إلى منزله (6)، وعليه الحج من قابل (7).
والمحصور والمضطر ينحران (8) بدنتيهما في المكان الذي يضطران فيه، وقد فعل رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - ذلك يوم الحديبية حين رد المشركون بدنته (9)، وأبوا أن (يذبحوها مبلغ) (10) النحر (11)، فأمر بها فنحرت مكانه (12).
وقال أبو عبد الله - عليه السلام -: المحصور غير المصدود، (وقال - عليه السلام -: المحصور) (13) هو المريض، والمصدود هو (14) الذي يرده المشركون كما ردوا رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله وسلم وأصحابه (15) ليس من مرض، والمصدود تحل له النساء، والمحصور

Certainly! Here is the translated text:

---

If a man has sexual relations with his wife before reaching Muzdalifah, he is required to perform Hajj again the following year.

For the one performing Qiran (Hajj combined with Umrah) who is prevented (2) and has stipulated by saying (3): "Release me where you have prevented me," he should not send his sacrificial animal (4) nor enjoy the privileges of entering Mecca the following year, but he should enter into a similar state to the one he had left (5), and he should not exit the state of Ihram until the sacrificial animal reaches its rightful place. Once the animal has reached its designated place, he is released from Ihram and can return home (6), and he is obligated to perform Hajj the following year (7).

As for the person prevented by illness or other reasons, they slaughter their sacrificial animal (8) at the location where they are prevented, just as the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) did on the day of Hudaybiyyah, when the polytheists prevented him from sacrificing his animal (9). They refused to let the animals reach the place of sacrifice (10), so he ordered that they be sacrificed at that place (12).

Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) said: The prevented (maḥṣūr) is different from the obstructed (maṣdūd). (He said, peace be upon him: The prevented (13) is the one who is ill, while the obstructed (14) is the one whom the polytheists turn back, as they did with the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) and his companions (15) without illness. Women are permissible for the obstructed, but not for the prevented.

وسأل سماعة أبا عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن رجل أحصر في الحج، قال - عليه السلام -: فليبعث بهديه إذا كان مع أصحابه، ومحله أن يبلغ الهدي محله، ومحله (2) منى يوم النحر إذا كان في حج، وإن كان في عمرة نحر بمكة، وإنما عليه أن يعدهم لذلك يوما، فإذا كان ذلك اليوم فقد وفى، وإن (3) اختلفوا في الميعاد لم يضره إن شاء الله (4).

translation:
He is not permitted (1).
Sama'a asked Abu Abdullah - peace be upon him - about a man who was prevented from completing the pilgrimage. He - peace be upon him - said: He should send his sacrificial animal if he is with his companions, and its place of ritual is to reach its designated area, which, for the pilgrimage, is Mina on the Day of Sacrifice. If he is on an Umrah, it should be slaughtered in Mecca. He only needs to assign them a specific day for this. Once that day arrives, he has fulfilled his duty, and if they disagree on the timing, it will not harm him, God willing (4).

If you have entered into the state of Ihram, refrain from killing any animals except the snake, scorpion, and mouse. As for the mouse, it can ruin leather water containers (5) and cause fires (6) in people's homes (7). Regarding the scorpion, the Prophet of God (8) - may peace and blessings be upon him and his family - extended his hand to a stone, and a scorpion stung him. He - may peace and blessings be upon him - said: "May God curse you, neither leaving the pious nor the wicked alone." If a snake intends to harm you, kill it, but if it does not intend to, do not harm it. As for the rabid dog (10) and wild beast, if they intend to harm you, kill them; if they do not intend to (11), do not harm them (12). The great black snake (13) known for treachery (14).

Kill it no matter what, and throw the raven and the kite (1) onto the back of your camel (2). If the wolf intends to kill you, then kill it (3). When a wild beast confronts you, avoid it, but if it insists, kill it if you can (4). If confronted by thieves, defend yourself against them (5). If a pilgrim kills an ostrich or a wild donkey, he must offer a blood sacrifice, and if he cannot, he should feed sixty needy people. If he cannot afford charity (8), he should fast for eighteen days.

translation:
If someone hits a cow, they must offer a cow. If they cannot, they should feed thirty needy people. If they cannot do this, they should fast for nine days. 

If someone hits a gazelle, they must offer a sheep. If they cannot afford it, they must feed ten needy people. If they cannot do this, they should fast for three days.

If a person in the state of ihram throws at a gazelle and hits its leg causing it to limp, and it still walks and grazes, then there is nothing on them. However, if it goes away without any clear outcome, they must atone for it, as its fate is uncertain and it might have perished. If they intentionally caused harm, they have to atone and bear the sin.

For a fox or a rabbit, the atonement is a sheep.

وإذا وجبت على الرجل بدنة في كفارة ولم يجدها فعليه سبع شياة، فإن لم يقدر صام ثمانية عشر يوما بمكة أو في منزله (1).
وإذا قتل المحرم نعامة فعليه بدنة، فإن لم يجد فاطعام ستين مسكينا، فإن كان قيمة البدنة أكثر من إطعام ستين مسكينا لم يزد على إطعام ستين مسكينا (2).
وإن قتل حمامة من حمام الحرم خارجا من الحرم فعليه شاة، فان قتلها في الحرم وهو (3) حلال فعليه ثمنها، وإن قتل فرخا من فراخ الحرم، فعليه حمل (4) قد فطم (5).

translation:
If a man is obligated to offer a camel as expiation and he cannot find one, then he must offer seven sheep. If he is unable to do that, he should fast for eighteen days either in Mecca or at his home (1).

If a person in a state of ihram kills an ostrich, he must offer a camel. If he cannot, he should feed sixty needy people. If the value of the camel is higher than the cost of feeding sixty needy people, he should not exceed feeding sixty (2).

If someone kills a pigeon from the sacred pigeons outside the sanctuary, he must offer a sheep. If he kills it within the sanctuary and he is not in a state of ihram, he must pay its value. If he kills a chick from the sanctuary's chicks, he must offer a young sheep (4) that has been weaned (5).

If someone kills a sandgrouse (6), he must offer a weaned lamb that has grazed on trees (7).

وإذا أصاب المحرم بيض نعام، ذبح عن كل بيضة شاة بقدر عدد البيض، فإن لم يجد شاة فعليه صيام ثلاثة أيام، فإن لم يقدر فإطعام عشرة مساكين (1).
وإذا وطئ بيض نعام ففدغها (2) وهو محرم فعليه أن يرسل الفحل من الإبل على قدر عدد البيض، فما لقح وسلم حتى ينتج كان النتاج هديا بالغ الكعبة (3).
فان وطئ بيض قطاة فشدخه (4) فعليه أن يرسل الفحل من الغنم في مثل (5) عدة البيض كما يرسل الفحل في عدة البيض من الإبل (6).
وما وطأت أو وطأه بعيرك وأنت محرم فعليك فداؤه (7).
واعلم أنه ليس عليك (8) فداء شيء أتيته وأنت جاهل به وأنت محرم في حجك ولا في (9) عمرتك، إلا الصيد فإن عليك (فيه الفداء) (10) بجهالة كان،

translation:
If a person in the state of ihram (a sacred state for Hajj or Umrah) encounters ostrich eggs, they must sacrifice a sheep for each egg equivalent to the number of eggs. If unable to find a sheep, they must fast for three days, and if that is still not possible, feed ten needy people.

If one accidentally damages ostrich eggs while in ihram, they must send a male camel to impregnate female camels equivalent to the number of eggs; once the offspring are born, they are to be sent as an offering to the Kaaba.

If one breaks the eggs of a sandgrouse while in ihram, they must send a male sheep to mate with females, equivalent to the number of broken eggs, similarly as with the camels for ostrich eggs.

If a person or their camel damages any eggs while they are in ihram, they are liable to make amends for it.

However, if one unknowingly commits such acts while in ihram during Hajj or Umrah, there is no penalty except in the case of hunting, where recompense is required regardless of whether it was done knowingly or unknowingly.

أو تعمد (1)، فان أصبته وأنت حلال (2) في الحرم فعليك الفداء مضاعفا (3).
وإن قتلت طيرا وأنت محرم في غير الحرم فعليك دم شاة، وليس عليك قيمته لأنه ليس في الحرم (4).
وإن اشترى رجل لرجل بيض نعام (5) فأكله المحرم، فعلى المحل (6) الجزاء قيمة البيض لكل بيضة درهم، وعلى المحرم لكل بيضة شاة (7).
وفي الحمامة درهم إذا أصابها المحل، وفي الفرخ نصف درهم، وفي البيضة ربع درهم (8).

translation:
If you intentionally (1), and if you hit it while you are lawful (2) in the Haram, then you must pay a doubled compensation (3). If you kill a bird while you are in the state of Ihram but outside the Haram, you are required to compensate with the blood of a sheep, and you are not liable for its value because it wasn't in the Haram (4). If a man buys ostrich eggs (5) for another man and the person in Ihram eats them, the person who is lawful (6) must pay the value of the eggs, which is one dirham per egg, and the person in Ihram must sacrifice a sheep for each egg (7). For a pigeon, it is one dirham if the lawful person gets it, for a chick half a dirham, and for an egg a quarter of a dirham (8).

وإن أصاب محل صيدا فأتى به رجلا محرما، فلا يجوز أن يأكل منه (١) (٢).
وإذا اضطر المحرم إلى صيد وميتة فإنه يأكل الصيد ويفدي (٣).
[وقد روي في حديث آخر أنه يأكل الميتة، لأنها قد أحلت له، ولم يحل له الصيد] (٤).
وإذا قتل المحرم الصيد فعليه جزاؤه، ويتصدق بالصيد على مسكين، فان عاد فقتل صيدا آخر لم يكن عليه جزاؤه (٥)، وينتقم الله منه في الآخرة، وهو قول الله عز وجل: ﴿ومن عاد فينتقم الله منه﴾ (6) (7).

translation:
If a person in the state of Ihram is given game that was hunted by someone else, they are not permitted to eat it. If a person in Ihram has no choice but to choose between consuming game or carrion, they should eat the game and offer a compensation. However, according to another narration, they should eat the carrion because it is permissible for them, while hunting is not. 

If a person in Ihram kills game, they are liable for its compensation and should give the game in charity to a poor person. If they repeatedly kill game, they are not liable for further compensation, for God will punish them in the Hereafter. This aligns with God Almighty's statement: "And whoever returns [to it], God will avenge Himself on him." (Quran 5:95)

text:
ولا بأس أن يصيد المحرم السمك، ويأكل طريه ومالحه ويتزوده (1).
وإن قتل جرادة فعليه تمرة، وتمرة خير من جرادة (2)، فإن كان كثيرا فعلية دم شاة (3).
ومر أبو جعفر - عليه السلام - على أناس (4) يأكلون جرادا وهم محرمون، فقال: سبحان الله، وأنتم محرمون؟ قالوا: إنما هو صيد البحر، فقال لهم: إرمسوه في الماء (5) إذا (6) (7).
فان قتل عظاية فعليه أن يتصدق بكف من طعام (8).

translation:
It is permissible for a pilgrim in a state of Ihram to catch fish and eat it, whether fresh or salted, and to use it as provisions. If a grasshopper is killed, a date must be offered as compensation, as a date is worth more than a grasshopper. If many grasshoppers are killed, a sheep must be sacrificed.

When Imam Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him) passed by people who were eating grasshoppers while in the state of Ihram, he exclaimed, "Glory be to God, and you are in the state of Ihram?" They replied, "It is only sea game," to which he responded, "Then immerse it in water."

If one kills a lizard, they must give a handful of food in charity.

References to this can be found in various sources such as Al-Kafi, Al-Tahdhib, Al-Istibsar, and others, indicating the significance and variations in wording across different texts. The importance of respecting the regulations of Ihram is highlighted, emphasizing the need for atonement when these rules are violated.

وإن قتل زنبورا خطأ فلا شيء عليه، وإن كان عمدا فعليه أن يتصدق بكف من طعام (1).
وإن أصاب المحرم صيدا خارجا من الحرم فذبحه، ثم أدخله الحرم (2) مذبوحا وأهدى إلى رجل محل، فلا بأس أن يأكل (3)، إنما الفداء على الذي أصابه (4).
وسئل الصادق - عليه السلام - عن المحرم يصيب الصيد فيفديه، يطعمه أو يطرحه؟ قال: إذا يكون عليه فداء آخر، قيل: فأي شيء يصنع به؟ قال: يدفنه (5).
وكل من وجب عليه فداء شيء أصابه وهو محرم، فإن كان حاجا نحر هديه الذي يجب عليه بمنى، وإن كان معتمرا نحره بمكة قبالة (6) الكعبة (7).
فان قتل محرم فرخا في غير الحرم فعليه حمل، وليس عليه قيمة، لأنه ليس في الحرم (8)، ويذبح الفداء إن شاء في منزله بمكة وإن شاء بالحزورة (9) بين الصفا والمروة،

translation:
If someone accidentally kills a hornet, there is nothing required of him, but if done intentionally, he must give a handful of food in charity (1).

If a person in a state of ihram (ritual consecration) kills game outside the sacred precincts (haram) and then brings it into the haram after slaughtering it, and gives it as a gift to a person who is not in ihram, it is permissible for that person to eat it (3); however, compensation is required from the one who hunted it (4).

Imam al-Sadiq, peace be upon him, was asked about a pilgrim in ihram who hunts an animal and must offer expiation; should he eat it or discard it? He replied: If he does, another expiation would be required. It was asked: So what should be done with it? He said: It should be buried (5).

For anyone obliged to offer expiation for something hunted while in ihram, if he is performing Hajj, he should sacrifice the animal in Mina, and if he is performing Umrah, he should sacrifice it opposite the Kaaba in Mecca (7).

If a consecrated pilgrim kills a bird chick outside the haram, he is required to offer a sheep as expiation, but not its monetary value, since it was not within the haram (8), and he may slaughter the expiation either at his home in Mecca or at Hajarat (between Safa and Marwa) (9).

قريب من موضع النخاسين (1) وهو معروف (2).
فإذا بلغت الحرم فاغتسل من بئر ميمون (3) أو من فخ (4)، وإن اغتسلت بمكة (5) فلا بأس (6).
فإذا نظرت إلى بيوت مكة فاقطع التلبية، وحدها عقبة المدنيين أو بحذاها، ومن أخذ على طريق المدينة قطع التلبية إذا نظر إلى عريش مكة، وهي عقبة ذي طوى (7) (8).
وعليك بالتكبير والتهليل والتحميد (9) والتسبيح والصلاة على

translation:
Close to the area of the slave traders, it is well-known. When you reach the sanctuary, perform a ritual wash from the well of Maimun or from Fakh. If you perform the wash in Mecca, there is no harm. When you see the houses of Mecca, cease the talbiyah at the pass of the Madaniyyin or near it. And those who take the route from Medina should stop the talbiyah when they see the Arish of Mecca, which is the pass of Dhu Tuwa.

Engage in the magnification, declaration of God's oneness, praise, and glorification, and send prayers upon the Prophet.

text:
النبي - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - (1).
فإذا أردت أن تدخل المسجد فادخل من باب بني شيبة (2) بالسكينة والوقار وأنت حاف، فإنه من دخله (3) بخشوع غفر له، وقل وأنت على باب المسجد: السلام عليك أيها النبي ورحمة الله وبركاته، بسم الله وبالله ومن الله وما شاء الله، والسلام على أنبياء الله ورسله، والسلام على رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -، والسلام على إبراهيم - عليه السلام -، والحمد لله رب العالمين.
فإذا دخلت المسجد فانظر إلى الكعبة وقل: الحمد لله الذي عظمك وشرفك وكرمك، وجعلك مثابة للناس (4) وأمنا مباركا وهدى للعالمين.
ثم ارفع يديك وقل: اللهم إني أسألك في مقامي هذا في أول مناسكي أن تقبل توبتي، وتجاوز عن خطيئتي، وتضع عني وزري.
الحمد لله الذي بلغني بيته الحرام، اللهم إني أشهد أن هذا بيتك الحرام، الذي جعلته مثابة للناس وأمنا مباركا وهدى للعالمين (5).
ثم انظر إلى الحجر الأسود وارفع يديك، واحمد الله واثن عليه، وصل على النبي وآله (6)، واسأله (7) أن يتقبله منك.

translation:
The Prophet - peace and blessings be upon him and his family -

When you wish to enter the mosque, enter through the Bani Shaybah Gate with tranquility and dignity, barefoot. For whoever enters it with humility shall be forgiven. As you stand at the entrance of the mosque, say: "Peace be upon you, O Prophet, and the mercy of Allah and His blessings. In the name of Allah, and by Allah, and from Allah, and whatever Allah wills. Peace be upon the prophets of Allah and His messengers. Peace be upon the Messenger of Allah - peace and blessings be upon him and his family. Peace be upon Ibrahim - peace be upon him. All praise is due to Allah, the Lord of the worlds."

Upon entering the mosque, look at the Kaaba and say: "Praise be to Allah, who has exalted and honored you, who has made you a point of reference for people, a place of peace, a blessing, and a guidance for the worlds."

Then raise your hands and say: "O Allah, I ask You at this place, for the beginning of my rituals, to accept my repentance, forgive my sins, and relieve me of my burdens. Praise be to Allah who has granted me access to His sacred house. O Allah, I testify that this is Your sacred house, which You have made a point of reference for people, a place of peace, a blessing, and a guidance for the worlds."

Then look towards the Black Stone and raise your hands, praise Allah, extol Him, invoke blessings upon the Prophet and his family, and ask Him to accept it from you.

text:
ثم استلم الحجر وقبله، فإن لم تقدر عليه فامسحه بيدك اليمنى وقبلها، فإن لم تقدر فأشر إليه بيدك وقل (1): اللهم (2) أمانتي أديتها، وميثاقي تعاهدته، لتشهد (3) لي بالموافاة، آمنت بالله، وكفرت بالجبت والطاغوت واللات والعزى، وعبادة الشياطين، وعبادة الأوثان، وعبادة كل ند يدعى من دون الله، فإن لم تستطع أن تقول هذا كله فبعضه (4).
وتقول وأنت في طوافك: اللهم إني أسألك باسمك الذي يمشى به على طلل الماء (5) كما يمشى به على جدد الأرض، وأسألك باسمك المخزون (المكنون عندك، وأسألك باسمك) (6) الذي يهتز له العرش، وأسألك باسمك الذي تهتز له أقدام ملائكتك، وأسألك باسمك الذي دعاك به موسى - عليه السلام - من جانب الطور الأيمن فاستجبت له وألقيت عليه محبة منك، وأسألك باسمك الذي غفرت به لمحمد - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - ما تقدم من ذنبه وما تأخر، وأتممت عليه نعمتك، أن تفعل بي كذا وكذا (7).
فإذا بلغت مقابل الميزاب، فقل: اللهم اعتق رقبتي من النار، وادرأ (8) عني

translation:
After receiving and kissing the Black Stone, if you are unable to do so, then touch it with your right hand and kiss your hand. If you cannot touch it, then gesture towards it with your hand and say: "O Allah, I have fulfilled my trust and adhered to my covenant, so let it bear witness for me to that. I believe in Allah, and reject idols, false deities, Al-Lat and Al-Uzza, the worship of devils, idols, and every rival that is worshiped besides Allah.” If you are unable to say all of this, say part of it.

While circumambulating, say: "O Allah, I ask You by Your name by which You walk on the surface of water as You walk on the paths of the earth. I ask You by Your hidden and treasured name, and by Your name that causes the Throne to tremble, and by Your name that causes the feet of Your angels to quiver, and by Your name by which Moses - peace be upon him - called You from the right side of the mountain and You responded to him and cast Your love upon him. I ask You by Your name by which You forgave Muhammad - peace and blessings be upon him and his family - for his past and future sins, and completed Your favor upon him, to do so and so for me.”

When you reach opposite the Mizab (the water spout of the Kaaba), say: "O Allah, free my neck from the Fire, and protect me from it."

text:
شر فسقة العرب والعجم، وشر فسقة الجن والانس (1).
فإذا بلغت الركن اليماني فالتزمه (2)، وصل على النبي - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - في كل شوط (3).
وقل بين هذا الركن والركن الذي فيه الحجر: ربنا آتنا في الدنيا حسنة وفي الآخرة حسنة وقنا برحمتك عذاب النار (4).
فإذا كنت في الشوط السابع، فقم بالمستجار وتعلق بأستار الكعبة، وهو مؤخر الكعبة مما يلي الركن اليماني بحذاء باب الكعبة، وابسط يديك (5) على البيت والصق خدك وبطنك بالبيت، ثم قل: اللهم البيت بيتك، والعبد عبدك، وهذا مقام العائذ بك من النار.
ثم (استلم الركن اليماني، ثم) (6) استلم الركن الذي فيه الحجر واختم به، وقل: اللهم قنعني بما رزقتني، وبارك لي فيما آتيتني إنك على كل شيء قدير (7).
ثم ائت مقام إبراهيم - عليه السلام - فصل ركعتين، واقرأ فيهما (الحمد) و (قل يا أيها الكافرون) و (قل هو الله أحد).

translation:
Evil exists among the sinners of both Arabs and non-Arabs, and among the sinners of both jinn and humans.

When you reach the Yemeni Corner (of the Kaaba), adhere to it and send blessings upon the Prophet (peace be upon him and his family) in every circuit. Between this corner and the corner that contains the Black Stone, say: "Our Lord, grant us good in this world and good in the Hereafter, and protect us by Your mercy from the punishment of the Fire."

When you are in the seventh circuit, stand at Al-Multazam and cling to the curtain of the Kaaba, which is at the back of the Kaaba aligned with the Yemeni Corner, opposite the door of the Kaaba. Spread your hands on the house, press your cheek and belly against it, and then say: "O Allah, the house is Your house, and the servant is Your servant, and this is the place of one who seeks refuge with You from the Fire."

Then, touch the Yemeni Corner, and afterwards, touch the corner that contains the Black Stone, concluding with it. Say: "O Allah, satisfy me with what You have provided for me and bless what You have given me, for You are capable of all things."

Then proceed to the Station of Ibrahim (peace be upon him) and perform two units of prayer, reciting in them Surah Al-Fatiha, Surah Al-Kafirun, and Surah Al-Ikhlas.

text:
ثم تشهد، ثم احمد الله واثن عليه، وصل على النبي - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -، واسأله (1) أن يتقبله (2) منك، فهاتان الركعتان هما الفريضة، ليس يكره لك أن تصليهما في أي الساعات شئت، عند طلوع الشمس أو عند غروبها (3)، ما لم يكن وقت صلاة مكتوبة، وإن دخل عليك وقت صلاة مكتوبة فابدأ بها، ثم صل ركعتي الطواف (4).
ثم تقوم فتأتي الحجر الأسود (5) فتقبله أو (6) تستلمه أو تومئ إليه فإنه لابد لك من ذلك.
فان قدرت أن تشرب من ماء زمزم قبل أن تخرج إلى الصفا فافعل، وتقول حين تشرب: اللهم اجعله لي علما نافعا، ورزقا واسعا، وشفاء من كل داء وسقم، إنك قادر يا رب العالمين (7).
ثم (8) اخرج إلى الصفا، وقم عليه حتى تستقبل (9) وتنظر (10) إلى البيت،

translation:
Then testify, then praise Allah and commend Him, and send blessings upon the Prophet—peace and blessings be upon him and his family. Pray and ask Him to accept them from you. These two units of prayer are obligatory, and there is no dislike for you to perform them at any time of the day you wish, whether at sunrise or sunset, as long as it is not during the time of an obligatory prayer. If the time for an obligatory prayer arrives, then begin with it, and after that, perform the two units of circumambulation prayer.

Then proceed to the Black Stone, kiss it, or touch it, or gesture towards it, for you must do this. If you can drink from the water of Zamzam before going to Safa, then do so. While drinking, say: "O Allah, let it be for me beneficial knowledge, ample sustenance, and a cure from every disease and ailment, for verily, You are capable, O Lord of the worlds."

Then head to Safa, and stand upon it, facing and looking towards the House (the Kaaba).

text:
وتستقبل الركن الذي فيه الحجر الأسود، واحمد الله واثن عليه، وقل: لا إله إلا الله وحده لا شريك له، له الملك وله الحمد، يحيي ويميت، وهو على كل شيء قدير، ثلاث مرات (1).
ثم انحدر عن الصفا وأنت كاشف عن ظهرك وقل (2): يا رب العفو، يا من أمرنا بالعفو، (يا من هو أولى بالعفو، يا من يحب العفو، يا من يثيب على العفو) (3) العفو العفو العفو (4)، (يا جواد (5)، يا كريم، يا قريب، يا بعيد، أردد علي نعمتك، واستعملني بطاعتك ومرضاتك) (6) (7).
ثم انحدر ماشيا، وعليك السكينة والوقار حتى تأتي المنارة، وهي طرف المسعى (8)، فهرول واسع ملء فروجك (9) وقل: بسم الله والله أكبر، اللهم (صل على محمد وآل محمد، اللهم) (10) اغفر وارحم، وتجاوز عما تعلم، إنك أنت الأعز الأكرم، حتى تجوز زقاق العطارين، وتقول إذا جاوزت المسعى (11): يا ذا المن والفضل والكرم النعماء (12) (والجود، صل على محمد وآل محمد) (13)، واغفر لي ذنوبي إنه (14) لا يغفر الذنوب إلا أنت.

translation:
Approach the corner where the Black Stone is located, and praise and thank God, saying: "There is no god but Allah, alone with no partner, to Him belongs the dominion and all praise; He gives life and causes death, and He has power over all things," three times.

Then, descend from Al-Safa while revealing your back and say: "O Lord, grant forgiveness, O the One who commands us to forgive, (O You who are more worthy of forgiving, O You who love forgiveness, O You who reward for forgiveness) forgive, forgive, forgive. O the Generous, O the Noble, O the Near, O the Distant, restore Your blessing upon me, and guide me in obedience and pleasing You."

Then, continue walking with calmness and dignity until you reach the minaret, which is at the edge of the path, then walk briskly and energetically. Say: "In the name of Allah, Allah is the Greatest, O Allah, (bless Muhammad and his family, O Allah) forgive and have mercy, pardon what You are aware of, for You are the most honored and most generous," until you pass by the spice market. Once you have passed the path, say: "O Possessor of bounty, grace, generosity, and benevolence, (bless Muhammad and his family) and forgive my sins, for none forgives sins except You."

text:
ثم امش (1) وعليك السكينة والوقار حتى تأتي المروة، وتصعد عليها حتى يبدو لك البيت، واصنع عليها مثل (2) ما صنعت على الصفا، فإذا بلغت حد زقاق العطارين فاسع ملء فروجك إلى المنارة الأولى التي (3) تلي الصفا، وطف بينهما سبعة أشواط تبدأ بالصفا وتختم بالمروة (4).
ثم قصر من رأسك من جوانبه ومن حاجبيك، وخذ من شاربك، وقلم أظفارك وابق منها لحجك (5)، فإذا فعلت ذلك فقد أحللت من كل شيء أحرمت منه، وطف بالبيت تطوعا ما شئت (6).
وإن طفت بالبيت وبالصفا والمروة وقد تمتعت، ثم عجلت فقبلت أهلك قبل (7) أن تقصر من رأسك فإن عليك دما تهريقه، وإن جامعت فعليك جزور أو بقرة (8)، وإن كنت جاهلا فلا شيء عليك (9).

translation:
Walk with calmness and dignity until you reach Al-Marwah. Ascend it until the Kaaba is visible to you, and do upon it as you did upon Al-Safa. When you reach the end of the Perfume Sellers' Alley, hasten between Al-Safa and Al-Marwah, making seven circuits, starting at Al-Safa and ending at Al-Marwah.

Then, trim some from your hair on all sides, including your eyebrows, take some from your mustache, and clip your nails, leaving some for your Hajj. If you have done this, you have exited from all prohibitions of Ihram, and you may perform voluntary Tawaf around the Kaaba as you wish.

If you have completed Tawaf of the Kaaba, and of Al-Safa and Al-Marwah, and have taken pleasure, then you hastened and approached your spouse before trimming your hair, you are required to donate an animal for sacrifice. If you have engaged in intercourse, you must offer a camel or a cow. If you were ignorant of the law, no penalty is upon you.

text:
وإن نسي المتمتع التقصير حتى يهل بالحج فإن عليه دما يهريقه (1).
وروي يستغفر الله (2).
وإن عقص (3) رجل رأسه وهو متمتع، فقدم مكة وحل عقاص رأسه وقصر وأحل (4) وأدهن، فإن عليه دم شاة (5).
وإن تمتع رجل بالعمرة إلى الحج، فدخل مكة فطاف (6) وسعى ولبس ثيابه وأحل، ونسي أن يقصر حتى خرج إلى عرفات، فلا بأس به يبني على العمرة وطوافها، وطواف الحج على أثره (7).
وإن أراد المتمتع أن يقصر فحلق رأسه فإن عليه دما يهريقه، فإذا كان يوم

---

Sacrificing is commanded with a razor upon one's head when intending to shave (1).

It is narrated: If a person performing 'Tamattu' accidentally shaves their head in Mecca, there is no penalty if they were ignorant or forgetful. However, if one deliberately does so during the first thirty days from the start of the pilgrimage month, there is no penalty. If it is done deliberately after these thirty days, during which the hair should be left to grow for the pilgrimage, a sacrificial blood offering must be made (4).

A man asked Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) saying: Once I completed the rites of Umrah, I went to my family without trimming my hair. He replied: You owe a sacrificial animal. The man responded, "When I intended to do so, and she hadn't trimmed her hair, she resisted. But when I overpowered her, she bit off some of her hair with her teeth." Abu Abdullah said: "May God have mercy on her, she was more wise than you. You owe a sacrificial animal and she owes nothing (7)."

And if you arrive in Mecca with your Ihram intact, perform the shortened prayer as long as you remain in the state of Ihram (9). When you enter the two sanctuaries, intend to stay for ten days and perform the complete prayer (10).

English Translation:

---

One should not enter Mecca without being in a state of ihram (sacred state for pilgrimage), except for someone who has a specific need or is experiencing severe discomfort.

If a man enters Mecca once, twice, or three times in a year, whenever he enters, he should pronounce the talbiyah (pilgrimage invocation), and whenever he exits, he may release himself from ihram.

When a pilgrim performing the tamattu' (enjoyment) pilgrimage has completed his rituals and needs to leave for another purpose, he should perform a ritual bath (ghusl) for entering a state of ihram again and declare his intention for Hajj before setting out for his task. If he is unable to return to Mecca, he should proceed to Arafat.

If he needs to go to places like Usfan, Ta'if, or Dhat Arq, he should leave in a state of ihram, announcing his intention for Hajj upon entry, and remain in this state until his return. If he returns to Mecca, he returns in a state of ihram and must not approach the Kaaba until the day of Mina with other pilgrims, staying in his ihram. If he wishes, he can direct himself towards Mina.

If one leaves for Medina or a place like it without entering a state of ihram and returns during the pilgrimage season, the rules apply accordingly.

النصف، فعليها أن تستأنف الطواف من أوله (1).
وروي أنها إن كانت طافت ثلاثة أشواط أو أقل، ثم رأت الدم حفظت مكانها، فإذا (2) طهرت طافت واعتدت بما مضى (3).
وسئل أبو عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن الطامث، قال: تقضي المناسك كلها، غير أنها لا تطوف بين الصفا والمروة، فقيل: إن بعض ما تقضي من المناسك أعظم من الصفا والمروة، فما بالها تقضي المناسك، ولا تطوف بين الصفا والمروة؟ (قال: لأن الصفا والمروة) (4) تطوف بينهما إذا شاءت، وهذه المواقف لا تقدر أن تقضيها إذا فاتتها (5).
وإن قدم المتمتع يوم التروية (6) فله أن يتمتع ما بينه وبين الليل (7)، فان قدم ليلة عرفة، فليس له أن يجعلها متعة، يجعلها حجا مفردا (8).

translation:
If a woman begins the Tawaf and sees blood before completing half of it, she must start the Tawaf from the beginning. It is narrated that if she completes three or fewer circuits and then sees blood, she should remember her position, and when she becomes pure, she resumes and accounts for what has already been done.

Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, was asked about a menstruating woman. He said: She completes all the rituals except for Tawaf between Safa and Marwa. It was said to him: Some of the rituals she completes are greater than Safa and Marwa. Why can she complete the rituals but not perform Tawaf between Safa and Marwa? He replied: Because she can perform Tawaf between Safa and Marwa whenever she wishes, but the standing places are not repeatable if missed.

If a Mutamatti arrives on the Day of Tarwiyah, which is the 8th of Dhu al-Hijjah, he is allowed to perform the Mutah before nightfall. If he arrives on the night of Arafah, he must not perform it as a Mutah, but rather as an individual Hajj.

(وإن دخل المتمتع مكة فنسي أن يطوف بالبيت وبالصفا والمروة حتى كانت ليلة عرفة، فقد بطلت متعته (1)، يجعلها حجا مفردا) (2) (3).
وكل من دخل مكة بحجة عن غيره، ثم أقام سنة فهو مكي، فإذا أراد أن يحج عن نفسه أو يعتمر بعد ما انصرف من عرفات، فليس له أن يحرم بمكة، ولكن يخرج إلى الوقت (4).
والمجاور بمكة إذا كان صرورة (5) فله أن يحرم في أول يوم من العشر الأول (6)، وإن لم يكن صرورة فإنه يخرج لخمس مضين من الشهر (7).
وإن طفت بالبيت المفروض ثمانية أشواط فأعد الطواف (8).
وروي يضيف إليها ستة، فيجعل واحدا فريضة، (والآخر نافلة) (9) (10).

translation:
If a person performing the Tamattu' pilgrimage enters Mecca and forgets to perform the Tawaf around the Kaaba and between Safa and Marwa until the night of Arafah, their Tamattu' is invalidated, turning it into an individual Hajj. Anyone entering Mecca to perform Hajj on behalf of someone else, and then stays for a year, becomes considered a resident of Mecca. If they wish to perform Hajj or Umrah for themselves after returning from Arafat, they cannot enter Ihram in Mecca; they must go out to the designated Miqat.

For residents of Mecca who are performing Hajj for the first time (Srurah), they are permitted to enter Ihram on the first day of the first ten days (of Dhu al-Hijjah). If they are not Srurah, they should enter Ihram after five days of the month have passed. If you circle the Kaaba for the obligatory Tawaf with eight circuits, you should repeat the Tawaf. However, it is narrated that you may add six more circuits, making one obligatory and the remaining as non-obligatory (supererogatory).

وإن طفت طواف الفريضة بالبيت فلم تدر ستة طفت أم سبعة فأعد الطواف (1)، فان خرجت وفاتك ذلك فليس عليك شيء (2).
وإن طفت ستة أشواط طفت شوطا آخر، فان فاتك ذلك حتى أتيت أهلك فمر من يطوف عنك (3).
وسئل أبو عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن رجل لا يدري ثلاثة طاف أم أربعة، قال: طواف نافلة أو فريضة؟ قيل (4): أجبني فيهما جميعا قال: إن كان طواف نافلة فابن على ما شئت، وإن كان طواف (5) فريضة فأعد الطواف (6).
فإذا كان يوم التروية فاغتسل، ثم البس ثوبيك، وادخل المسجد وعليك السكينة والوقار، فطف بالبيت أسبوعا (7) إن شئت، ثم صل ركعتين لطوافك عند مقام إبراهيم - عليه السلام - أو في الحجر، ثم اقعد حتى تزول الشمس، فإذا زالت الشمس فصل المكتوبة، وقل مثل (8) ما قلت يوم أحرمت بالعقيق، ثم اخرج وعليك السكينة والوقار، فإذا انتهيت إلى (9) الردم (10) وأشرفت على الأبطح (11) فارفع

translation:
If you perform the obligatory Tawaf around the Kaaba but are unsure whether you completed six or seven circuits, then repeat the Tawaf. However, if you leave and miss the opportunity to correct it, there is nothing upon you.

If you complete six circuits, perform one more. If you leave and reach your family without completing it, ask someone to perform it on your behalf.

Abu Abdullah - peace be upon him - was asked about a man who is uncertain whether he completed three or four circuits. He responded: "Is it a non-obligatory Tawaf or an obligatory one?" It was said: "Answer for both." He replied: "If it is a non-obligatory (supererogatory) Tawaf, then continue based on what you think. If it is an obligatory Tawaf, repeat it."

On the day of Tarwiyah, perform a full-body purification (ghusl), put on your two garments, and enter the mosque with calmness and dignity. If you wish, perform a complete Tawaf around the Kaaba (seven circuits), then pray two units of prayer for your Tawaf at the station of Ibrahim - peace be upon him - or in the Hijr. Sit until the sun passes the zenith, then perform the prescribed prayer, and say what you said on the day you entered Ihram at Al-'Aqiq. Then proceed with calmness and dignity. When you reach the Redm and overlook the Abtah, raise your voice.

text:
صوتك بالتلبية حتى تأتي منى (1).
ثم تقول وأنت متوجه إلى منى: اللهم إياك أرجو، وإياك أدعو، فبلغني أملي، وأصلح لي عملي (2).
وإذا أتيت منى فقل: اللهم إن هذه منى (وهي مما مننت) (3) به (4) علينا من المناسك، فأسألك أن تمن علي فيها بما مننت به على أنبيائك (5)، فإنما أنا عبدك وفي قبضتك (6).
ثم صل بها العصر، والمغرب، والعشاء الآخرة، والفجر (7).
ثم تمضي إلى عرفات وتقول وأنت متوجه إليها: اللهم إليك صمدت، وإياك اعتمدت، ووجهك أردت، أسألك أن تبارك لي في أجلي، وأن تقضي لي حاجتي، (وأن تجعلني ممن تباهي به اليوم من هو أفضل مني) (8)، ثم تلبي وأنت مار إلى عرفات.

translation:
Raise your voice in the talbiyah until you reach Mina. Then say as you head towards Mina: "O Allah, it is You I hope for, it is You I call upon, so fulfill my hopes and rectify my deeds." When you arrive at Mina, say: "O Allah, this is Mina, and it is one of the rites You have blessed us with. I ask You to bestow upon me in it what You have bestowed upon Your Prophets, for I am only Your servant and in Your grasp."

Then, perform the Asr, Maghrib, Isha, and Fajr prayers there. Next, proceed to Arafat and say as you head towards it: "O Allah, to You I have turned, on You I have relied, and Your face I seek. I ask You to bless my lifespan and fulfill my needs, and to make me among those whom You take pride in today over those who are better than me." Then continue to recite the talbiyah as you proceed to Arafat.

text:
فإذا أتيت عرفات فاضرب خباءك (1) بنمرة (2) قريبا من المسجد، فإن ثم ضرب رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - خباءه وقبته، فإذا زالت الشمس يوم عرفة فاقطع التلبية، وعليك بالتهليل، والتحميد (3)، والثناء على الله.
ثم اغتسل وصل الظهر والعصر، وتجمع بينهما لتفرغ نفسك للدعاء، فإنه يوم دعاء ومسألة (4).
واعمل بما في كتاب «دعاء الموقف» (5) من الدعاء، والتحميد (6)، والتهليل والصلاة على النبي وآله (7) - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -، وجميع ما فيه.

translation:
When you arrive at Arafat, set up your tent at Namira, near the mosque, as this is where the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his family, set up his tent and canopy. When the sun passes its zenith on the Day of Arafah, cease the talbiyah and engage in the proclamation of God's oneness (tahlil), praise (tahmid), and extol God.

Then, perform ritual washing and pray the Zuhr and Asr prayers, combining them so that you can dedicate yourself to supplication, as it is a day for prayers and requests. Act in accordance with what is in the book "Du'a al-Mawqif" regarding supplication, praise, and proclamation of God's oneness, as well as prayers upon the Prophet and his family, peace be upon them all, and all that is contained within.

1 - The "khibaa" refers to a tent, as mentioned in "Majma' al-Bahrayn," Vol. 1, p. 615.
2 - Namira refers to the mountain marking the boundaries of the sanctuary at Arafat, as per "Lisan al-Arab," Vol. 5, p. 236.
3 - "And glorification" is mentioned in source D.
4 - Referenced from al-Mustadrak, Vol. 10, p. 18, Hadith 1, and also from al-Faqih, Vol. 2, p. 322, with variations as seen in al-Mustadrak, Vol. 10, p. 21, Hadith 6.
5 - It is one of the books by the author, mentioned by Najashi in his Rijal, p. 390.
6 - "And glorification" is mentioned in source D.
7 - Not found in sources A and J, source D.

text:
الإفاضة من عرفات إياك أن تفيض منها قبل غروب الشمس فيلزمك دم شاة (1) (2).
فإذا غربت الشمس فأفض (3).
فإذا انتهيت إلى الكثيب (4) الأحمر على يمين الطريق فقل: اللهم (ارحم موقفي) (5)، وزد في عملي، (وسلم ديني) (6)، وتقبل مناسكي (7).

translation:
Departure from Arafat: Be careful not to depart from it before sunset, otherwise, a sacrifice of a sheep will be required of you. According to some authorities, it is a must to offer a camel if one departs knowingly and intentionally before sunset. 

Once the sun sets, you may proceed. As you reach the red sandhill on the right side of the road, say: "O Allah, have mercy on my stance, increase my good deeds, protect my faith, and accept my rituals."

This directive is contrary to the well-known practice. The scholar mentioned it in "Al-Mukhtalif" as a requisite for those who knowingly and deliberately depart early and it is noted in various texts such as "Al-Mustadrak," "Al-Hidayah," and "Al-Faqih," with slight variations in wording. Other references include "Al-Kafi" and "Al-Tahdhib." 

The "sandhill" is a dune of sand, as defined in "Al-Qamus Al-Muhit." 

The supplication has variations like "Have mercy on me, my weakness, and my stance," which are found in other versions of the supplication texts. Some versions omit phrases like "protect my faith." The practice and its details can also be found in various sources, indicating the importance of standing at the right time and place during the pilgrimage rituals.

text:
فإذا أتيت المزدلفة - وهي الجمع - فصل بها المغرب والعشاء الآخرة بأذان وإقامتين، ولا تصلهما إلا بها وإن ذهب ربع الليل (1).
وبت بالمزدلفة (2)، فإذا طلع الفجر فصل الغداة، ثم قف بها بسفح الجبل (3) إلى أن تطلع الشمس على جبل ثبير (4) (5)، وقف بها، فإن الوقف بها فريضة (6)، فأحمد الله، وهلله، وسبحه، ومجده، وكبره، وصل على (النبي - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - وآله) (7)، وأدع لنفسك ما بينك وبين طلوع الشمس على ثبير، فإذا طلعت ورأت الإبل مواضع أخفافها في الحرم فأفض حتى تأتي وادي محسر (8)، فارمل (9) فيه مقدار مائة خطوة، وقل كما

translation:
When you arrive at Muzdalifah, which is also called Al-Jam', perform the Maghrib and the later Isha prayers with one call to prayer (Adhan) and two calls to commence (Iqamas). Do not perform these prayers anywhere else but at Muzdalifah, even if a quarter of the night passes.

Spend the night at Muzdalifah. When dawn breaks, perform the Fajr prayer, then stand at the foot of the mountain until the sun rises over Mount Thabir. Standing here is obligatory, so praise God, say 'La ilaha illallah' (there is no god but God), glorify Him, honor Him, and magnify Him. Send blessings upon the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) and pray for yourself until the sun rises over Thabir.

When the sun has risen and the camels can see the places of their footprints in the sanctuary, proceed until you reach the Valley of Muhassir. Walk briskly for about a hundred steps, saying:

1. Referenced in Al-Mustadrak: 10/49, Hadith 3. Similar instructions are found in Al-Hidayah: 61, Al-Faqih: 2/325, with a similar mention in Al-Tahdhib: 5/188, Hadith 1, and Al-Istibsar: 2/254, Hadith 1, among others.

2. See Al-Faqih: 2/325 and Al-Hidayah: 61 for similar guidance. Also, refer to Al-Kafi: 4/473, Hadith 5, and other sources.

3. "At the foot of the mountain" is the interpretation of 'Safah Al-Jabal', which means the base of the mountain.

4. Thabir is one of the largest mountains in Mecca, located between Mecca and Arafat.

5. See Al-Hidayah: 61, with similar references found in Al-Faqih: 2/326, Al-Kafi: 4/469, and Al-Tahdhib: 5/191.

6. Standing here is obligatory, as referenced in Al-Hidayah: 61 and other texts.

7. "The Prophet and his family" refers to sending blessings upon Muhammad and his family as mentioned in variant sources.

8. Muhassir is a valley located between Muzdalifah and Mina, closer to Mina.

9. 'Raml' refers to brisk walking or trotting, which is walking quickly with short steps.

text:
قلت بالمسعى بمكة، ثم إمض إلى منى (1).
فإن أحببت أن تأخذ حصاك الذي ترمي به من مزدلفة فعلت، وإن أحببت أن يكون من رحلك بمنى فأنت في سعة (2)، فأغسلها (3).
وأقصد إلى الجمرة القصوى وهي جمرة العقبة، فارمها بسبع (4) حصيات من قبل وجهها، ولا ترمها من أعلاها، ويكون بينك وبين الجمرة عشرة أذرع، أو خمسة عشر ذراعا، وتقول والحصى في يدك (5): اللهم هذه حصياتي، فاحصهن لي وارفعهن في عملي.
ثم تقول مع كل حصاة إذا رميتها: الله أكبر (6)، ولتكن الحصاة مثل الأنملة منقطة كحلية (7).
فإذا أتيت رحلك، ورجعت من رمي الجمار فقل: اللهم بك وثقت، وعليك

translation:
At the Sa'i in Mecca, then proceed to Mina. If you wish to take the pebbles you will throw from Muzdalifah, you may do so, or if you prefer them to be from your belongings at Mina, that is also permissible. Wash them. Head towards the farthest Jamarah, which is Jamrat al-'Aqabah, and throw it with seven pebbles from the side facing you; do not throw from its top. There should be a distance of ten to fifteen cubits between you and the Jamarah. While the pebbles are in your hand, say: "O Allah, these are my pebbles, so count them for me and elevate them in my deeds."

Then say "Allahu Akbar" with each pebble you throw. Let the pebbles be the size of a fingertip and rounded like a ring. When you return to your tent after stoning the Jamarat, say: "O Allah, in You I place my trust, and upon You [I rely]."

- References can be found in various historical texts and religious guides as indicated, such as Al-Kafi, Al-Faqih, Al-Tahdhib, and others.

text:
توكلت، فنعم الرب أنت، ونعم المولى ونعم النصير (1).
ثم اشتر هديك إن كان من البدن أو من البقر، وإلا فإجعله كبشا سمينا فحلا، فإن لم تجد فحلا فموجئا (2) من الضأن، فإن لم تجد فتيسا (فحلا، فإن لم تجد فحلا) (3) فما تيسر لك، وعظم (شعائر الله فإنها من تقوى القلوب) (4) (5).
ولا تعط الجزار جلودها ولا قلائدها (ولا جلالها (6)، ولكن تصدق بها، ولا تعط السلاخ منها شيئا (7)) (8) (9).
وقال والدي - رحمه الله - في رسالته إلي: يا بني، إعلم أنه لا يجوز في الأضاحي من البدن إلا الثني، وهو الذي تم له خمس سنين ودخل في السادسة، ويجزي من المعز والبقر الثني، وهو الذي تم له سنة ودخل في الثانية (10)، ويجزي من الضأن الجذع لسنة (11).

translation:
I have placed my trust in You, for You are the best Lord, the best Protector, and the best Helper.

Then purchase your sacrificial animal, whether it be a camel or a cow. If not, then choose a fat, mature ram. If you cannot find a mature one, then a castrated sheep, and if even that is not available, then a goat. Choose what you can afford and honor the symbols of God, as they are indicative of the piety of hearts.

Do not give the butcher their skins or their collars, nor their covers, but rather donate them, and do not give the slaughterer any part of them.

In a letter to me, my father - may God have mercy on him - said: My son, know that only a mature camel, five years old and entering its sixth year, is permissible for sacrifice. From goats and cows, a mature animal, one year old and entering its second year, is sufficient. From sheep, a six-month-old lamb (yearling) is acceptable.

text:
وتجزي البقرة عن خمسة نفر إذا كانوا من أهل بيت (1).
وروي أن البقرة لا تجزي إلا عن واحد (2).
وإذا عزت (3) الأضاحي أجزأت شاة عن سبعين (4).
وإذا اشتريت هديك فانحره أو (5) اذبحه وقل: وجهت وجهي للذي فطر السماوات والأرض، حنيفا مسلما وما أنا من المشركين، إن صلاتي ونسكي ومحياي ومماتي لله رب العالمين، لا شريك له، وبذلك أمرت، وأنا من المسلمين، اللهم منك ولك، بسم الله والله أكبر، اللهم تقبل مني.
ثم اذبح وانحر (6) ولا تنخع (7) حتى يموت (8)، ثم (9) كل وتصدق وأطعم واهد إلى من شئت (10).

translation:
A cow may suffice for five people if they are from the same household (1). It is narrated that a cow only suffices for one person (2). When sacrificial animals become rare (3), it is permissible for one sheep to suffice for seventy (4).

When you purchase your sacrificial animal, slaughter or (5) sacrifice it while saying: "I have turned my face towards Him who created the heavens and the earth, as a monotheist, a Muslim, and I am not among the polytheists. Indeed, my prayer, my sacrifice, my living, and my dying are for Allah, the Lord of all worlds, who has no partner; this I have been commanded, and I am of the Muslims. O Allah, from You and to You, in the name of Allah and Allah is the Greatest. O Allah, accept from me." Then slaughter and sacrifice (6), but do not cut (7) the spinal cord until it dies (8). Then (9) eat, give in charity, feed, and gift to whomever you wish (10).

1. References are made to various Islamic texts such as Al-Mustadrak, Al-Hidayah, and others, which discuss similar rulings and mention a variance where a cow suffices for seven people instead of five.
2. This ruling is also mentioned in texts such as Al-Wasa'il and Fiqh al-Ridha, with slight variations.
3. 'Az of something means when it becomes scarce.
4. Found in texts like Al-Hidayah and Al-Faqih which allow for a single sheep to suffice for a larger number when scarcity occurs.
5. Variations in wording are noted in different sources.
6. Alternatives in terminology.
7. "Nakh' of the animal means cutting its spinal cord before it dies."
8. Reference found in Al-Mustadrak and other compilations, mentioning prayers and supplications associated with the act.
9. Mention of wording variations in source texts.
10. Found in texts such as Al-Kafi, referencing the sharing and distribution of the sacrificial animal's meat.

وسئل الصادق - عليه السلام - عن قول الله تبارك وتعالى: (فإذا وجبت جنوبها فكلوا منها وأطعموا القانع والمعتر (1)) قال: القانع الذي يقنع بما تعطيه، والمعتر الذي يعتريك (2).
وسئل - عليه السلام - عن لحوم الأضاحي فقال: كان علي بن الحسين، وأبو جعفر - عليهما السلام - يتصدقان بثلث على جيرانهم وثلث على السؤال، ويمسكان (3) الثلث الآخر (4) لأهل البيت (5).
وكره أبو عبد الله - عليه السلام - أن يطعم المشرك من لحوم الأضاحي (6).
وكان علي بن الحسين - عليه السلام - يطعم من ذبيحته الحرورية (7)، ويعلم أنهم حرورية (8).
ولا بأس باخراج الجلد والسنام من الحرم، ولا يجوز إخراج اللحم منه (9).
وسئل الصادق - عليه السلام - عن فداء الصيد، يأكل صاحبه من لحمه؟ فقال: يأكل من أضحيته، ويتصدق بالفداء (10).

translation:
Imam Sadiq (peace be upon him) was asked about the words of Allah Almighty: "And when their sides collapse, eat of them and feed the self-contented and the beggar." (1) He said: The self-contented is the one who is satisfied with what you give him, and the beggar is the one who approaches you (2).

Imam Sadiq (peace be upon him) was also asked about the meat of the sacrifices. He replied: Ali ibn al-Hussein and Abu Ja'far (peace be upon them) used to give a third to their neighbors, a third to the beggars, and keep (3) the remaining third (4) for the household (5).

Abdullah (peace be upon him) disliked feeding the polytheists with the sacrificial meat (6).

Ali ibn al-Hussein (peace be upon him) would feed the Haruri sect from his sacrifice (7), knowing that they were Haruri (8).

There is no harm in taking the skin and the hump out of the Haram, but taking the meat out is not permissible (9).

Imam Sadiq (peace be upon him) was asked if the owner of the hunted animal should eat from its meat as a ransom. He replied: He may eat from his sacrifice and donate the ransom (10).

الحلق فإذا أردت أن تحلق رأسك فأستقبل القبلة، واحلق إلى العظمين النابتين من الصدغين (1) قبالة وتد الأذنين (2).
فإذا حلقت فقل: اللهم أعطني بكل شعرة نورا يوم القيامة (3).
وأدفن شعرك بمنى (4)، فإنه روي عن أبي عبد الله - عليه السلام - أنه قال: إن المؤمن إذا حلق رأسه بمنى، ثم دفن شعره، جاء يوم القيامة وكل شعرة لها لسان مطلق تلبي باسم صاحبها (5).

translation:
If you wish to shave your head, face the Qibla, and shave towards the two bones that emerge from the temples, facing the ear lobes. After shaving, say: "O Allah, grant me with every hair a light on the Day of Resurrection." Bury your hair at Mina, as it is narrated from Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, that he said: "When a believer shaves his head at Mina and then buries his hair, it will come on the Day of Resurrection with each hair having a free tongue praising its owner's name."

1. The temple: the area between the corner of the eye and the ear's base, also referred to as the hair hanging over it. 
2. Referenced in "Mustadrak": 10/137, and in "Fiqh al-Ridha": 225 with slight variation, and in "Al-Faqih": 2/329, and "Al-Hidaya": 63 similarly. Also see "Al-Kafi": 4/503, "Al-Tahdhib": 5/244, and from these "Al-Wasa'il": 14/229.
3. Referenced in "Mustadrak": 10/137, and in "Al-Faqih": 2/329, and "Al-Hidaya": 63 similarly, and in "Al-Tahdhib": 5/244 with slight variation, from which "Al-Wasa'il": 14/228.
4. Referenced in "Al-Faqih": 2/329, and "Al-Hidaya": 63 similarly, and in "Qurb al-Isnad": 140, and "Al-Tahdhib": 5/242, and "Al-Istibsar": 2/286 conveying a similar meaning, from which "Al-Wasa'il": 14/220, and additionally in "Al-Bihar" 99/302 about "Qurb al-Isnad".
5. Referenced from "Al-Wasa'il": 14/220, and from "Al-Kafi": 4/502, and "Al-Faqih": 2/139 similarly.

text:
وقال رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -: رحم الله المحلقين، قيل: يا رسول الله والمقصرين؟
[قال: رحم الله المحلقين، قيل: يا رسول الله والمقصرين؟ (قال: رحم الله المحلقين، قيل: يا رسول الله والمقصرين؟) (1)] (2) قال: والمقصرين (3).
وإذا لبد الرجل رأسه أو عقصه بخيط في الحج والعمرة، فليس له أن يقصر وعليه الحلق (4).
وإذا عقص المحرم رأسه وهو متمتع فقام فقضى نسكه، وحل عقاصه، وقصر وأدهن، وأحل، فعليه شاة (5).
وأعلم أن الصرورة لا يجوز له أن يقصر، وعليه الحلق، إنما التقصير لمن قد حج حجة الإسلام (6).

translation:
The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him and his family, said: "May Allah have mercy on those who shave their heads." It was said, "O Messenger of Allah, and those who trim?" He replied, "May Allah have mercy on those who shave their heads." It was again asked, "O Messenger of Allah, and those who trim?" He repeated, "May Allah have mercy on those who shave their heads." Then he said, "also those who trim."

If a man binds or braids his hair with a thread during Hajj or Umrah, he is not permitted to trim; shaving is obligatory for him.

If a pilgrim, while in a state of Ihram and enjoying the benefits of tamattu' (combining Umrah with Hajj), completes his rites, undoes his braid, trims, applies oil, and removes his restrictions, he is required to offer a sheep.

Be aware that it is not permissible for a first-time pilgrim (Suroor) to trim; shaving is obligatory for him. Trimming is allowed only for those who have already performed the obligatory Hajj of Islam.

text:
ولا تلق شعرك إلا بمنى، فإن جهلت أن تقصر من رأسك أو تحلقه حتى ارتحلت من منى، فارجع إلى منى والق شعرك بها، حلقا كان أو تقصيرا (١).
ولا تغسل رأسك بالخطمي (٢) حتى تحلقه، فإن أبا عبد الله - عليه السلام - نهى عن ذلك (٣).
وفي حديث آخر (٤) سئل - عليه السلام - يجوز للرجل أن يغسل رأسه بالخطمي قبل أن يحلقه؟ قال:
يقصر ويغسله (٥).
وسئل أبو جعفر - عليه السلام - عن قول الله عز وجل: ﴿ثم ليقضوا تفثهم﴾ (6) قال: هو حفوف (7) الرجل من الطيب (8).
وروي: أن التفث هو الحلق، وما في جلد الإنسان (9).

translation:
Do not shed your hair anywhere except in Mina. If you forget to shorten or shave your head hair until you have left Mina, return there to shed your hair, whether by shaving or shortening it. Do not wash your head with soapwort until you have shaved it, because Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, forbade that practice.

In another narration, Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, was asked if a man is permitted to wash his head with soapwort before shaving it. He responded: He should shorten his hair and then wash it.

Abu Ja'far, peace be upon him, was asked about the words of God Almighty: "Then let them complete the rites prescribed for them." He said: It refers to a man's cleansing himself from perfumes. It has been narrated that 'fulfillment of the rites' is related to shaving and what pertains to the skin of a human being.

text:
وروي: أن التفث، هو ما يكون من الرجل في حال إحرامه، فإذا دخل مكة وطاف وتكلم بكلام طيب كان ذلك كفارة لذلك (١).
وسئل أبو عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن رجل زار البيت ولم يحلق رأسه، قال: يحلقه بمكة، ويحمل شعره إلى منى، وليس عليه شيء (٢).
ولا تحلق رأسك حتى تذبح، فإن الله عز وجل يقول: ﴿ولا تحلقوا رؤوسكم حتى يبلغ الهدي محله﴾ (3) (4).
وروي: إذا اشترى الرجل هديه وقمطه (5) في رحله، فقد بلغ محله (6).
وإن جهلت فحلقت رأسك قبل أن تذبح فليس عليك شيء (7).

translation:
It was narrated that "Al-Tafath" refers to the state one is in during their Ihram. When a person enters Mecca, performs Tawaf, and speaks good words, it serves as an atonement for that state. 

Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, was asked about a man who visited the House (Kaaba) but did not shave his head. He replied: "He should shave his head in Mecca and then carry the hair to Mina, and there is nothing upon him."

Do not shave your head until you have sacrificed, for Allah Almighty says: "Do not shave your heads until the offering reaches the place of sacrifice" (Quran 2:196). 

It was narrated: If a person buys his sacrificial animal and prepares it in his travel luggage, the offering has reached its place.

And if you unknowingly shave your head before sacrificing, there is nothing upon you.

1. Referenced from Al-Mustadrak: 10/131, and similar narrations can be found in Al-Faqih and Meanings of News, among other sources.
2. Referenced from Wasail and found in other texts like Al-Tahdhib and Al-Istibsar, with similar meanings in Al-Kafi.
3. Quranic Reference: Al-Baqarah 2:196.
4. Additional narrations can be found in various Islamic texts and referenced sources as noted.

text:
وإن نسيت أن تذبح بمنى حتى زرت البيت فاشتر بمكة وانحرها (1) بها (2) وليس عليك شيء، وقد أجزأت عنك (3).
وكل من زار البيت قبل أن يحلق وهو عالم أنه لا ينبغي فعليه دم شاة (4)، فإن كان جاهلا فلا شيء عليه (5).
وإذا تمتع الرجل بالعمرة، ووقف بعرفة وبالمشعر، ورمى الجمرة، وذبح وحلق، فلا يجوز له أن يغطي رأسه حتى يطوف بالبيت وبالصفا (6) والمروة، فإن كان قد فعل فلا شيء عليه (7).
وإذا ذبح الرجل (8) وحلق فقد أحل من كل شيء أحرم منه إلا النساء والطيب فإذا زار البيت فطاف وسعى بين الصفا والمروة فقد أحل من كل شيء أحرم منه إلا النساء، فإذا طاف طواف النساء فقد أحل من كل شيء أحرم منه (9).
وروي عن إدريس القمي أنه قال لأبي عبد الله - عليه السلام -: إن مولى لنا تمتع

translation:
If you forgot to perform the sacrifice at Mina and then visited the Kaaba, you should buy a sacrifice in Mecca and slaughter it there. There is nothing further required of you, and it will suffice for you.

Anyone who visits the Kaaba before shaving, knowing that this is not appropriate, must offer a sheep as atonement. However, if he was unaware, there is no obligation upon him.

When a man performs the lesser pilgrimage (Umrah) and stands at Arafat and Muzdalifah, and stones the Jamarat, slaughters, and shaves, he must not cover his head until he has circled the Kaaba and performed the Sa'i between Safa and Marwah. However, if he did cover his head, there is no penalty upon him.

Once a man has slaughtered and shaved, he is released from all prohibitions except those concerning women and perfume. Once he has visited the Kaaba and performed the Tawaf and the Sa'i between Safa and Marwah, he is released from all prohibitions except those concerning women. Once he performs the Tawaf of women, he is completely released from all prohibitions.

It is narrated from Idris Al-Qummi that he asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, about a servant of ours who performed the Tamattu'.

text:
فلما حلق لبس الثياب قبل أن يزور البيت، قال: بئس ما صنع، قلت: أعليه شيء؟ قال: لا، قلت: فإني رأيت ابن أبي سماك (1) يسعى بين الصفا والمروة وعليه خفان وقباء (2) ومنطقة، فقال: بئس ما صنع، قلت: عليه شيء؟ قال: لا (3).
ويكره للمتمتع أن يطلي رأسه بالحناء حتى يزور البيت (4).
وإن وقع رجل على امرأة قبل أن يطوف طواف النساء فعليه جزور سمينة، وإن كان جاهلا فليس عليه شيء (5).
وإن أحل رجل من إحرامه ولم تحل امرأته فعليها بدنة يغرمها زوجها (6).
وروي: إذا وقع الرجل (على المرأة) (7) وقد طاف بالبيت والصفا والمروة طوافا واحدا للحج ما عليه؟
قال: يهريق دم جزور، أو بقرة، أو شاة (8).
ومن كان متمتعا فلم يجد هديا فليصم ثلاثة أيام (في الحج) (9)، يوما قبل

translation:
When he shaved, he wore clothes before visiting the House (Kaaba). He said, "What a bad thing he did." I asked, "Is there any penalty on him?" He said, "No." I said, "I saw Ibn Abi Simak (1) making the sa'i between Safa and Marwah while wearing boots, a robe (2), and a belt." He said, "What a bad thing he did." I asked, "Is there any penalty on him?" He said, "No" (3).

It is disliked for a pilgrim performing Tamattu' to dye their hair with henna until after they have visited the House (4).

If a man were to have intercourse with a woman before performing the Tawaf for women, he would be required to sacrifice a fat camel. However, if he was unaware, there is no penalty on him (5).

If a man exits his state of Ihram while his wife does not, she must offer a she-camel, and her husband bears the cost (6).

It is narrated: If a man were to have intercourse (with his wife) (7) after having performed Tawaf of the House and Safa and Marwah as a single act for Hajj, what is required of him? He is required to sacrifice the blood of a camel, a cow, or a sheep (8).

Whoever is performing Tamattu' and cannot find a sacrificial animal should fast three days (during Hajj) (9), one day before...

1 - This is Ibrahim ibn Abi Simak, whom Al-Najashi mentioned in his 'Rijal' book (p. 21), stating that he was a Waqifi who narrated from Abu al-Hasan Musa - peace be upon him. Likewise, Sheikh Tusi mentioned him in his 'Rijal' as one of the companions of Imam al-Kadhim - peace be upon him. Sayyid Al-Khoei also referenced him in his 'Rijal' (1/196).

text:
التروية، ويوم التروية، ويوم عرفة، وسبعة أيام إذا رجع إلى أهله، فإن فاته ذلك وكان له مقام صام بمكة ثلاثة أيام، وإن لم يكن له مقام صام في الطريق أو في أهله، فإن كان له مقام بمكة فأراد أن يصوم السبع، ترك الصيام بقدر مسيره إلى أهله أو شهرا، ثم صام (1).
وروي أن رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - بعث بديل بن ورقاء الخزاعي على جمل أورق (2)، فأمره أن ينهى الناس عن صيام أيام منى، فتخلل بديل الفساطيط ينادي (3) بأعلى صوته: أيها الناس، لا تصوموا هذه الأيام، فإنها أيام أكل وشرب وبعال (4). والبعال: الجماع.
وروي: إذا لم يجد المتمتع الهدي حتى يقدم أهله أن يبعث بدم (5)، ومن لم يتهيأ له صيام الثلاثة الأيام بمكة فليصمها بالمدينة، وسبعة إذا رجع إلى أهله (6).

translation:
The text discusses specific Islamic practices regarding fasting and rituals during the pilgrimage period. It begins by mentioning the day of "Tarwiyah" and the day of "Arafah," followed by seven days when one returns to their family. If someone misses this opportunity, they can fast three days in Mecca if they reside there, or if not, on their way back or with their family. If they do reside in Mecca and intend to fast the seven days, they must pause their fasting for the duration of their journey back to their family or a month, and then resume fasting.

It is narrated that the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) sent Budayl ibn Warqa al-Khuza'i on a grey camel, instructing him to forbid people from fasting during the days of Mina. Budayl walked among the tents, announcing loudly: "O people, do not fast on these days, for they are days of eating, drinking, and intimacy." The term "intimacy" here refers to marital relations.

Another narration mentions that if someone performing Tamattu' cannot find a sacrificial animal until returning to their family, they should send a blood sacrifice. If one cannot manage to fast the three days in Mecca, they should fast them in Medina and seven when they return to their family.

References to these rulings can be found in several Islamic jurisprudence texts, indicating their widespread acknowledgment and the importance placed on these specific rituals and guidelines within the tradition.

text:
وإذا تمتع الرجل بالعمرة إلى الحج ولم يكن له هدي، فصام ثلاثة أيام (1) في الحج، ثم مات بعد ما رجع إلى (2) أهله قبل أن يصوم السبعة فليس (3) على وليه أن يقضي عنه (4).
وروى معاوية بن عمار عن أبي عبد الله - عليه السلام - أنه قال: من مات ولم يكن له هدي لمتعته فليصم عنه وليه (5).
وإن صام المتمتع ثلاثة أيام في الحج، ثم أصاب هديا يوم خرج (6) من منى فقد أجزأه صيامه، وليس عليه شيء (7).
فان صام يوم التروية ويوم عرفة، فإنه يصوم يوما آخر بعد أيام التشريق (8).

translation:
If a man enjoys the 'Umrah leading to Hajj and does not have a sacrificial animal, he must fast three days during Hajj. If he dies after returning to his family before fasting the remaining seven days, his guardian is not obliged to fast on his behalf.

Muawiyah ibn Ammar narrated from Abu Abdullah - peace be upon him - who said: If a person dies without having a sacrificial animal for his enjoyment, his guardian should fast on his behalf.

If the person performing Hajj Tamattu' fasts three days during Hajj and then acquires a sacrificial animal when leaving Mina, his fasting suffices, and nothing further is required of him. If he fasts on the Day of Tarwiyah and the Day of Arafah, he should fast one additional day after the Days of Tashreeq.

The Shaykh mentioned in Al-Tahdhib that these three days refer to the initial fast, and regarding the seven additional days, nobody is required to make up for them if the person dies after returning to his family.

text:
وسئل أبو عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن صوم أيام التشريق، فقال: أما بالأمصار فلا بأس، وأما بمنى فلا (1).
وسأل معاوية بن عمار أبا عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن رجل دخل متمتعا في ذي القعدة، وليس معه ثمن هدي، [قال: لا] (2) يصوم ثلاثة أيام حتى يتحول الشهر فان (3) تحول الشهر يصوم قبل يوم التروية بيوم، ويوم التروية، ويوم عرفة، قال: فالسبعة الأيام متى يصومها إذا كان يريد المقام؟ قال: يصومها إذا مضت أيام التشريق (4).
وسأله حماد بن عثمان عمن ضاع ثمن هديه يوم عرفة، ولم يكن معه ما يشتري به، قال - عليه السلام -:
يصوم ثلاثة أيام أولها يوم الحصبة (5) (6).

translation:
Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) was asked about fasting during the days of Tashreeq, and he said: "In the cities, there is no harm, but in Mina, it is not allowed."

Muawiya bin Ammar asked Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) about a man who entered into the state of Tamattu' (a type of pilgrimage) in the month of Dhu al-Qa'dah and did not have the means to offer a sacrifice. [He said: No,] he should not fast the three days until the new month begins. If the month changes, he should fast the day before the Day of Tarwiyah, the Day of Tarwiyah, and the Day of Arafah. He then asked: "When should he fast the seven days if he intends to stay?" He replied: "He should fast them after the days of Tashreeq have passed."

Hammad bin Uthman asked him about someone who lost the money for his sacrificial animal on the Day of Arafah and did not have anything to buy it with. He (peace be upon him) said: "He should fast three days starting from the Day of Hasba."

text:
التكبير أيام التشريق (التكبير من صلاة الظهر (يوم النحر) (1) إلى صلاة الفجر (2) من آخر أيام التشريق) (3) إن أنت أقمت بمنى (4)، وإن أنت خرجت من منى فليس عليك التكبير، والتكبير أن تقول: الله أكبر، الله أكبر، لا إله إلا الله والله أكبر، الله أكبر ولله الحمد، الله أكبر على ما هدانا، الله أكبر على ما رزقنا من بهيمة الأنعام، والحمد لله على ما أبلانا (5).
الصلاة في مسجد الخيف وصل في مسجد الخيف، وهو مسجد منى، فإن رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - صلى فيه (6).
وروي: أنه صلى فيه ألف نبي، وإنما سمي الخيف، لأنه مرتفع (عن الوادي، وكلما كان مرتفعا) (7) على (8) الوادي سمي خيفا (9).

translation:
The Takbir during the Days of Tashreeq is recited from the Dhuhr prayer on the Day of Sacrifice (1) until the Fajr prayer (2) on the last day of Tashreeq (3) if you are staying in Mina (4). If you leave Mina, you are not required to recite the Takbir. The Takbir is recited as follows: Allah is the Greatest, Allah is the Greatest, there is no deity but Allah, and Allah is the Greatest; Allah is the Greatest and all praise is due to Allah; Allah is the Greatest for what He has guided us to, Allah is the Greatest for what He provided us from the livestock, and all praise is due to Allah for what He bestowed upon us (5).

Praying in the Mosque of Al-Khayf: Pray in the Mosque of Al-Khayf, the mosque of Mina, for indeed the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) prayed there (6). It is narrated that a thousand prophets prayed there. It is named Al-Khayf because it is elevated (above the valley, and anything elevated) (7) from (8) the valley is called "Khayf" (9).

زيارة البيت فإذا أتيت البيت يوم النحر قمت (1) على باب المسجد فقلت: اللهم أعني على نسكي، وسلمني (له وسلمه لي) (2)، أسألك مسألة العليل (3) الذليل المعترف بذنبه أن تغفر لي ذنوبي، (وأن ترجعني بحاجتي) (4)، اللهم إني عبدك، والبلد بلدك، والبيت بيتك، جئت (5) أطلب رحمتك، وأبتغي مرضاتك، متبعا لأمرك، راضيا بقولك (6)، أسألك مسألة المضطر إليك، المطيع لأمرك، المشفق من عذابك، الخائف لعقوبتك، أسألك أن تلقيني عفوك، وتجيرني برحمتك من النار (7).
إتيان (8) الحجر الأسود ثم تأتي الحجر الأسود فتستلمه، فإن لم تستطع فاستلمه بيدك وقبل يدك (9) فإن لم تستطع فاستقبله وأشر إليه بيدك، وقبلها وكبر، وقل مثل ما قلت حين (10) طفت بالبيت (يوم قدمت) (11) مكة.
