translation:
In an account, Abu Hamza al-Thamali asked Abu Ja'far, peace be upon him, about a man who struck another man's head with a tent pole, injuring him in such a way that he lost his sanity. Abu Ja'far, peace be upon him, said: "He must pay a full compensation (blood money)." Abu Hamza further asked: "If the victim lives for ten days, or more or less, and then recovers his sanity, can he still claim the compensation from the assailant?" Abu Ja'far, peace be upon him, answered: "No, the right to compensation has already been executed, including all its consequences."

Abu Hamza continued: "What if the victim dies after two or three months, and his companions decide they want to kill the assailant?" Abu Ja'far, peace be upon him, replied: "If they wish to kill him, they must pay the compensation amongst themselves within a year. If the year passes, they have no right to kill him, and the compensation, including its obligations, has been concluded."

Furthermore, if four witnesses testify against a man for adultery, and then one of them retracts their testimony saying, "I doubted my testimony," he is liable to pay compensation (blood money). However, if he says, "I deliberately testified falsely against him," then he shall be executed.

1. This reference comes from various sources such as Al-Mustadrak, Al-Mahasib, Al-Kafi, Al-Faqih, and Al-Tahdhib, which contain similar narrations with slight variations.
2. The word "Amah" means the kind of injury that reaches the inner layer of the brain, as defined in Lisan al-Arab.
3. This narration is also referenced in other texts like Al-Mustadrak and Al-Tahdhib, and associated works.
4. The matter of testimony is discussed in detail in Al-Mustadrak, Al-Faqih, Al-Kafi, and Al-Tahdhib, with slight verbal variations.

text:
وقال أبو جعفر - عليه السلام -: دية ولد الزنا دية العبد، ثمانمائة درهم (١).
[وروي أن دية العبد ثمنه، ولا يتجاوز بقيمة عبد دية حر] (٢) (٣).
وسأل أبو بصير أبا عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن قول الله عز وجل: ﴿فمن اعتدى بعد ذلك فله عذاب أليم﴾ (4) قال: هو الرجل يقبل الدية أو يعفو، ثم يبدو له فيلقى الرجل فيقتله فله عذاب أليم، كما قال الله عز وجل (5).
وإن ادعى رجل على رجل قتلا وليس له بينة، فعليه أن يقسم خمسين يمينا بالله، فإذا أقسم دفع إليه صاحبه فقتله، فان أبى أن يقسم، قيل للمدعى عليه: أقسم، فان أقسم خمسين يمينا أنه ما قتل ولا يعلم قاتلا، أغرم الدية إن وجد القتيل بين ظهرانيهم (6).

translation:
Abu Ja'far, peace be upon him, said: "The blood money for the child of adultery is equivalent to the blood money of a slave, which is eight hundred dirhams." (1)

[It is also narrated that the blood money for a slave is his value, and it should not exceed the blood money of a free person in value.] (2) (3)

Abu Baseer asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, about the saying of Allah, the Exalted: "But if any excess is committed against him, after this, he shall have a grievous penalty." (4) He replied: "This verse refers to a man who accepts the blood money or pardons, and then later changes his mind, confronts the person, and kills him. For such a person, there shall be a grievous penalty, as stated by Allah, the Exalted." (5)

If a man claims that another man has committed murder against him and has no evidence, he is required to take fifty oaths by Allah. Once he takes these oaths, the accused is handed over to him for him to kill. If he refuses to take the oaths, the accused is then asked to swear. If he swears fifty oaths that he neither committed the murder nor knows the murderer, he must pay the blood money if the victim is found among their midst. (6)

1. Cited from Al-Mukhtalaf, p. 794, and Al-Mustadrak, Vol. 18, p. 305, Hadith 1. In Al-Tahdhib, Vol. 10, p. 315, Hadith 12 and Hadith 14 through two sources from Abu Al-Hasan and Ja'far, peace be upon them, where it states instead "the blood money of a Jew" and "the blood money of a Dhimmi" respectively. Referred in Al-Wasa'il, Vol. 29, p. 222 - Chapters on Blood Money - Section 15, Hadith 1 and Hadith 3. Similar context will appear on p. 530.

The scholar, in Al-Mukhtalaf regarding the blood money of the child of adultery, argued: the required blood money is that of a Muslim if they outwardly profess Islam, and even retribution is warranted if a Muslim intentionally kills him, due to the generality of the verse and the statement, peace be upon him: "They are equal to each other."

text:
وليس على الصبيان قصاص، وعمدهم خطأ، تحمله العاقلة (1) (2).
وروي أن عليا - عليه السلام - أتي برجل قد (3) قطع قبل امرأة، فلم يجعل بينهما قصاصا (4)، وألزمه الدية (5).
وسأل حفص بن البختري أبا عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن رجل ضرب على رأسه فذهب سمعه وبصره، واعتقل لسانه، ثم مات، فقال: إن كان ضربة بعد ضربة اقتص منه، ثم قتل، وإن كان أصابه هذا من ضربة واحدة، قتل ولم يقتص منه (6).
وأتى علي - عليه السلام - برجل نباش، فأخذ بشعره فضرب به الأرض، ثم أمر الناس أن يطؤوه (7) حتى مات (8).
وسأل علي بن عقبة أبا عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن عبد قتل أربعة أحرار واحدا بعد واحد، فقال: هو لأهل الأخير من القتلى، إن شاؤوا قتلوا وإن شاؤوا استرقوا،

translation:
Children are not subject to retribution, and their intentional actions are considered mistakes, for which the 'Aqila bears responsibility. It is narrated that Ali, peace be upon him, was brought a man who had mutilated a woman, and he did not impose retaliation between them, but instead obligated the payment of blood money. Hafs ibn al-Bakhtari asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, about a man who was struck on the head, losing his hearing and sight, losing his ability to speak, and then eventually dying. He said: If he was injured from successive blows, retribution is exacted from the assailant, then he is executed. But if it was from a single blow, the assailant is executed without further retribution.

Ali, peace be upon him, once dealt with a grave-digger, grabbed him by his hair, slammed him to the ground, and then ordered the people to trample him until he died. Ali ibn Oqba asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, about a slave who killed four free men, one after the other. He said: The matter is in the hands of the family of the last victim; if they wish, they can kill him, or they can enslave him.

لأنه لما قتل الأول استحقه أولياء الأول، فلما قتل الثاني استحق أولياؤه من أولياء الأول، فلما قتل الثالث استحق أولياؤه من أولياء الثاني، فلما قتل الرابع استحق أولياؤه من أولياء الثالث، فصار لأولياء الرابع، إن شاؤوا قتلوا وإن شاؤوا استرقوا (1).
واعلم أن جراحات العبد على نحو جراحات الأحرار في الثمن (2).
وفي ذكر الصبي الدية، وفي ذكر العنين الدية (3).
وقال عبد الله بن سنان لأبي عبد الله - عليه السلام -: ما على رجل وثب على امرأة فحلق رأسها؟ قال (4):
يضرب ضربا وجيعا، ويحبس في حبس المسلمين حتى يستبرأ، فإن نبت أخذ منه مهر نسائها، وإن لم ينبت أخذ منه الدية كاملة خمسة آلاف درهم، قال: فكيف صار مهر نسائها عليه إن نبت شعرها وإن لم ينبت الدية؟ فقال: يا بن سنان، شعر المرأة وعذرتها شريكان في الجمال، فإذا ذهب بأحدهما وجب لها المهر كاملا (5).
وقضى أمير المؤمنين - عليه السلام - في رجل ضرب رجلا بعصا، فذهب سمعه، وبصره، ولسانه، وفرجه، وعقله (6) وهو حي، بست ديات (7).

translation:
The text discusses concepts related to justice and retribution within an Islamic legal context. The following is a translation of the provided Arabic text:

---

Because when the first (person) was killed, his heirs were entitled to the right. When the second was killed, his heirs were entitled from the heirs of the first. When the third was killed, his heirs were entitled from the heirs of the second. When the fourth was killed, his heirs were entitled from the heirs of the third. Thus, it came to the heirs of the fourth; if they wished, they could kill (the perpetrator), or if they wished, they could enslave (him).

Know that the injuries to a slave are equivalent in value to the injuries to free men.

In the case of a child, there is diyah (compensation), and in the case of an impotent person, there is diyah.

Abdullah ibn Sinan said to Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him): What is the ruling on a man who assaulted a woman and shaved her head? He replied: He should be severely beaten and imprisoned in a Muslim jail until he is deemed safe. If her hair grows back, he should compensate her with her full dowry. If it does not grow back, he has to pay the full diyah of five thousand dirhams. Abdullah asked: Why is he liable for the woman's dowry if her hair grows back, and liable for diyah if it does not? He said: O son of Sinan, a woman's hair and chastity are partners in beauty, and if one is lost, she deserves her full dowry.

The Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) ruled in the case of a man who struck another man with a stick, causing him to lose his hearing, sight, speech, genital function, and mind while alive. The ruling was six full compensations.

Footnotes reference the sources of the rulings cited, including "Al-Mustadrak," "Al-Mukhtalif," "Al-Tahdhib," and others.

translation:
The Prophet - peace be upon him - ruled in the case of a slap to the face which causes it to turn black, that the compensation for it is six dinars. If the mark turns green, the compensation is three dinars, and if it turns red, the compensation is one and a half dinars.

On the subject of reparation for a eunuch's injury.

If a man and a boy jointly kill another man, if the boy is five hand spans tall, retaliation is taken from him and for him. If the boy has not reached five hand spans, then he is liable for the blood money.

A case was presented to Ali - peace be upon him - in which a man stepped on another man's stomach causing him to soil his clothes. He ruled that the aggressor’s stomach should be stepped on until he soils himself as the victim had, or alternatively, he should pay a third of the blood money.

There is no retaliation between slaves and free people for anything less than loss of life, nor between Jews and Muslims in similar matters.

translation:
In the case of a Christian (1) and a Zoroastrian (2), if a servant gouges out the eye of a free person, and the servant has debt, then the servant becomes the property of the person whose eye was gouged out, and the creditors lose their claim (3). If a servant kills their master, they are to be executed in return, as decreed by the Messenger of God—peace be upon him and his family—and the Commander of the Faithful—peace be upon him (4).

If two men testify against a person that he committed theft leading to the cutting of his hand, and then one retracts saying it was a mistaken identity, he is liable to pay half the blood money and the hand is not to be cut. If both of them say it was a mistaken identity, they are liable to pay the full blood money for the hand from their own wealth (5).

If four witnesses testify that they saw a man engaging in intercourse with a woman and he is stoned, and then one of them retracts, that witness is liable for a quarter of the blood money (6).

translation:
In the matter of a debt owed to the nation, it is considered to be ten times its value (1) (2).

A case was brought to Ali - peace be upon him - concerning a man who killed a pig belonging to a dhimmi (a non-Muslim under Muslim protection). He was held accountable for its value (3).

Abu Abdullah - peace be upon him - was asked about a thief who broke into a woman's home intending to steal her belongings. After gathering the clothes, he succumbed to his desires and raped her. Her son awoke and, using an axe he had with him, killed the thief. The thief had collected the clothes and was about to leave when the woman attacked him with the axe and killed him. The thief’s family came the next day seeking blood money. Abu Abdullah said: “The thief’s family must pay the blood money for the son, while the thief must pay four thousand dirhams as compensation for forcing himself upon her, for he was a fornicator. She is not liable for killing him because he was a thief” (6).

During the time of Abu Abdullah - peace upon him - a man married a woman. On the night of the wedding, the woman brought her male friend into the bridal chamber. When the husband entered to consummate the marriage, the friend attacked, leading to a fight in which the husband killed the friend, and the woman then attacked the husband.

translation:
A woman struck her husband, killing him with a friend, and Abu Abdullah - peace be upon him - said: The woman is liable for the blood money of the friend and is executed for the husband.

If a man shaves another man's beard, if it does not grow back, he owes a full blood money; if it grows back, he owes a third of the blood money.

The Commander of the Faithful, peace be upon him, ruled in the case of "the Hashima" [a head wound that penetrates the skull and fractures the bone], that the compensation is ten camels.

Two maidens were brought before Ali, peace be upon him, having entered the bathhouse, where one deflowered the other with her finger. The one who committed the act was charged with her indemnity (blood money).

If a man converts to Islam and then is mistakenly killed, the blood money is distributed among people of similar status.

أسلم وليس له موال (1).
وقال رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -: من أخرج ميزابا، أو كنيفا، أو وتد وتدا، أو وثق دابة، أو حفر بئرا (2) في طريق المسلمين، فأصاب شيئا فعطب، فهو له ضامن (3).
وسأل رفاعة بن موسى أبا عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن رجل ضرب رجلا فنقص بعض نفسه، بأي شيء يعرف؟ قال: بالساعات، قال: وكيف بالساعات؟ قال (4) - عليه السلام -: إن النفس إذا طلع الفجر هو في الشق الأيمن من الأنف، فإذا مضت الساعة صار إلى الأيسر، فتنظر ما بين نفسك ونفسه، ثم تحسب، ثم يؤخذ بحساب ذلك منه (5) (6).
وسئل - عليه السلام - عن رجل ضرب رجلا فقطع بوله، قال: إن كان البول يمر إلى الليل فعليه الدية كاملة (7)، وإن كان يمر إلى نصف النهار فعليه ثلثا الدية، وإن كان إلى ارتفاع النهار فعليه ثلث الدية (8).

translation:
He converted to Islam without having any patrons.

The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him and his family, said: Whoever places a gutter, or a toilet, or a stake, or tethers an animal, or digs a well in the pathway of Muslims, causing harm to anything, is liable for the damage.

Rafa’a ibn Musa asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, about a man who struck another man, causing a deficiency in his person's body, and how this matter would be evaluated. He replied: By the hours. He was asked: How by the hours? He, peace be upon him, said: At the time of dawn, the soul is in the right side of the nose, then after one hour it moves to the left; hence you look between your breath and his breath, calculate accordingly, and restitution should be determined by this measure.

He was also asked about a man who struck another, causing him to lose control of his urination, to which he responded: If the urination continues until evening, the full compensation is owed. If it continues until midday, two-thirds of the compensation is owed. If only until forenoon, one-third is owed.

The scholar Al-Allamah noted: If the killing was by mistake, the compensation is owed by the perpetrator if he has wealth. If not, it is on the imam. If the deceased has no inheritors, the compensation goes to the imam.

text:
وسأل أبو بصير أبا عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن رجل قتل وليس له مال وعليه دين، فهل لأوليائه أن يهبوا دمه لقاتله وعليه دين (1)؟ قال: إن أصحاب الدين هم الخصماء للقاتل، فان وهب (2) أولياؤه دمه للقاتل، ضمنوا الدين للغرماء، وإلا فلا (3).
وسأله هشام بن سالم (4) عن رجل دخل الحمام فصب عليه ماء حار، فامترط (5) شعر رأسه ولحيته (6) ولا ينبت أبدا، قال - عليه السلام -: عليه الدية (7).
واعلم أن في السن الأسود ثلث دية السن، وفي اليد الشلاء ثلث ديتها، وفي العين القائمة (8) إذا طمست ثلث ديتها، وفي شحمة الأذن (9) ثلث ديتها، وفي الرجل العرجاء ثلث ديتها، وفي خشاش (10) الأنف في كل واحد ثلث الدية (11).
وإذا فقأ حر عين مكاتب أو كسر سنه، فإن كان أدى نصف مكاتبته، فقأ عين الحر، أو (12) أخذ ديته إن كان خطأ، فإنه بمنزلة الحر، وإن كان لم يؤد النصف

translation:
Abu Basir asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, about a man who was killed without leaving behind any wealth but had debts. He inquired whether the man's heirs are allowed to forgive his blood in favor of the murderer, who also has debts. Abu Abdullah replied that the creditors are the ones who have a claim against the murderer. If the heirs forgive him, they must assume responsibility for the deceased's debt to the creditors; otherwise, they are not responsible.

Hisham ibn Salim asked him about a man who entered a bathhouse and had hot water poured on him, causing the hair on his head and beard to fall out and never grow back again. He, peace be upon him, said that the man is entitled to compensation.

Be aware that for the loss of a black tooth, one-third of the tooth's compensation (diyah) is required; for a paralyzed hand, one-third of the hand's diyah is required; for a functioning eye that is blinded, one-third of the eye's diyah is required; for the earlobe, one-third of its diyah is required; for a lame foot, one-third of its diyah is required; and for each side of the nose, one-third of the diyah is required.

If a free man injures the eye or breaks the tooth of a contractual slave (mukhabar), and the slave has paid half of his contract, then the free man is treated as such in terms of recompense, or he pays the diyah if it was accidental. If the slave has not yet paid half of the contract...

text:
قوم فأدى بقدر ما أعتق منه، وإن فقأ مكاتب عين مملوك، وقد أدى نصف مكاتبته قوم المملوك، وأدى المكاتب إلى مولى العبد نصف ثمنه (1).
واعلم أن العاقلة لا تضمن عمدا، ولا إقرارا، ولا صلحا (2).
وكان أمير المؤمنين - عليه السلام - يجعل جناية المعتوه (3) على عاقلته، خطأ كانت جنايته أو عمدا (4).
وقال أبو عبد الله - عليه السلام -: قرأت في كتاب علي - عليه السلام -: لو أن رجلا قطع فرج امرأته، لأغرمته (5) ديتها، فإن لم يؤد إليها، قطعت لها فرجه إن طلبت ذلك (6).
وسأل أبو بصير أبا جعفر - عليه السلام - فقال: ما ترى في رجل ضرب امرأة شابة على بطنها، فعقر رحمها وأفسد (7) طمثها، وذكرت أنه قد ارتفع طمثها عنها لذلك، وقد كان طمثها مستقيما؟ قال: ينتظر بها سنة، فان صلح رحمها، وعاد طمثها إلى ما كان، وإلا استحلفت وأغرم ضاربها (8) ثلث ديتها، لفساد رحمها وارتفاع طمثها (9).

translation:
A person is required to pay according to the amount they have freed. If a contracted slave injures the eye of another slave and has paid half of his contract, the tribe of the injured slave should pay, and the contracted slave must pay half of the injured slave's value to the injured slave’s master.

It is important to understand that the 'aqilah (the collective responsibility of the tribe) does not cover intentional acts, admissions, or reconciliations.

Amir al-Mu'minin (peace be upon him) used to hold the 'aqilah responsible for the offenses committed by a deranged person, whether the act was intentional or accidental.

Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) mentioned that he read in the Book of Ali (peace be upon him): If a man were to mutilate the private parts of his wife, he would be required to pay her compensation. If he fails to do so and she demands it, his own private parts would be mutilated in retribution.

Abu Basir asked Abu Ja’far (peace be upon him): What do you think of a man who strikes a young woman on her abdomen, which causes her uterus to be injured and disrupts her menstrual cycle, to the extent that her regular menstruation ceases? Abu Ja'far replied that one must wait one year; if her uterus heals and her menstruation returns to normal, it is fine. Otherwise, the woman is to take an oath, and the assailant must pay one-third of her blood money as compensation for the damage to her uterus and the cessation of her menstruation.

text:
ودية اليهودي والمجوسي والنصراني وولد الزنا ثمانمائة درهم (1).
ومن حلق رأس رجل فلم ينبت فعليه مائة دينار (2)، وإن حلق لحيته فعليه الدية (3).
وكان أمير المؤمنين - عليه السلام - يفتي في كل مفصل من الأصابع بثلث عقل تلك الإصبع (4)، إلا الإبهام فإنه كان يفتي (5) في مفصلها نصف عقل تلك الإصبع، لأن لها مفصلين (6).
واعلم أن للانسان ثمانية وعشرين (7) سنا، اثني عشر في مقاديم الفم، وستة عشر في مواخره، فدية (كل سن من المقاديم إذا كسرت حتى تذهب خمسون دينارا وهي إثنى عشر، فديتها) (8) كلها ستمائة دينار، ودية كل سن من الأضراس على النصف من دية المقاديم خمسة وعشرون دينارا وهي ستة عشر ضرسا، فديتها أربعمائة دينار، فان زاد في (9) الأسنان واحد على ثمانية (10) وعشرين التي هي الخلقة السوية (11)، فلا دية له لأنه قد زاد على ثمانية وعشرين، وما نقص

translation:
The compensation for a Jew, a Zoroastrian, a Christian, and a child born out of wedlock is eight hundred dirhams. If someone shaves the head of another person and the hair does not grow back, the penalty is one hundred dinars. If a person shaves another's beard, they must pay the compensation as prescribed.

The Commander of the Faithful, peace be upon him, used to rule that the compensation for each joint of the fingers, except for the thumb, is one-third the amount for the entire finger. For the thumb, he ruled that the compensation for each joint is half the amount for the whole thumb, as it has two joints.

It is known that a human has twenty-eight teeth: twelve at the front of the mouth and sixteen at the back. The compensation for each tooth at the front if broken to the extent it falls out is fifty dinars. The total compensation for all the front teeth amounts to six hundred dinars. The compensation for each molar is half that of the front teeth, twenty-five dinars, making the total compensation for all the molars four hundred dinars. If an extra tooth grows beyond the natural count of twenty-eight, there is no compensation as it exceeds the normal creation. Any deficiency from the original number should be addressed accordingly.

فلا دية له (1).
وقضى أمير المؤمنين - عليه السلام - في جارية ركبت جارية، فنخستها (2) جارية أخرى فقمصت (3) المركوبة فصرعت الراكبة فماتت، فقضى بديتها نصفين بين الناخسة والمنخوسة (4).
وقضى - عليه السلام - في رجل أقبل بنار، فأشعلها في دار قوم، فاحترقت الدار واحترق أهلها واحترق متاعهم، أن يغرم قيمة الدار وما فيها، ثم يقتل (5).
وسئل أبو الحسن الأول - عليه السلام - عن رجل أتى رجلا وهو راقد، فلما صار على ظهره انتبه فبعجه (6) بعجة (7) فقتله، قال: لا دية له ولا قود (8).

translation:
There is no blood money for him.

The Commander of the Faithful, peace be upon him, judged in the case of a female slave who was riding another female slave. Another slave provoked the ridden slave, causing her to buck, which resulted in the rider falling and dying. He ruled that the blood money be shared equally between the provocateur and the provoked.

He also ruled, peace be upon him, in the case of a man who brought fire and set it to a people’s house, causing the house, its inhabitants, and their belongings to burn, that he should pay the value of the house and its contents and then be executed.

Abu al-Hasan the First, peace be upon him, was asked about a man who approached another man while he was sleeping, and when the man woke up to find the intruder on top of him, he cut him open and killed him. Abu al-Hasan said that there is neither blood money nor retribution for him.

Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, was asked about a case where a man exerted force on his wife or a woman exerted force on her husband, resulting in one killing the other. He said that there is no liability on either if they were both trustworthy.

اتهما لزمهما (1) اليمين بالله (أنهما لم يريدا) (2) القتل (3).
واعلم أن الناقلة (4) إذا كانت في العضو ففيها ثلث دية ذلك العضو (5).
ورفع إلى أمير المؤمنين - عليه السلام - رجل عذب عبده حتى مات، فضربه مائة نكالا (6)، وحبسه وغرمه قيمة العبد، وتصدق بها (7).

translation:
Two individuals were required to swear by Allah that they did not intend murder.

Be aware that if a moving fracture is in a limb, it entails one-third of the compensation for that limb.

A case was presented to the Commander of the Faithful, peace be upon him, involving a man who tortured his slave to death. He was given one hundred lashes as a punishment, was imprisoned, and was made to compensate the value of the slave, which was then given in charity.

The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and his family, ruled that if the heart is seized with fear and escapes, blood money is due.

He, peace be upon him, also ruled that if a nail is cut off, the compensation is ten dinars.

If a man claims that he has lost one-sixth of his vision in both eyes and one-sixth of his hearing in both ears, he is not required to swear an oath, nor is his claim accepted. This is because he has no knowledge of what portion of his hearing and sight he has lost, nor what remains. An oath is only required in cases where the truth is known; as for the unknown and ambiguous, it is not required.

فلا يستحلف عليه، ولا يقبل منه يمينه (1) (2)، فان ادعى أنه ذهب ثلث سمعه فيمينه ورجلين معه (3).
والمدبر إذا قتل رجلا خطأ، دفع (4) برمته (5) إلى أولياء المقتول، فان (6) مات الذي دبره، استسعى (7) في قيمته (8).
والمكاتب إذا قتل رجلا خطأ، فعليه من الدية بقدر ما أدى من مكاتبته، وعلى مولاه ما بقي من قيمته، فان عجز المكاتب فلا عاقلة له، فإنما ذلك على إمام المسلمين (9).
فان شهد شهود على رجل أنه قتل رجلا، ثم خولط، فان شهدوا أنه قتله وهو صحيح العقل لا علة به من ذهاب عقله، قتل به، فإن لم يشهدوا وكان له مال، دفع إلى أولياء المقتول الدية، فإن لم يكن له مال، أعطوا من بيت مال المسلمين، ولا يبطل دم امرئ مسلم (10).

translation:
He shall not be compelled to take an oath, nor is his oath accepted (1) (2). If he claims that a third of his hearing is lost, he is required to swear an oath alongside two witnesses (3).

If a slave who is promised freedom after a certain service kills a man unintentionally, he is handed over completely (4) (5) to the heirs of the deceased. If the one who promised him freedom dies, the slave must work to repay his value (6) (7) (8).

If a contractually obligated slave (mukātib) kills a man unintentionally, he must pay a portion of the blood money equivalent to what he has paid towards his freedom. The remaining value is the responsibility of his master. If the mukātib is unable to pay, he has no kinship group (ʿāqilah) to bear this responsibility, so the duty falls on the leader of the Muslims (9).

If witnesses testify that a man killed another, and then the accused becomes mentally incapacitated, they must testify that he committed the act while of sound mind, without any mental ailment, otherwise, he shall not be executed. If no such testimony exists and he possesses wealth, blood money is given to the deceased's heirs. If he possesses no wealth, it shall be distributed from the Muslims' public treasury, as the blood of a Muslim shall not be wasted in vain (10).

وإذا قطع الذمي يد رجل مسلم (قطعت يده) (1)، وأخذ فضل ما بين الديتين (2).
وإن قتل قتلوه به إن شاء أولياؤه، ويأخذوا من ماله أو من مال أوليائه فضل ما بين الديتين (3).
وإذا (4) قطع المسلم يد المعاهد خير أولياء المعاهد، فان شاؤوا أخذوا دية يده، وإن شاؤوا قطعوا يد المسلم وأدوا إليه (5) فضل ما بين الديتين، وإذا قتله المسلم صنع كذلك (6).
واعلم أن دية كلب الصيد أربعون درهما، ودية كلب الماشية عشرون درهما ودية الكلب الذي ليس للصيد ولا للماشية زنبيل (7) من (8) تراب، على القاتل أن يعطي، وعلى صاحب الكلب أن يقبله (9).

translation:
If a dhimmi (non-Muslim living under Muslim rule) cuts off the hand of a Muslim man, his hand shall be cut off, and the difference between the two blood money (diyyas) is to be taken. 

If the dhimmi kills the Muslim, he shall be executed if the heirs of the victim so wish, and they shall take from his property or the property of his heirs the difference between the two blood money compensations.

If a Muslim cuts off the hand of a mu'ahid (a non-Muslim living in a Muslim land under a peace treaty), the mu'ahid's family has the choice; if they wish, they can take the diyya for the hand, or if they prefer, they may cut off the Muslim's hand and give the difference between the two blood money amounts. Similarly, if a Muslim kills a mu'ahid, the same procedure applies.

Be informed that the blood money for a hunting dog is forty dirhams, for a livestock guard dog is twenty dirhams, and for a dog that is neither for hunting nor guarding livestock, the payment is a basket of dirt, which the killer must give, and the dog's owner must accept.

text:
وقضى أمير المؤمنين - عليه السلام - في عبد قتل حرا خطأ، فلما قتله أعتقه مولاه، فأجاز عتقه، وضمنه الدية (1).
فان قتل المكاتب رجلا خطأ، فإن كان مولاه حين كاتبه اشترط عليه أنه إن عجز فهو رد في (2) الرق، فهو بمنزلة المملوك، يدفع إلى أولياء المقتول، فان (3) شاؤوا استرقوا وإن شاؤوا باعوا، وإن كان مولاه حين كاتبه لم يشترط عليه، وقد كان أدى من مكاتبته شيئا، (فان عليا - عليه السلام - كان يقول: يعتق من المكاتب بقدر ما أدى من مكاتبته ورقا) (4)، وعلى (5) الإمام أن يؤدي (إلى أولياء المقتول من الدية) (6) بقدر ما أعتق من المكاتب، ولا يبطل دم امرئ مسلم، وأرى أن يكون ما بقي على المكاتب مما لم يؤده لأولياء (7) المقتول، يستخدمونه حياته بقدر ما بقي، وليس لهم أن يبيعوه (8).
وسأل ضريس الكناسي (9) أبا عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن امرأة وعبد قتلا رجلا خطأ، فقال: إن خطأ المرأة والعبد مثل العمد (10)، فان أحب أولياء المقتول أن

الوجه فيه أن خطأهما عمد على ما يعتقده بعض مخالفينا أنه خطأ، لأن منهم من يقول: إن كل من يقتل بغير حديد فان قتله خطأ.
translation:
The Commander of the Faithful, peace be upon him, decreed in the case of a slave who accidentally killed a free man. After the killing, the slave's master freed him. The act of freeing the slave was approved, and the master was held responsible for the blood money (diya).

In the case where a mukatab (a slave who has a contract for eventual freedom) accidentally kills a man, if the master had stipulated at the time of the contract that the mukatab would revert to slavery if he failed to fulfill his contract terms, then he would be treated like a regular slave. The heirs of the deceased may then choose to keep him as a slave or sell him. However, if the master did not make such a stipulation and the mukatab had paid part of his contract, then Ali, peace be upon him, maintained that the mukatab gains freedom equivalent to what he has paid. The imam must provide the deceased's heirs with a portion of the blood money corresponding to the amount of freedom the mukatab has earned, ensuring the blood of a Muslim is not wasted. The remaining amount owed by the mukatab should be worked off by serving the heirs of the deceased for the amount still owed, although they do not have the right to sell him.

Daris al-Kinasi asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, about a case where a woman and a slave accidentally killed a man. Abu Abdullah responded that in terms of liability, the mistake by a woman and a slave is akin to intentional killing. Therefore, if the deceased's heirs wish...

(Note: The text becomes fragmented at this point due to the inclusion of notes, but based on given commentary, it seems that the impression of mistake by women and slaves as intentional might be attributed to a differing legal interpretation by some, which contrasts with divine ruling where accidental killing is compensated by blood money rather than retribution. The belief mentioned states that killing without iron is considered erroneous is not universally accepted and is especially debated concerning those not fully legally accountable, like the mentally ill.)

text:
يقتلوهما قتلوهما، وإن كانت قيمة العبد أكثر من خمسة آلاف درهم، ردوا على سيد العبد ما يفضل بعد الخمسة آلاف درهم، وإن أحبوا أن يقتلوا المرأة ويأخذوا العبد فعلوا، إلا أن يكون قيمته أكثر من خمسة آلاف درهم، فيردوا على مولى (1) العبد ما يفضل بعد الخمسة آلاف درهم ويأخذوا العبد، أو يفتديه سيده، وإن كانت قيمة العبد أقل من خمسة آلاف درهم، فليس لهم إلا العبد (2).
واعلم أن دية الخطأ تستأدى (3) في (4) ثلاث سنين، ودية العمد تستأدى في سنة (5).
فإن قتل رجل رجلا، وليس للمقتول أولياء من المسلمين، وله أولياء من أهل الذمة من قرابته، فعلى الإمام أن يعرض على قرابته من الذمة الإسلام، فمن أسلم منهم دفع القاتل إليه، فإن شاء قتل، وإن شاء عفا (6)، وإن شاء أخذ الدية، فإن لم يسلم من قرابته أحد، كان الإمام ولي أمره، فان شاء قتل وإن شاء أخذ الدية، وليس له أن يعفو (7).

translation:
Kill them, kill both of them. If the value of the slave exceeds five thousand dirhams, they should return to the slave's master what exceeds five thousand dirhams. If they wish to kill the woman and take the slave, they may do so, unless his value is greater than five thousand dirhams. In that case, they must return to the slave's master what exceeds five thousand dirhams and take the slave, or the master may ransom him. If the value of the slave is less than five thousand dirhams, they have only the slave as compensation.

Be aware that the blood money for accidental killing is to be paid over three years, while for deliberate killing, it is to be paid in a year.

If a man kills another man, and the deceased has no Muslim relatives, but has relatives from among the Dhimmis, the imam must offer Islam to his non-Muslim relatives. If any of them converts to Islam, the killer is handed over to them; they may kill him, pardon him, or accept the blood money. If none of his relatives convert, the imam acts as his guardian. He may choose to execute or accept blood money but does not have the option to pardon.

(Note: Footnote numbers and references from the original text have been omitted for clarity in the translation.)

text:
ورويت أنه جاء رجل إلى عمر بن الخطاب ومعه رجل، فقال: إن بقرة هذا شقت بطن جملي، فقال عمر: قضى رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - فيما قتل البهائم: أنه جبار (1) - والجبار الذي لا دية له (2) ولا قود -.
فقال أمير المؤمنين - عليه السلام -: قضى النبي - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -: لا ضرر ولا ضرار (3)، إن كان صاحب البقرة ربطها على طريق الجمل فهو له ضامن، فنظروا فإذا تلك البقرة جاء بها صاحبها من السواد، وربطها على طريق الجمل، فأخذ عمر برأيه - عليه السلام -، وأغرم صاحب البقرة ثمن الجمل (4).

نقل العلامة في المختلف: ٧٩٨ عن نهاية الشيخ عن أبي بصير، عن أبي عبد الله - عليه السلام - قال: قضى أمير المؤمنين - عليه السلام - في حائط اشترك في هدمه ثلاثة نفر فوقع على واحد منهم فمات فضمن الباقين ديته، لأن كل واحد منهم ضامن صاحبه، ثم ذكر العلامة أن الصدوق رواها في الفقيه: ٤ / ١١٨ ح ١ وقال في المقنع عقيب هذه الرواية: وليس في ذلك إلا التسليم، مع أنه قال قبلها: والهدم جبار، والظاهر سقطت الرواية مع قوله في الهدم من النسخ، ولم نثبت ما ذكره في المتن لعدم نقله عنه مباشرة، وفي الكافي: ٧ / ٢٨٤ ح ٨، والتهذيب: ١٠ / 241 ح 8 مثله، عنهما الوسائل: 29 / 236 - أبواب موجبات الضمان - ب 3 ح 1 وعن الفقيه.
translation:
A man came to Umar ibn Al-Khattab with another man and said, "The cow of this man ripped open the belly of my camel." Umar replied, "The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his family, ruled regarding animals that: 'It is a matter of ghabar'—meaning there is no compensation or retaliation."

Then the Commander of the Faithful, Ali - peace be upon him - said, "The Prophet, peace be upon him and his family, ruled: 'There should be neither harm nor reciprocating harm.' If the owner of the cow tied it on the camel's path, he is responsible." Upon investigation, it was found that the cow's owner had brought it from wasteland and tied it on the camel's path. Umar accepted Ali’s opinion - peace be upon him - and made the owner of the cow pay for the camel.

This is referred to as "Jabbār" which means there is no liability. This ruling is also mentioned in collections such as "Majma’ Al-Bahrain", indicating no compensation is due in such cases.

In a different account, it is reported by the scholar, referring to the narrative from Abu Basir, from Abu Abdullah - peace be upon him - that the Commander of the Faithful - peace be upon him - ruled in a case where a wall collapsed, and three people were involved in its demolition. It fell on one of them, resulting in his death. It was ruled that the others must pay his blood money, as each was responsible for the other's actions. The scholar cited these rulings in various scholarly texts, stating that the only course was submission, though earlier it was mentioned: the demolition is "Jabbār." However, some versions of the texts omitted this narration with respect to demolition, and thus it was not included directly. Similar rulings can be found in works like "Al-Kafi" and "Al-Tahdhib," alongside other related scholarly references.

text:
باب الدخول في أعمال السلطان، وطلب الحوائج إليه روي عن أبي عبد الله - عليه السلام - أنه قال: اتقوا الله وصونوا أنفسكم بالورع (1)، وقووه (2) بالتقية والاستغناء بالله عن طلب الحوائج إلى صاحب السلطان.
واعلموا (3) أنه من خضع لصاحب سلطان ولمن يخالفه (4) على دينه طلبا لما في يديه من دنياه، أذله الله ومقته عليه، ووكله إليه، فان هو غلب على شيء من دنياه فصار إليه منه شيء، نزع الله البركة منه، ولم يأجره على شيء ينفقه في حج ولا عتق ولا بر (5).
وسأل عمار الساباطي أبا عبد الله - عليه السلام - عن عمل السلطان يخرج فيه الرجل؟ قال: لا، إلا أن لا يقدر على شيء يأكل ولا يشرب، ولا يقدر على حيلة، فان فعل فصار في يده شيء فليبعث بخمسه إلى أهل البيت (6).

translation:
Title: Entering into the Affairs of the Ruler and Seeking Needs from Him

It was narrated from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) that he said: "Fear God and protect yourselves with piety, and strengthen it with prudence and relying on God rather than seeking needs from the ruler. Know that whoever humbles himself before a ruler and compromises his faith for worldly gains, God will humiliate and detest him, and will abandon him to the ruler. If he manages to gain something of the worldly possessions, God will remove the blessings from it and will not reward him for anything he spends on pilgrimage, emancipation, or charity."

Ammar Al-Sabati once asked Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) about participating in the ruler's work. He said: "No, except if he has no means to eat or drink and cannot find any other way. If he does so and earns something, he should send a fifth of it to the family of the House."

- "Tahdhib," vol. 6, page 330, hadith 35.
- "Fiqh Al-Rida," page 367 with some variations at the beginning.
- "Tahdhib," vol. 6, page 330, hadith 36, and similar content in "Wasa'il," vol. 9, page 506 and vol. 17, page 202.

(Note: These references are cited to show the source of the teachings and to indicate the location of similar narrations within Islamic scholarly works.)

text:
وقال رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -: من ولي عشرة فلم يعدل بينهم، جاء يوم القيامة ويداه ورجلاه ورأسه في ثقب (1) فأس (2).
وقال أمير المؤمنين - عليه السلام -: أيما رجل ولي شيئا من أمور المسلمين، فأغلق بابه دونهم وأرخى ستره، فهو في مقت من الله ولعنته حتى يفتح الباب فيدخل إليه ذو الحاجة ومن كانت له مظلمة (3).
وروي أن أبا عبد الله - عليه السلام - قال للوليد بن صبيح: أما تعجب يا وليد عن زرارة، يسألني عن أعمال هؤلاء؟ متى كانت الشيعة تسأل عن هذا؟ إنما كانت تسأل يؤكل من طعامهم، ويشرب من شرابهم، ويستظل بظلهم (4).

translation:
The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him and his family, said: "Whoever governs ten or more and does not act justly among them will come on the Day of Resurrection with his hands, feet, and head in the hole of an axe."

The Commander of the Faithful, peace be upon him, said: "Any man who is entrusted with any affair concerning the Muslims and then closes his door to them and draws down his curtain, is under the abhorrence and curse of Allah until he opens the door so that the needy and those who have grievances may enter."

It is narrated that Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, said to Al-Walid ibn Subaih: "Are you not amazed, O Walid, at Zurara, who asks me about the deeds of these people? Since when did the Shia inquire about this? They used to ask whether it is permissible to eat from their food, drink from their drink, and seek shade under their shadow."

text:
باب النوادر قال والدي - رحمه الله - في رسالته إلي: إذا لبست يا بني ثوبا جديدا فقل: الحمد لله الذي كساني من اللباس (1) ما أتجمل به في الناس، اللهم اجعلها ثياب بركة أسعى فيها بمرضاتك، وأعمر فيها مساجدك، فإنه روي عن النبي - صلى الله على وآله وسلم - أنه (2) قال: من فعل ذلك لم يتقمصه (3) حتى يغفر له (4).
وإذا أردت لبس السراويل فلا تلبسه من قيام، فإنه يورث الحبن (5) وهو الماء الأصفر، ويورث الغم والهرم، وتلبسه وأنت جالس، وتقول عند ذلك: اللهم استر عورتي، (وآمن روعتي، ولا تبد عورتي) (6)، وعف فرجي، ولا تجعل للشيطان (في ذلك) (7) نصيبا ولا سبيلا، ولا له إلى ذلك وصولا، فيصنع لي (8) المكائد فيهيجني

translation:
Chapter of Anecdotes

My father - may God have mercy on him - wrote in his letter to me: "When you, my son, wear new clothes, say: 'Praise be to God who has clothed me with garments that allow me to present myself well among people. O God, make them blessed garments in which I strive to please You and fill Your mosques, for it is narrated from the Prophet - may peace and blessings be upon him and his family - that he said: Whoever does this shall not don it without being forgiven.'

And when you want to wear trousers, do not put them on while standing, for this causes disease (water retention) and brings sadness and aging. Wear them while sitting and say: 'O God, cover my private parts, protect me from fear, and do not expose my private parts. Preserve my chastity, and do not grant Satan any share or access to this, nor any way to reach it, so that he may not set traps for me and provoke me.'"

text:
لارتكاب محارمك (1).
واعلم أن غسل الثياب يذهب الهم والحزن، وهو طهور للصلاة (2).
وعليك بلبس ثياب القطن، فإنه (3) لباس (4) رسول الله - صلى الله على وآله وسلم -، ولباس الأئمة - عليهم السلام - (5)، واتق لبس السواد، فإنه لباس فرعون (6).
ولا تلبس النعل الأملس، فإنه حذو فرعون، وهو أول من اتخذ الملس (7).
وإذا اكتحلت فقل: اللهم نور بصري، واجعل فيه نورا أبصر به حكمتك، وأنظر به إليك يوم ألقاك، ولا تغش بصري [ظلماء] (8) يوم ألقاك (9).
فإذا أصبحت فقل: بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم، لا حول ولا قوة إلا بالله العلي

translation:
To commit forbidden actions against your loved ones (1).
And know that washing clothes removes worry and sadness, and it is purification for prayer (2).
And you should wear cotton clothes, for it is the attire (3) of the Messenger of Allah - peace and blessings be upon him and his family - and the attire of the Imams - peace be upon them (5), and beware of wearing black, for it is the attire of Pharaoh (6).
Do not wear smooth sandals, for they are patterned after Pharaoh's, and he was the first to make smooth ones (7).
When you apply kohl, say: "O Allah, illuminate my vision and place light within it to see Your wisdom, and so I may look upon You on the day I meet You, and do not cover my sight [in darkness] (8) on the day I meet You (9)."
When you wake up, say: "In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, there is no power and no might except with Allah, the Most High."

text:
العظيم، ثلاث مرات، فان أمير المؤمنين - عليه السلام - قال: من فعل ذلك بعد المغرب وبعد الصبح، صرف الله عنه سبعين لونا من البلاء، أدناها الجذام، والبرص، والسلطان، والشيطان (1).
وروي عن أبي عبد الله - عليه السلام - أنه قال: لا تدع أن تقول: بسم الله وبالله، في كل صباح ومساء، فان في ذلك إصرافا لكل سوء (2).
وإن تهيأ لك أن تتناول في كل يوم إحدى وعشرين زبيبة حمراء على الريق فافعل، فإنها تدفع جميع الأمراض إلا مرض الموت (3).
وإذا نظرت في المرآة، فقل: الحمد لله الذي خلقني فأحسن خلقي، وصورني فأحسن صورتي، وزان مني ما شان من غيري، وأكرمني بالإسلام (4).
فإذا أردت أخذ (5) المشط فخذه بيدك اليمنى، وقل: بسم الله، وضعه على أم رأسك، ثم سرح مقدم رأسك وقل: اللهم حسن شعري وبشري وطيبهما، واصرف عني الوباء.

translation:
The Great, three times, for the Commander of the Faithful - peace be upon him - said: Whoever does this after sunset and after dawn, God will turn away from him seventy types of calamities, the least of which are leprosy, vitiligo, domination, and the devil (1).

And it is narrated from Abu Abdullah - peace be upon him - that he said: Do not neglect to say: In the name of God and by God, every morning and evening, for it wards off all evil (2).

And if you can, eat twenty-one red raisins on an empty stomach each day, for they prevent all diseases except the disease of death (3).

And when you look in the mirror, say: Praise be to God, who created me and made my creation excellent, shaped me finely, adorned in me what he disfigured in others, and honored me with Islam (4).

If you wish to take a comb, take it with your right hand, say: In the name of God, place it on the top of your head, and then comb the front of your head, saying: O God, beautify my hair and my skin and make them pleasant and divert from me all disease.

text:
ثم سرح مؤخر رأسك وقل: اللهم لا تردني على عقبي، واصرف عني كيد الشيطان، ولا تمكنه من قيادي (1) فيردني على عقبي.
ثم سرح حاجبك وقل: اللهم زيني زينة (2) أهل الهدى، ثم سرح لحيتك من فوق وقل: اللهم سرح عني الغموم، والهموم، ووسوسة الصدور (3)، ووسوسة الشيطان، ثم أمر المشط على صدرك (4).
وإذا أخذت في حاجة فامسح وجهك بماء الورد، فإنه من فعل ذلك (5)، لم يرهق وجهه قتر ولا ذلة (6).
فإذا لبست خاتما فقل: اللهم سومني بسيماء الإيمان (7)، وتوجني بتاج الملك وقلدني حبل الإسلام، ولا تخلع ربقة الإيمان من عنقي (8).
وابدأ بالملح في أول الطعام، فلو علم (9) الناس ما في الملح، لاختاروه على

translation:
Then comb the back of your head and say: "O Allah, do not turn me back on my heels, and ward off from me the scheming of Satan, and do not let him take control of my reins, causing me to turn back on my heels." Then comb your eyebrows and say: "O Allah, adorn me with the adornment of the guided ones." Next, comb your beard from above and say: "O Allah, remove from me worries, concerns, and the whisperings of the hearts and the whisperings of Satan." Then pass the comb over your chest.

And if you have a need, wipe your face with rose water, for whoever does so will have neither dust nor humiliation cover their face. When you wear a ring, say: "O Allah, mark me with the mark of faith, crown me with the crown of sovereignty, necklace me with the rope of Islam, and do not remove the loop of faith from my neck."

Start with salt at the beginning of your meal, for if people knew what is in the salt, they would choose it over all else.

text:
الترياق (1) المجرب (2).
ومن بدأ (في طعامه) (3) بالملح، ذهب عنه سبعون نوعا من الداء، وما لا يعلمه إلا الله (4).
وإذا انتبهت من نومك فقل: لا إله إلا الله الحي القيوم، وهو على كل شيء قدير، سبحان إله النبيين وإله المرسلين، وسبحان رب السماوات السبع (5) وما فيهن، ورب الأرضين السبع ومن فيهن، ورب العرش العظيم، والحمد لله رب العالمين (6).
وإذا أردت لبس الخف والنعل فقل: (بسم الله) (7)، اللهم صل على محمد (وآل محمد، ووطئ قدمي في الدنيا والآخرة وثبتهما) (8)، وثبت قدمي على الصراط يوم تزل فيه الأقدام، فإذا خلعتهما (9) فقل:
بسم الله، الحمد لله الذي رزقني ما أوقي به قدمي من الأذى، (اللهم ثبتهما على صراطك ولا تزلهما عن صراطك السوي) (10) (11).

translation:
**The Tried (1) Remedy (2).**

Whoever begins their meal (3) with salt will be protected from seventy types of ailments, known only to God (4).

When you wake up from sleep, say: "There is no deity but God, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of existence, and He is over all things competent. Glory be to the God of the prophets and the God of the messengers; Glory be to the Lord of the seven heavens (5) and all within them, the Lord of the seven earths and all within them, and the Lord of the magnificent Throne. Praise be to God, the Lord of all worlds" (6).

When you wish to put on your socks or shoes, say: "In the name of God" (7), "O God, bless Muhammad (and the family of Muhammad, and firmly place my feet in this world and the Hereafter, and stabilize them)" (8), and stabilize my feet on the Path on the Day when feet will slip. When you remove them (9), say: "In the name of God, praise be to God who provided me with what protects my feet from harm, (O God, stabilize them on Your Path and do not let them slip from Your straight Path)" (10) (11).

text:
ولا تلبسهما (1) إلا جالسا (2)، وتبدأ (3) باليمنى (4)، فإذا خلعتهما خلعتهما من قيام (5).
وإذا خرجت من منزلك فقل: بسم الله، لا حول ولا قوة إلا بالله، توكلت على الله، فإنك إذا فعلت ذلك، ناداك ملك في قولك: «بسم الله» هديت، وفي قولك: «لا حول ولا قوة إلا بالله» وقيت، وفي قولك: «توكلت على الله» كفيت، فيقول الشيطان: كيف لي بعبد هدي ووقي وكفي (6).
واتق أكل الغدد من اللحم، فإنه يحرك (7) عرق الجذام (8)، وكل التمر، فإن فيه شفاء من كل داء (9).

translation:
Do not wear them except while sitting, and start with the right foot. When you remove them, do so while standing. 

When you leave your house, say: "In the name of Allah, there is no power and no strength except with Allah, I have placed my trust in Allah." If you do this, an angel will call out, with your saying "In the name of Allah" you are guided, with "there is no power and no strength except with Allah" you are protected, and with "I have placed my trust in Allah" you are sufficed. The Shaytan will then say, "What can I do with a servant who has been guided, protected, and sufficed?"

Avoid eating the glands of the meat as it activates the veins of leprosy. Eat dates, for they contain a cure for every disease.

text:
وعليك بكثرة الاستغفار، فإنه يجلب الرزق (1).
وقدم ما استطعت من عمل الخير تجده غدا (2).
وإياك والجدال والقياس (3) في الدين، فإنه يورث الشك (4).
وعليك بطول السجود في الصلاة، فإنه (5) ما (6) من عمل أشد على إبليس لعنه الله من أن يرى ابن آدم ساجدا، لأنه أمر بالسجود فعصى، وهذا أمر بالسجود فأطاع فنجا (7).
وروي: إذا أطال العبد سجوده، قال إبليس: ويله أطاعوا وعصيت، وسجدوا وأبيت (8).
وإذا اشتكى أحدكم عينه (9)، فليقرأ آية الكرسي، (ويضمر في قلبه) (10) (11).

translation:
And you should frequently seek forgiveness, as it brings about sustenance. (1) Offer as much good deeds as you can, for you will find them tomorrow. (2) Beware of disputes and analogical reasoning in matters of religion, as they lead to doubt. (3)(4) Engage in prolonged prostration during your prayers, for there is no act more distressing to the accursed Satan than when he sees a son of Adam prostrate. He was commanded to prostrate but disobeyed, while this one was commanded and obeyed, thus he was saved. (5)(6)(7) It is narrated: when a servant prolongs his prostration, Satan laments: "Woe to me, they obeyed and I disobeyed, they prostrated and I refused." (8) If any of you has an ailment in his eye, let him recite Ayat al-Kursi, contemplating it in his heart. (9)(10)(11)
